text: A civil suit was contested between the brothers of the deceased Sunanda
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The defence version is not reliable and believable that the appellant Nilesh was not residing with his mother
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In stead it was suggested that as father of the appellant Nilesh being Government Medical Officer was engaged in transferable job so he had made arrangement wherein his wife would stay at the village along with his son
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Recovery of articles made by the police is incriminating in nature
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The medical evidence supports the prosecution case
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It was submitted that conduct of the appellant Nilesh has to be minutely and seriously viewed
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Here is a son who had committed murder of his mother by severely beating and strangulating
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: If the police had not arrived at the spot at the relevant time the appellant Nilesh would have cremated his mother and the evidence would have disappeared
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 17 We have perused the entire evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: We find that the conduct of the appellant Nilesh is blameworthy
label: ANALYSIS

text: No explanation is coming forward as to why in spite of receiving serious injuries by the deceased the appellant Nilesh son of the deceased made arrangements for cremating his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: Soon before the dead body was to be taken for cremation the police reached the spot and could witness the injuries on the person of deceased Sunanda
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant Nilesh did not brother to lodge any formal report to the police
label: ANALYSIS

text: No intimation was given to anybody in respect of injuries suffered by his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: His keeping silence goes against his plea of innocence
label: ANALYSIS

text: In normal circumstance son would certainly raise hue and cry after seeing his mother in injured condition
label: ANALYSIS

text: She had died unnatural death
label: ANALYSIS

text: The medical evidence has supported the prosecution version
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the statement under section 313 of the Criminal Procedure Code the appellant Nilesh had stated thus Q No 46
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why witnesses are deposing against you
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ans I say that land in name of my mother situated at Ahmedpur which having plotings
label: ANALYSIS

text: My maternal uncle Mama Sudhakar Nagargoje wants to grab that land standing in name of mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: Witnesses are telling false story at instance of my maternal uncle Sudhakar Nagargoje 18
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if for the sake of argument it is believed that Sudhakar had involved appellant Nilesh in the commission of murder of his mother but the question remains as to why the appellant maintained silence throughout and instead showed haste in preparation for cremating his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19 From the evidence we can gather that though the appellant had taken a plea that he was not residing with his mother but instead residing in the house of one Motiram Gitte as a tenant the plea is not convincing
label: ANALYSIS

text: The house where mother of the deceased was residing was owned by appellant Nilesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no reason coming forward as to why appellant Nilesh was said to be residing separately from his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: When the evidence indicates that father of the appellant Nilesh had made this arrangement so that the mother and son could stay together as he was discharging his duties as a Government Medical Officer there is no convincing reason to accept the plea of the defence in respect of separate residence of Nilesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: 20 The other strong circumstance going against the appellant Nilesh is the post mortem report which indicates that the deceased was mercilessly beaten and thereafter strangulated
label: ANALYSIS

text: The cause of death is asphyxia due to strangulation
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was an unnatural death
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant Nilesh has not explained anything regarding the circumstances resulting into death of his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21 The villagers had gathered and the dead body was to be taken for cremation
label: ANALYSIS

text: Till this moment the appellant has not whispered to anybody regarding the circumstances in which the deceased suffered injuries or whether the appellant had any suspicion or doubt about conduct of any other persons who might have caused these injuries to his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: The testimony of PW 3 Sudhakar clearly blames the appellant Nilesh and indicates that he was having interest in the property which was a valuable property belonging to his mother
label: ANALYSIS

text: 22 Another intriguing feature in the case is silence of the husband of deceased Sunanda
label: ANALYSIS

text: The police officers tried for three to four times to elicit from husband of the deceased Sunanda but he was reluctant to make any statement
label: ANALYSIS

text: This further causes shadow on the plea of innocence raised by the appellant Nilesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: 23 On behalf of the defence it was submitted that PW 3 Sudhakar did not attend the funeral of deceased Sunanda
label: ANALYSIS

text: By that conduct of PW 3 Sudhakar we cannot discard the prosecution version for upholding innocence of the appellant Nilesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: 24 We do not find any convincing reasoning to hold that due to political pressure the police falsely involved the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: Appellant Nilesh had ample opportunity and time to say something till fag end of the trial regarding the incident in question but except blaming PW 3 Sudhakar the appellant Nilesh preferred not to say anything further
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the prosecution evidence we do not notice that any other person residing in the village had grudge against the deceased to mercilessly beat her and strangulate her
label: ANALYSIS

text: No other person was shown to be the beneficiary if Sunanda is done to death
label: ANALYSIS

text: If it is presumed that PW 3 Sudhakar was interested in involving the appellant Nilesh in the crime so as to grab the property of Sunanda then just because Nilesh is involved in the crime his legal rights to the property do not get extinguished
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore theory propounded by the defence on that count is also not convincing and sustainable
label: ANALYSIS

text: 25 Considering the facts of the case certain inferences are required to be drawn to the extent of conduct of the appellant Nilesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: The haste shown to cremate his mother speaks for itself and indicates guilty mind of the appellant Nilesh
label: ANALYSIS

text: 26 As regards the appellant Balasaheb we find that he has been involved with allegation that as he had helped appellant Nilesh in commission of the crime
label: ANALYSIS

text: Except recovery at the instance of appellant Balasaheb the prosecution has failed to bring home guilty of Balasaheb
label: ANALYSIS

text: Recovery is not incriminating in nature
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution evidence is lacking to establish active involvement of appellant Balasaheb Gangadhar Gitte
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no motive for Balasaheb to assist appellant Nilesh in commission of the crime
label: ANALYSIS

text: 27 We have perused the reasoning adopted by the trial Court in convicting both the appellants
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are not convinced with the reasoning of the trial Court in convicting and sentencing the appellant Balasaheb Gitte
label: ANALYSIS

text: At the same time the trial Court has scanned the evidence properly and reached appropriate conclusions while convicting and sentencing appellant Nilesh Baburao Gitte
label: ANALYSIS

text: 28 We have perused the case law submitted by the learned counsel Shri Warma in respect of the principles that in a case based on circumstantial evidence the motive plays vital role
label: RATIO

text: The chain of circumstances must be so complete so as to clearly point out that the appellant alone must the guilty person
label: RATIO

text: These circumstances shall be conclusively established and in case the chain of circumstances is not complete then benefit goes to the accused
label: RATIO

text: Considering the facts circumstances and the evidence brought on record we are of the opinion that the conviction and sentence awarded by the trial Court against the appellant Nilesh Baburao Gitte is required to be confirmed whereas we are not inclined to confirm the finding of guilt recorded by the trial Court against the appellant Balasaheb Gangadhar Gitte
label: RATIO

text: ORDER 29 Criminal Appeal No 447 of 2012 is dismissed
label: RPC

text: 30 Criminal Appeal No 502 of 2012 is allowed
label: RPC

text: The judgment and order dated 22 6 2012 passed by the learned Additional Sessions Judge 2 Ambajogai in Sessions Case No 42 of 2011 convicting the appellant Balasaheb Gangadhar Gitte for an offence punishable under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code and sentencing him to suffer imprisonment for life and to pay fine of Rs 2 000 in default to suffer simple imprisonment for three months
label: RPC

text: is quashed and set aside
label: RPC

text: The appellant Balasaheb Gangadhar Gitte is acquitted of the offence for which he was tried
label: RPC

text: He be set at liberty forthwith if not required in any other case
label: RPC

text: Fine amount if paid be refunded to him
label: RPC

text: Sd Sd A I S CHEEMA J NARESH H PATIL J rsl
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER HETHUBHA ALIAS JITHUBA MADHUBA ORS Vs
label: PREAMBLE

text: RESPONDENT THE STATE OF GUJARAT DATE OF JUDGMENT 13 03 1970 BENCH RAY A N
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH RAY A N DUA I D CITATION 1970 AIR 1266 1971 SCR 1 31 1970 SCC 1 720 CITATOR INFO F 1971 SC1836 6 E 1981 SC 365 2 3 ACT Code of Criminal Procedure 1898 s 429 Difference of opinion among two Judges If third Judge can deal with whole case Indian Penal Code 1860 S 34 Scope of Accused acting pursuant to pre arranged plan to attack two persons Killing one person by mistake instead of the other If common intention can be inferred
label: PREAMBLE

text: HEADNOTE The three appellants were charged with offences under ss 302 and 323 read with s 34 of the Penal Code and appellants 1 and 2 were charged with the individual offences under ss 302 and 323 for intentionally causing the death of A mistaking him for V and for causing simple hurt to V
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Sessions Judge acquitted all the three accused under s 302 read with s 34 but convicted them under s 304 Part 11 read with s 34 and sentenced them to suffer rigorous imprisonment for five years
label: PREAMBLE

text: Appellants 1 and 2 were also convicted for the offence under s 323 and
label: PREAMBLE

text: appellant 3 was convicted for the offence under s 323 read with s 34
label: PREAMBLE

text: All three were sentenced for these convictions to rigorous imprisonment for terms
label: PREAMBLE

text: to run concurrently
label: PREAMBLE

text: On appeal to a Division Bench of the High Court one learned Judge held that the first appellant alone was responsible for the fatal injury on A and found him guilty under s 302 while the second and third appellants were found guilty under s 324 read with s 34
label: PREAMBLE

text: The second learned Judge was of the view that all the accused must be acquitted as he was not satisfied with the evidence and proof of the identity of the accused
label: PREAMBLE

text: The case was then placed before
label: PREAMBLE

text: a third learned Judge under s 429 Cr P C who held that the first appellant must be convicted under s 302 while the second and third appellants must be convicted under s 302 read with s 34 and all of them must be sentenced to suffer rigorous prisonment for life
label: PREAMBLE

text: The conviction of the first and second appellants under s 323 and of the third appellant under s 323 read with s 34
label: PREAMBLE

text: was upheld
label: PREAMBLE

text: In appeal to this Court it was contended i that the third learned Judge under s 429 Cr P C could only deal with the differences between the two learned Judges and not with the whole case and ii that there was no comnmittee intend on within the meaning of supp I P C on the part of the three appellants to kill A as he was attacked by mistake HELD Dismissing the appeal
label: PREAMBLE

text: i Section on of the Criminal Procedure Code states that when the judges comprising the Court of Appeal are equally divided in opinion the case with their opinion thereon shall be laid before another Judge of the same Court and such Judge after hearing if any as he thinks fit shall deliver his opinion and the judgment or order shall follow such before another Judge and secondly the Judgment and order will follow the opinion of the third learned Judge
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is therefore manifest that the third learned Judge can or will deal with the whole case
label: PREAMBLE

text: 35 D F Babu and Ors v State of Uttar Pradesh 1965 2 S C R 771 referred to
label: PREAMBLE

text: ii The plea that A was mistaken for V would not take away the common intention established by a pre arranged plan and participation of all the accused in furtherance of common intention
label: PREAMBLE

text: The act might be done by one of the several persons in furtherance of the common intention of them all without each one of them having intended to do the particular act in exactly the same way as an act might be done by one member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common intention which the other members of the unlawful assembly did not each intend to be don
label: PREAMBLE

text: 36 H On the facts it was clear that the attack took place in pursuance of a pre arranged plan
label: PREAMBLE

text: The attack by appellants 1 and 2 on A and the evidence showing that appellant 3 held back P during the attack all proved common intention participation and united criminal behaviour of all appellant 3 was therefore equally responsible and guilty with appellants 1 and 2 who had attacked A Shankarlal Kachrabbhai and Ors v State of Gujarat 1965 1 S C R 287 referred to
label: PREAMBLE

text: The dominant feature of s 34 is the element of participation in actions
label: PREAMBLE

text: This participation need not in all cases be by physical presence
label: PREAMBLE

text: Common intention implies acting in concert
label: PREAMBLE

text: There is a pre arranged plan which is proved either from conduct or from circumstances or from incriminating facts
label: PREAMBLE

text: The principle of joint liability in the doing of a criminal act is embodied in s 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: The existence of common intention is to be the basis of liability
label: PREAMBLE

text: That is why the prior concert and the pre arranged plan is the foundation of common intention to establish liability and guilt
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No 100 of 1967
label: NONE

text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 13 1967 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No 566 of 1965
label: NONE

text: J L Hathi K L Hathi and K N Bhat for the appellant
label: NONE

text: S K Dholakia Badri Das Sharma and S P Nayar for the respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ray J
label: NONE

text: This is an appeal from the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat
label: FAC

text: The appellants were charged with offences under sections 302 and 323 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: FAC

text: Accused Nos 1 and 2 were charged for the individual offences under sections 302 and 323 of the Indian Penal Code for intentionally causing death of Amarji and for causing simple hurt to Vaghji Mansangji
label: FAC

text: The deceased Amarji was the brother in law sister s husband of Vaghji Mansangji
label: FAC

text: Two important eyewitnesses were Pabaji Dajibha and Pachanji Kesarji
label: FAC

text: Amarjiwas Pabaji s mother s sister s son
label: FAC

text: Pachanji is the first cousin of Vaghji Mansangji
label: FAC

text: Accused No 3 Mulubha is the maternal uncle mother s bro ther of accused No 2 Ranubha Naranji and accused No 1 Hethubha alias Jitubha is the son of another maternal uncle of accused No 2
label: FAC

text: Accused No 2 was residing at Bhalot
label: FAC

text: Vaghji also resided there
label: FAC

text: About two months prior to the date of the occurrence on 26 January 1965 at 8 p m there was a quarrel between the children of the house of accused No 2 Ranubha and the children of the house of Vaghji
label: FAC

text: There was exchange of words between the members of the two families
label: FAC

text: Accused No
label: FAC

text: 2 Ranubha and his father Naranji assaulted the wife of Vaghji
label: FAC

text: Vaghji then filed a complaint
label: FAC

text: Ultimately the complaint was compounded on the intervention of accused No 3 Mulubha
label: FAC

text: The prosecution case is that because of the behaviour of accused No 2 Ranubha towards the wife of Vaghji Ranubha had to leave his own village of Bhalot and had to go to reside with his maternal uncles at Bhuvad
label: FAC

text: The further prosecution case is that the relations of Ranubha thereafter went to village Bhalot for fetching the goods of Ranubha and at that time they had threatened Vaghji and others that Ranubha had to leave the village and Vaghji and others would not be able to continue to reside in the village
label: FAC

text: On 26 January 1965 Amarji Pabaji Vaghji and Pachanji took their carts of fuel wood for selling it in the village Khedoi which is about 7 miles from Bhalot
label: FAC

text: They left Bhalot at about 10 a m and reached Khedoi at about 1 p m
label: FAC

text: The cart loads of fuel wood were sold in Khadoi by about 5 p m
label: FAC

text: They made some purchases and then left Khedoi at about 7 p m
label: FAC

text: While returning home Amarjis cart was in the front and Pabaji Pachanji and Vaghji followed him in
label: FAC

text: that order
label: FAC

text: There was not much distance between each cart
label: FAC

text: When the carts had gone about 2 miles from Khedoi and they were about to enter village Mathda the three accused persons were noticed waiting on the roads
label: FAC

text: All of them caught hold of Amarji and attacked him who was in the first cart
label: FAC

text: In the meantime accused No 3 Mulubha caught hold of the hand of Pabaji and prevented him from going near Amarji
label: FAC

text: Mulubha was armed with an axe
label: FAC

text: Accused Nos 1 and 2 dealt knife blows to Amarji
label: FAC

text: The prosecution suggested that the accused persons realised their mistake that instead of Vaghji they had attacked Amarji and so both the accused Nos 1 and 2 left Amarji and went to the cart of Vaghji and gave blows with sticks to Vaghji
label: FAC

text: On seeing the attack on vaghji Pabaji intervened and asked the accused to desist from attacking Vaghji anylonger as they had already killed Amarji
label: FAC

text: Thereupon the accused stopped attacking Vaghji
label: FAC

text: By this time Amarji had come staggering to the spot where Pabaji was standing
label: FAC

text: Then Amarji was placed in one of the carts and Vaghji was made to sit in that cart
label: FAC

text: Pachanji drove his cart first and the two carts without any drivers which had been formerly driven by Vaghji and Amarji were kept in the middle and Pabaji with the two injured men in his cart was driving his cart last
label: FAC

text: The carts were taken to village Khedoi
label: FAC

text: It is the prosecution case that the three accused persons followed these carts up to a certain distance and then accused Nos 1 and 2 left while accused No 3 disappeared near Khari Vadi
label: FAC

text: Pabaji took the carts to Moti khedoi and saw police head constable Banesing who had come to Khedoi for patrolling work
label: FAC

text: Banesing was attached to the police outpost at Bhuvad
label: FAC

text: Banesing directed these persons to take Amarji to the Khedoi hospital
label: FAC

text: By that time Amarji had died
label: FAC

text: Banesing left Khedoi with Pabaji for Anjar police station which is about 8 miles from Khedoi
label: FAC

text: They reached Anjar at about 11 p m and Pabaji s F I R was recorded before police sub inspector Khambholja
label: FAC

text: The police sub inspector then preceded to Khedoi hospital
label: FAC

text: Amarji was declared to be dead
label: FAC

text: The police sub inspector recorded the statements of Vaghji and Pachanji and then took steps in the investigation of the case
label: FAC

text: At the trial all the three accused denied having committed the offence The Sessions Judge acquitted all the three persons under section 302 read with section 34
label: RLC

text: He however convicted all the accused for the offence punishable under section 304 Part II read with section 34 and sentenced them to suffer rigorous imprisonment for five years
label: RLC

text: Accused Nos 1 and 2 were convicted for the offence under section 323 and accused No 3 was convicted for the offence under section 323 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: RLC

text: Accused Nos 1 and 2 were sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three months while accused No 3 was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for two months
label: RLC

text: All the sentences were to run concurrent All the accused filed appeals against their convictions
label: FAC

text: Before the Division Bench in the High Court of Gujarat Divan J held that accused No 1 alone was responsible for the fatal injury on Amarji and he was found guilty for the offence under section 302 while accused Nos 2 and 3 were found guilty for the offence under section 324 read with section 34
label: RLC

text: Shelat J was of the view that all the accused must acquitted because he was not satisfied with the evidence and proof of the identity of the accused
label: RLC

text: The case was then placed under Section 429 of Criminal Procedure Code before Mehta J who held that accused No 1must be Convicted for the offence under section 302 while accused Nos 2 and 3 must be convicted for the offence under section 302 read with section 34 and all of them should be sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for life
label: RLC

text: The conviction of accused Nos 1 and 2 under section 323 and of accused No 3 under section 323 read with section 34 was upheld
label: FAC

text: The conviction of all the accused under section 304 Part 11 was altered by convicting accused No 1 under section 302 and accused Nos 2 and 3 under section 302 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: FAC

text: Counsel for the appellants contended first that the third learned Judge under section 429 of the Criminal Procedure Code could only deal with the differences between the two learned Judges and not with the whole case
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The same contention had been advanced before Mehta J in the High Court who rightly held that under section 429 of the Criminal Procedure Code the whole case was to be dealt with by him
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Court in Babu and Ors v State of Uttar Peadesh 1 held that it was for tic third learned Judge to decide on what points the arguments would be heard and therefore he was free to resolve the differences as he thought fit
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Mehta J here dealt with the whole case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Section 429 of the Criminal Procedure Code states that when the Judges comprising the Court of Appeal are equally divided in opinion the case with their opinion thereon shall be laid before another Judge of the same Court and such Judge after such hearing if any as he thinks fit shall deliver his opinion and the judgment or order shall follow such opinion
label: STA

text: Two things are noticeable first that the case shall be laid before another Judge and secondly the judgment and order will follow the opinion of the third learned Judge
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is therefore manifest that the third learned Judge can or will deal with the whole case
label: ANALYSIS

text: The second and the main contention of counsel for the ap pellants was that there was no common intention to kill Amarji
label: ANALYSIS

text: The finding of fact is that the attack the three accused was a concerted one under prearranged plan
label: ANALYSIS

text: Amarji Was attacked by mistake but whosoever inflicted injury in the region of the collar bone of Amarji must be held guilty of murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: under section 302
label: ANALYSIS

text: Amarji was further found to have been attacked by accused Nos 1 and 2 and accused No 3 who was armed with an axe caught hold of the hand of Pabaji
label: ANALYSIS

text: The injury on Amarji was an incised wound 1 3 4 3 4 over the left side of the neck neck just above the left collar bone
label: ANALYSIS

text: The direction of the wound was was towards right and downwards
label: ANALYSIS

text: The other injury was incised 1 1965 2 S C R 771 wound 1 1 2 1 2 over the chest right side near the middle line between the 6th and 7 ribs
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence establishes these features first that all the accused were related secondly they were residing at Bhuvad at the relevant time thirdly all the three accused made sudden appearance on the scene of the occurrence fourthly they started assault as soon as the carts arrived at the scene of the offence fifthly the way in which Amarji was attacked by accused Nos 1 and 2 and stab wounds were infficted on him and the manner in which accused No 3 held up Pabaji would show that the three accused were lying in wait under some pre arranged plan to attack these persons when they were returning to Bhalot
label: ANALYSIS

text: It therefore follows that the attack took place in pursuance of the pre arranged plan and the rapidity with which the attacks Were made also shows the pre concerted plan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The attack by accused Nos 1 and 2 on Amarji and the holding up of Pabaji by accused No 3 all prove common intention participation and united criminal behaviour of all and therefore accused No 3 would be equally responsible with accused Nos 1 and 2 who had attacked Amarji
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Court in the case of Shankarlal Kachrabhai and Ors v State of Gujarat 1
label: PRE_RELIED

text: said that a mistake by one of the accused as to killing X in place of Y would not displace the common intention if the evidence showed the concerted action in furtherance of pre arranged plan
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The dominant feature of section 34 is the element of participation in actions
label: ANALYSIS

text: This participation need not in all cases be by physical presence
label: ANALYSIS

text: Common intention implies acting in concert
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is a pre arranged plan which is proved either from conduct or from circumstances of from incriminating facts
label: ANALYSIS

text: The principle of joint liability in the doing of a criminal act is embodied in section 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: ANALYSIS

text: The existence of common intention is to be the basis of liability
label: ANALYSIS

text: That is why the prior concert and the pre arranged plan is the foundation of common intention to establish liability and guilt
label: ANALYSIS

text: Applying these principles to the evidence in the present case it appears that there was pre arranged plan of the accused to commit offences
label: ANALYSIS

text: All the accused were lying in wait to attack the party of Amarji Vaghji Pabaji and Pachanji
label: ANALYSIS

text: Amarji was in the forefront
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused attacked him
label: ANALYSIS

text: Vaghji was also attacked and prevented from going to the relief of Amarji
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plea that Amarji was mistaken for Vaghji would not take away the common intention established by pre arranged plan and participation of all the accused in furtherance of common intention
label: ANALYSIS

text: The act might be done by one of the several persons in furtherance of the common intention of them all without each one of them having intended 1 1965 1 S C R 287 to do the particular act in exactly the same way as an act might be done by one member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common intention which the other members of the unlawful assembly did not each intend to be done In view of the evidence that Amarji was killed in furtherance of the common intention of all the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: the appellants are guilty of murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Shankarlal s case 1 this Court said that if the common intention was to kill A and if one of the accused killed B to wreck his private vengeance it could not be possibly in furtherance of the common intention for which others can be liable
label: ANALYSIS

text: But if on the other hand he killed B bona fide believing that he was A and the common intention was to kill A the killing of B was in furtherance of the common intention
label: ANALYSIS

text: All the three accused in the present case were lying in wait and assaulted the driver of the first cart and stabbed him in pursuance of their prearranged plan
label: RATIO

text: Therefore all the three accused including the appellant must share the liability of murder under section 302 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: RATIO

text: Further in view of the finding that the the concerted plan was to cause injuries to the intended victim with dangerous weapons with which the assailants were lying in wait the liability of the appellant is established
label: RATIO

text: The conclusion of Mehta J is correct
label: RPC

text: The appeal there fore fails and is dismissed
label: RPC

text: The accused must surrender to the bail and serve out the sentences
label: RPC

text: R K P S Appeal dismissed
label: RPC

text: PETITIONER BHARWADA BHOGINBHAI HIRJIBHAI Vs RESPONDENT STATE OF GUJARAT DATE OF JUDGMENT24 05 1983 BENCH THAKKAR M P J BENCH THAKKAR M P J SEN A P J CITATION 1983 AIR 753 1983 SCR 3 280 1983 SCALE 1 665 1983 SCC 3 217 10 14 CITATOR INFO 247 27 RF 1988 SC 696 14 19 R 1988 SC1883 R 1989 SC1890 R 1990 SC 658 ACT Constitution of India 1950 Article 136 read with order XXI of the Supreme Court Rules 7966 Concurrent finding of fact when can be reopened by the Supreme Court in an appeal by Special Leave explained Evidence Reappreciation of evidence in the context of minor discrepancies explained Evidence Corroborative evidence in rape cases
label: PREAMBLE

text: Whether when and to what extent corroboration to the testimony of a victim of rape is essential to establish the charge
label: PREAMBLE

text: HEADNOTE The appellant a government servant employed in the Sachivalaya at Gandhinagar was found guilty by the Sessions Judge Mehsna of serious charges of sexual misbehaviour with two young girls aged about 10 or 12 and was convicted for the offence of rape outraging the modesty of women and wrongful confinement
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appeal carried to the High Court substantially failed
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court affirmed the orders of conviction under section 342 I P C for wrongfully confining the girls and conviction under Section 354 I P C for outraging the modesty of the two girls
label: PREAMBLE

text: With regard to the more serious charge of rape on one of the girls the High Court came to the conclusion that what was established by evidence was an offence or attempt to commit rape and not of rape
label: PREAMBLE

text: Accordingly the conviction under Section 376 was altered into one under Section 376 read with Section Sl I I P C
label: PREAMBLE

text: Dismissing the appeal and maintaining the conviction on all counts
label: PREAMBLE

text: Court HELD 1 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: A concurrent finding of fact as recorded by the Sessions Court and affirmed by the High Court cannot be reopened in an appeal by Special Leave
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is conceivable in the Western Society that a female may level false accusation as regards sexual molestation against a male for several reasons such as 1 The female may be a golddigger and may well have an economic motive to extract money by holding out the gun of prosecution or public exposure 2 She may be suffering from psychological neurosis and may seek an escape from the neurotic prison by phantasizing or imagining a situation where she is desired wanted and chased by males
label: PREAMBLE

text: 3 She may want to wreak vengence on the male for real or imaginary wrongs
label: PREAMBLE

text: She may have a grudge against a particular male or males in general and may have the design to square the account 4 She may have been induced to do so in consideration of economic rewards by a person interested in placing the accused in a compromising or embarassing position on account of personal or political vendetta 5 She may do so
label: PREAMBLE

text: to gain notoriety or publicity or to appease her own ego or
label: PREAMBLE

text: to satisfy her feeling of self importance in the context of her inferiority complex 6 She may do so on account of jealousy 7 She may do so to win sympathy of others 8 She may do so upon being repulsed
label: PREAMBLE

text: By and large these factors are not relevant to India and the Indian Conditions
label: PREAMBLE

text: Rarely will a girl or a woman in India make such false allegations of sexual assault whether she belongs to the urban or rural society or sophisticated or not so sophisticated or unsophisticated society
label: PREAMBLE

text: Only very rerely can one conceivably come accross an exception or two and that too possibily from amongst the urban elites
label: PREAMBLE

text: Because 1 A girl or a woman in the tradition bound non permissive Society of India would be extremely reluctant even to admit that any incident which is likely to reflect on her chastity had ever occurred 2 She would be conscious of the danger of being ostracised by the Society or being looked down by the society including by her own family members relatives friends and neighbours 3 She would have to brave the whole world 4 She would face the risk of losing the love and respect of her own husband and near relatives and of her matrimonial home and happiness being shattered 5 If she is unmarried she would apprehend that it would be difficult to secure an alliance with a suitable match from a respectable or an acceptable family 6 lt would almost inevitably and almost invariably result in mental torture and suffering to herself 7 The tear of being taunted by others will always haunt her 8 She would feel
label: PREAMBLE

text: extremely embarrassed in relating the incident to others being over powered by feeling of shame on account of the upbringing in a tradition bound society where by and large sex is taboo
label: PREAMBLE

text: 9 The natural inclination would be to avoid giving publicity to the incident lest the family name and family honour is brought into controversy 10 The parents of an unmarried girl as also the husband and members of the husband s family of a married woman would also more often than not want to avoid publicity on account of the fear of social stigma on the family name and family honour 11 The fear of the victim herself being considered to be promiscuous or in some way responsible for the incident regardless of her innocence 12 The reluctance to face interrogation by the investigating agency to face the court to face the cross examination by Counsel for the culprit and the risk of being disbelieved acts as a deterrent
label: PREAMBLE

text: In view of these factors the victims and their relatives are not too keen to bring the culprit to books
label: PREAMBLE

label: PREAMBLE

label: PREAMBLE

label: PREAMBLE

text: Just as a witness who has sustained an injury which is not shown or believed to be self inflicted is the best witness in the sense that he is least likely to exculpate the real offender the evidence of a victim of a sex offence is entitled to great weight absence of corroboration notwithstanding
label: PREAMBLE

text: And while corroboration in the form of eye witness account of an independent witness may often be forthcoming in physical assault cases such evidence cannot
label: PREAMBLE

text: be expected in sex offences having regard to the very nature of the offence
label: PREAMBLE

text: It would therefore be adding insult to injury to insist on corroboration drawing inspiration from the rules devised by the courts in the Western World
label: PREAMBLE

text: Therefore if the evidence of the victim does not suffer from any basic infirmity and the probabilities factor does not render it unworth of credence as a general rule there is no reason to insist on corroboration except from the medical evidence where having regard to the circumstances of the case medical evidence can be expected to be forthcoming subject to the following qualification Corroboration may be insisted upon when a woman having attained majority is surprised in a compromising position and there is a likelihood of her having levelled such an accusation on account of the instinct of self preservation

label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No 68 of 1977 Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and order dated 15th November 1976 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No 832 of 1976
label: NONE

text: R H Dhebar and B V Desai for the Appellant
label: NONE

text: R N Poddar for the Respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by THAKKAR J
label: NONE

text: To say at the beginning what we cannot help saying at the end human goodness has limits human depravity has none
label: NONE

text: The need of the hour however is not exasperation
label: NONE

text: The need of the hour is to mould and evolve the law so as to make it more sensitive and responsive to the demands of the time in order to resolve the basic problem Whether when and to what extent corroboration to the testimony of a victim of rape is essential to establish the charge
label: NONE

text: And the problem has special significance for the women in India for while they have often been idolized adored and even worshipped for ages they have also been exploited and denied even handed justice Sixty crores anxious eyes of Indian a women are therefore focussed on this problem
label: NONE

text: And to that problem we will presently address ourselves
label: NONE

text: The learned Sessions Judge Mehsana found the appellant a Government servant employed in the Sachivalaya at Gandhinagar guilty of serious charges of sexual misbenaviour with two young girls aged about 10 or 12 and convicted the appellant for the offence of rape outraging the modesty of women and wrongful confinement
label: RLC

text: The appeal carried to the High Court substantially failed
label: FAC

text: The High Court affirmed the order of conviction under Sec 342 of the Indian Penal Code for wrongfully confining the girls
label: RLC

text: The High Court also sustained the order of conviction under Sec 354 of the Indian Penal Code for outraging the modesty of the two girls
label: RLC

text: With regard to the more serious charge of rape on one of the girls the High Court came to the conclusion that what was established by evidence was an offence of attempt to commit rape and not of rape
label: RLC

text: Accordingly the conviction under Sec 376 was altered into one under Sec 376 read with Sec 511 of the Indian Penal Code
label: FAC

text: The appellant has preferred the present appeal with special leave
label: FAC

text: The incident occurred on Sunday September 7 1975 at about 5 30 p m at the house of the appellant
label: FAC

text: The evidence of P W 1 and P W 2 shows that they went to the house of the appellant in order to meet his daughter belonging to their own age group of 10 or 12 who happened to be their friend
label: FAC

text: The appellant induced them to enter his house by creating an impression that she was at home though in fact she was not
label: FAC

text: Once they were inside the appellant closed the door undressed himself in the presence of both the girls and exposed himself
label: FAC

text: He asked P W 2 to indulge in an indecent act
label: FAC

text: P W 2 started crying and fled from there
label: FAC

text: P W 1however could not escape
label: FAC

text: She was pushed into a cot and was made to undress
label: FAC

text: The appellant sexually assaulted her
label: FAC

text: P W 1 was in distress and was weeping as she went out
label: FAC

text: She however could not apprise her parents about what had transpired because both of them were out of Gandhinagar they returned after 4 or 5 days
label: FAC

text: It appears that the parents of P W 1 as well as parents of P W 2 wanted to hush up the matter
label: FAC

text: Some unexpected developments however forced the issue
label: FAC

text: The residents of the locality somehow came to know about the incident
label: FAC

text: And an alert Woman Social Worker P W 5 Kundanben President of the Mahila Mandal in Sector 17 Gandhinagar took up the cause
label: FAC

text: She felt indignant at the way in which the appellant had misbehaved with two girls of the age of his own daughter who also happened to be friends of his daughter taking advantage of their helplessness when no one else was present
label: FAC

text: Having ascertained from P W 1 and P W 2 as to what had transpired she felt that the appellant should atone for his infamous conduct
label: FAC

text: She therefore called on the appellant at his house
label: FAC

text: It appears that about 500 women of the locality had also gathered near the house of the appellant
label: FAC

text: Kundanben requested the appellant to apologize publicly in the presence of the woman who had assembled there
label: FAC

text: If the appellant had acceded to this request possibly the matter might have rested there and might not have come to the court
label: FAC

text: The appellant however made it a prestige issue and refused to apologize
label: FAC

text: Thereupon the police was contacted and a complaint was lodged by P W 1 on 19 Sept 1975
label: FAC

text: P W 1 was then sent to the Medical officer for medical examination
label: FAC

text: The medical examination disclosed that there was evidence to show that an attempt to commit rape on her had been made a few days back
label: FAC

text: The Sessions Court as well as the High Court have accepted the evidence and concluded that the appellant was guilty of sexual misbehavior with P W 1 and P W 2 in the manner alleged by the prosecution and established by the evidence of P W 1 and P W 2
label: FAC

text: Their evidence has been considered to be worthy of acceptance lt is a pure finding of fact recorded by the Sessions Court and affirmed by the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: Such a concurrent finding of fact cannot be reopened in an appeal by special leave unless it is established 1 that the finding is based on no evidence or 2 that the finding is perverse it being such as no reasonable person could have arrived at even if the evidence was taken at its face value or 3 the finding is based and built on inadmissible evidence which evidence if excluded from vision would negate the prosecution case or substantially discreditor impair it or 43 some vital piece of evidence which would tilt the balance in favour of the convict has been overlooked disregarded or wrongly discarded
label: ANALYSIS

text: The present is not a case of such a nature
label: ANALYSIS

text: The finding of guilt recorded by the Sessions Court as affirmed by the High Court has been challenged mainly on the basis of minor discrepancies in the evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: We do not consider it appropriate or permissible to enter upon a reappraisal or reappreciation of the evidence in the context of the minor discrepancies painstakingly highlighted by learned counsel for the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: Over much importance cannot be attached to minor discrepancies
label: ANALYSIS

text: The reasons are obvious 1 By and large a witness cannot be expected to possess a photographic memory and to recall the details of an incident
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not as if a video tape is replayed on the mental screen
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 ordinarily it so happens that a witness is overtaken by events
label: ANALYSIS

text: The witness could not have anticipated the occurrence which so often has an element of surprise
label: ANALYSIS

text: The mental faculties therefore cannot be expected to be attuned to absorb the details
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3 The powers of observation differ from person to person
label: ANALYSIS

text: What one may notice another may not
label: ANALYSIS

text: An object or movement might emboss its image on one person s mind whereas it might go unnoticed on the part of another
label: ANALYSIS

text: 4 By and large people cannot accurately recall a conversation and reproduce the very words used by them or heard by them
label: ANALYSIS

text: They can only recall the main purport of the conversation
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is unrealistic to expect a witness to be a human tape recorder
label: ANALYSIS

text: 5 In regard to exact time of an incident or the time duration of an occurrence usually people make their estimates by guess work on the spur of the moment 1 1 at the time of interrogation
label: ANALYSIS

text: And one cannot expect people to make very precise or reliable estimates in such matters
label: ANALYSIS

text: Again it depends on the time sense of individuals which varies from person to person
label: ANALYSIS

text: 6 Ordinarily a witness cannot be expected to recall accurately the sequence of events which take place in rapid succession or in a short time span
label: ANALYSIS

text: A witness is liable to get confused or mixed up when interrogated later on
label: ANALYSIS

text: 7 A witness though wholly truthful is liable to be overawed by the court atmosphere and the piercing cross examination made by counsel and out of nervousness mix up facts get confused regarding sequence of events or fill up details from imagination on the spur of the moment
label: ANALYSIS

text: The sub conscious mind of the witness sometimes so operates on account of the fear of looking foolish or being disbelieved though the witness is giving a truthful and honest account of the occurrence witnessed by him Perhaps it is a sort of a psychological defence mechanism activated on the spur of the moment
label: ANALYSIS

text: Discrepancies which do not go to the root of the matter and shake the basic version of the witnesses therefore cannot be annexed with undue importance
label: ANALYSIS

text: More so when the all important probabilities factor echoes in favour of the version narrated by the witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is now time to tackle the pivotal issue as regards the need for insisting on corroboration to the testimony of the prosecutrix in sex offences
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Court in Rameshwar v The State of Rajasthan 1 has declared that corroboration is not the sine que non for a conviction in a rape case
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The utterance of the Court in Rameshwar may be replayed across the time gap of three decades which have whistled past in the inimitable voice of Vivian Bose J who spoke for the Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: The rule which according to the cases has hardened into one of law is not that corroboration is essential before there can be a conviction but that the necessity of corroboration as a matter of prudence except where the circumstances make it safe to dispense with it must be present to the mind of the judge
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The only rule of law is that this rule of prudence must be present to the mind of the Judge or the jury as the case may be and be understood and appreciated by him or them
label: PRE_RELIED

text: There is no rule of practice that there must in every case be corroboration before a conviction can be allowed to stand
label: PRE_RELIED

text: And whilst the sands were running out in the time glass the crime graph of offences against women in India has been scaling new peaks from day to day
label: ANALYSIS

text: That is why an elaborate rescanning of the jurisprudential sky through the lenses of logos and ethos has been necessitated
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the Indian setting refusal to act on the testimony of a victim of sexual assault in the absence of corroboration as a rule is adding insult to injury
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why should the evidence of the girl or the woman who complains of rape or sexual molestation be viewed with the aid of spectacles fitted with lenses tinged with doubt disbelief or suspicion
label: ANALYSIS

text: To do so is to justify the charge of male chauvinism in a male dominated society
label: ANALYSIS

text: We must analyze the argument in support of the need for corroboration and subject it to relentless and remorseless cross examination
label: ANALYSIS

text: And we must do so with a logical and not an opiniated eye in the light of probabilities with our feet firmly planted on the soil of India and with our eyes focussed on the Indian horizon
label: ANALYSIS

text: We must not be swept off the feet by the approach made in the Western World which has its own social mileu its own social mores its own permissive values and its own code of life
label: ANALYSIS

text: Corroboration may be considered essential to establish a sexual offence in the backdrop of the social ecology of the Western World
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is wholly unnecessary to import the said concept on a turn key basis and to transplate it on the Indian soil regardless of the altogether different atmosphere attitudes mores responses of the Indian Society and its profile
label: ANALYSIS

text: The identities of the two worlds are different
label: ANALYSIS

text: The solution of problems cannot therefore be identical
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is conceivable in the Western Society that a female may level false accusation as regards sexual molestation against a male for several reasons such as 1 The female may be a gold digger and may well have an economic motive to extract money by holding out the gun of prosecution or public exposure
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 She may be suffering from psychological neurosis and may seek an escape from the neurotic prison by phantasizing or imagining a situation where she is desired wanted and chased by males
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3 She may want to wreak vengence on the male for real or imaginary wrongs
label: ANALYSIS

text: She may have a grudge against a particular male or males in general and may have the design to square the account 4 She may have been induced to do so in consideration of economic rewards by a person interested in placing the accused in a compromising or embarassing position on account of personal or political vendatta 5 She may do so to gain notoriety or publicity or to appease her own ego or to satisfy her feeling of self importance in the context of her inferiority complex 6 She may do so on account of jealousy 7 She may do so to win sympathy of others 8 She may do so upon being repulsed
label: ANALYSIS

text: By and large these factors are not relevant to India and the Indian conditions
label: ANALYSIS

text: Without the fear of making too wide a statements or of overstating the case it can be said that rarely will a girl or a woman in India make false allegations of sexual assault on account of any such factor as has been just enlisted
label: ANALYSIS

text: The statement is generally true in the context of the urban as also rural Society
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also by and large true in the context of the sophisticated not so sophisticated and unsophisticated society
label: ANALYSIS

text: Only very rarely can one conceivably come across an exception or two and that too possibly from amongst the urban elites
label: ANALYSIS

text: Because 1 A girl or a woman in the tradition bound non permissive Society of India would be extremely reluctant even to admit that any incident which is likely to reflect on her chastity had ever occurred
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 She would be conscious of the danger of being ostracised by the Society or being looked down by the Society including by her own family members relatives friends and neighbours
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3 She would have to brave thewhole world
label: ANALYSIS

text: 4 She would face the risk of losing the love and respect of her own husband and near relatives and of her matrimonial home and happiness being shattered
label: ANALYSIS

text: S If she is unmarried she would apprehend that it would be difficult to secure an alliance with a suitable match from a respectable or an acceptable family
label: ANALYSIS

text: 6 It would almost inevitably and almost invariably result in mental torture and suffering to herself
label: ANALYSIS

text: 7 The fear of being taunted by others will always haunt her
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 She would feel extremely embarrassed in relating the incident to others being over powered by a feeling of shame on account of the upbringing in a tradition bound society where by and large sex is taboo
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 The natural inclination would be to avoid giving publicity to the incident lest the family name and family honour is brought into controversy
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 The parents of an unmarried girl as also the husband and members of the husband s family of a married woman would also more often than not want to avoid publicity on account of the fear of social stigma on the family name and family honour
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 The fear of the victim herself being considered to be promiscuous or in some way responsible for the incident regardless of her innocence
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 The reluctance to face interrogation by the investigating agency to face the court to face the cross examination by Counsel for the culprit and the risk of being disbelieved acts as a deterrent
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of these factors the victims and their relatives are not too keen to bring the culprit to books
label: ANALYSIS

text: And when in the face of these factors the crime is brought to light there is a built in assurance that the charge is genuine rather than fabricated
label: ANALYSIS

text: On principle the evidence of a victim of sexual assault stands on par with evidence of an injured witness
label: ANALYSIS

text: Just as a witness who has sustained an injury which is not shown or believed to be self inflicted is the best witness in the sense that he is least likely to exculpate the real offender the evidence of a victim of a sex offence is entitled to great weight absence of corroboration notwithstanding
label: ANALYSIS

text: And while corroboration in the form of eye witness account of an independent witness may often be forthcoming in physical assault cases such evidence cannot be expected in sex offences having regard to the very nature of the offence
label: ANALYSIS

text: It would therefore be adding insult to injury to insist on corroboration drawing inspiration from the rules devised by the courts in the Western World
label: ANALYSIS

text: Obseisance to which has perhaps become a habit presumably on account of the colonial hangover
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are therefore of the opinion that if the evidence of the victim does not suffer from any basic infirmity and the probabilities factors does not render it unworthy of credence as a generalrule there is no reason to insist on corroboration except from the medical evidence where having regard to the circumstances of the case medical evidence can be expected to be forthcoming subject to the following qualification Corroboration may be insisted upon when a woman having attained majority is found in a compromising position and there is a likelihood of her having levelled such an accusation on account of the instinct of self preservation
label: ANALYSIS

text: Or when
label: ANALYSIS

text: the probabilities factor is found to be out of tune
label: ANALYSIS

text: Now we return to the facts of the present case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Testing the evidence from this perspective the evidence of P W 1 and P W 2 inspires confidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only motive suggested by defence was that there was some history of past trade union rivalry between the father of P W 2 and the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: It must be realized that having regard to the prevailing mores of the Indian Society it is inconceivable that a girl of 10 or 12 would invent on her own a false story of sexual molestation
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even at the age of 10 or 12 a girl in India can be trusted to be aware of the fact that the reputation of the entire family would be jeopardised upon such a story being spread
label: ANALYSIS

text: She can be trusted to know that in the Indian Society her own future chances of getting married and settling down in a respectable or acceptable family would be greatly marred if any such story calling into question her chastity were to gain circulation in the Society
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also unthinkable that the parents would tutor their minor daughter to invent such a story in order to wreak vengence on someone
label: ANALYSIS

text: They would not do so for the simple reason that it would bring down their own social status in the Society apart from ruining the future prospects of their own child
label: ANALYSIS

text: They would also be expected to be conscious of The traumatic effect on the psychology of the child and the disastrous consequences likely to ensue when she grows up
label: ANALYSIS

text: She herself would prefer to suffer the injury and the harassment rather than to undergo the harrowing experience of lodging a complaint in regard to a charge reflecting on her own chastity
label: ANALYSIS

text: We therefore refuse to countenance the suggestion made by the defence that the appellant has been falsely roped in at the instance of the father of P W 2 who was supposed to have some enmity against the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is unthinkable that the parents of P W 2 would tutor her to invent a story of sexual misbehavior on the part of the appellant merely in order to implicate him on account of past trade union rivalry
label: ANALYSIS

text: The parents would have also realized the danger of traumatic effect on the psychology of their daughter
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact it would have been considered to be extremely distasteful tobroach the subject
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is unthinkable that the parents would go to the length of inventing a story of sexual assault on their own daughter and tutor her to narrate such a version which would bring down their own social status and spoil their reputation in Society
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ordinarily no parents would do so in Indian society as at present
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under the circumstances the defence version that the father of P W 2 had tutored her to concoct a false version in order to falsely implicate the appellant must be unceremoniously thrown overboard
label: ANALYSIS

text: Besides why should the parents of P W 1 mar the future prospects of their own daughter
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not alleged that P W 1 had any motive to falsely implicate the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: So also it is not even suggested why P W 1 should falsely implicate the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the stand point of probabilities it is not possible to countenance the suggestion that a false story has been concocted in order to falsely implicate the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: The medical evidence provided by P W 6 Dr Hemangini Desai fully supports the finding of the High Court that there was an attempt to commit rape on P W 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under the circumstances the conclusion reached by the High Court cannot be successfully assailed
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only question that now remains to be considered is as regards the sentence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant has behaved in a shockingly indecent manner
label: ANALYSIS

text: The magnitude of his offence cannot be overemphasized m the context of the fact that he misused his position as a father of a girl friend of P W 1 and P W 2 P W 1 and P W 2 were visiting his house unhesitatingly because of the fact that his daughter was their friend
label: ANALYSIS

text: To have misused this position and to have tricked them into entering the house and to have taken undue advantage of the situation by subjecting them to sexual harassment is a crime of which a serious view must be taken
label: ANALYSIS

text: But for the following facts and circumstances we would not have countenanced the prayer for leniency addressed to us on behalf of the appellant
label: RATIO

text: The special circumstances are these
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant has lost his job in view of the conviction recorded by the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: The incident occurred some 7 years back
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appeal preferred to the High Court was dismissed in November 15 1976
label: ANALYSIS

text: About 6 1 2 years have elapsed thereafter
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the view that we are taking the appellant will have to be sent back to jail after an interval of about 6 1 2 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant must have suffered great humiliation in the Society
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prospects of getting a suitable match for his own daughter have perhaps been marred in view of the stigma in the wake of the finding of guilt recorded against him in the context of such an offence
label: ANALYSIS

text: Taking into account the cumulative effect of these circumstances and an overall view of the matter we are of the opinion that the ends of Justice will be satisfied if the substantive sentence imposed by the High Court for the offence under Sec 376 read with Sec 511 is reduced from one of 2 1 2 years R I to one of 15 months R I
label: RPC

text: The sentence of fine and in default of fine will be course remain undisturbed
label: RPC

text: So also the sentence imposed in the context of the offence under Sec 342 and Sec 354 of the Indian Penal Code will remain intact
label: RPC

text: Subject to the modification in the sentence to the aforesaid extent the appeal fails and is dismissed
label: RPC

text: The appellant shall surrender in order to undergo the sentence
label: RPC

text: The bail bonds will stand cancelled
label: RPC

text: S R Appeal dismissed
label: RPC

text: IN THE COURT OF THE SUB DIVISIONAL JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE
label: PREAMBLE

text: SUNDARGARH
label: PREAMBLE

text: PRESENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: DISTRICT
label: PREAMBLE

text: SUNDARGARH
label: PREAMBLE

text: Shri Hara Prasad Padhy LL B S D J M Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 a CC CASE No 249 of 2011
label: PREAMBLE

text: Trial No 120 of 2012 Date of argument 25 08 2016
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of Judgment 08 09 2016 State of Odisha
label: PREAMBLE

text: Prosecution
label: PREAMBLE

text: vrs 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: Kalabati Sa aged about 30 years
label: PREAMBLE

text: Wife of Kamaru Sa Resident of Village Subdega Bakupada PS Talsara District
label: PREAMBLE

text: Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: Accused person
label: PREAMBLE

text: Offence U s 47 a i Bihar Orissa Excise Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: Counsel for the State Sri Debasish Shit APP
label: PREAMBLE

text: Counsel for the Defence Sri N K Patel associates Advocate
label: PREAMBLE

text: J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: 1 Accused person stands charged for the offence U s 47 a i of Bihar Orissa Excise Act for illegal possession of I D Liquor
label: FAC

text: 2 The story of the prosecution in brief is that on 07 12 2011 at about 10 50 a m while the SI of Excise EI EB Unit Sambalpur was performing patrolling duty along with staff at Subdega Bakupada village area noticed that the accused Kalabati Sa was going on the road by carrying one plastic jerry cane in her hand
label: FAC

text: On suspicion the SI of Excise detained her on the road and directed the lady constable for search and on search she recovered five litres of ID liquor containing in the said plastic jerry cane from the possession of the accused in presence of the witnesses
label: FAC

text: Thereafter he conducted blue litmus test smell test hydrometer test and from above tests and his prolonged service experience he ascertained that the seized article was I D liquor
label: FAC

text: Thereafter he collected sample sent the same for chemical examination and after completion of his inquiry submitted final PR against the accused person U s 47 a i of Bihar Orissa Excise Act suggesting his trial
label: FAC

text: The plea of the accused person is one of complete denial and false implication only for statistical purpose
label: FAC

text: The points for determination of this case are as follows i
label: ISSUE

text: Whether on 07 12 2011 at about 9 45 a m on the road of village Subdega Bakupada the SI of Excise seized five litres of ID liquor kept in a plastic jerry cane for the purpose of selling without any authority
label: ISSUE

text: ii Whether on the same date time and place the said five litres of ID liquor has been seized from your exclusive and conscious possession
label: ISSUE

text: iii Whether the seized article is I D liquor or not
label: ISSUE

text: 5 To prove its case prosecution has examined only three witnesses
label: NONE

text: Out of whom P W 3 is the SI of Excise EI EB Sambalpur and P W 1 is the accompanying Excise constable
label: NONE

text: Pw 2 is the cited independent seizure witness to the alleged occurrence
label: NONE

text: Prosecution proved certain documents marked as Ext 1 Ext 2
label: NONE

text: On the other hand no oral or documentary evidence adduced on behalf of accused person in his defence
label: ANALYSIS

text: 6 On analysis of the evidence on record P W 3 the SI of Excise deposed that on 07 12 2011 while he was performing patrolling duty at Subdega Bakupada area and found that the accused was coming on the road by holding a plastic jerry cane in her hand so on suspicion he detained the accused Kalabati Sa and directed the lady constable for search and on search she recovered five litres of ID liquor containing in the plastic jerry cane from the possession of the accused
label: FAC

text: According to this witness he had conducted blue litmus paper test which turned into red in colour conducted hydrometer test and thereafter prepared the seizure list
label: FAC

text: He further deposed that he collected the sample and sent the same for chemical examination
label: FAC

text: Another official witness PW 1 Excise constable like wise supported the version of P W 3 in respect of patrolling and seizure of the liquor from the possession of the accused
label: FAC

text: Specific version of both the witnesses is that seizure was conducted by the SI of Excise in presence of the witnesses
label: FAC

text: Hence it is necessary to testify the testimony of the official witnesses from independent source for the sake of corroboration
label: FAC

text: P W 2 the independent seizure witness in evidence did not support the version of P W 3 at all in respect of factum of seizure
label: FAC

text: According to him nothing was seized in his presence by any Excise staff and he has put his thumb impression on a paper
label: FAC

text: Hence there is discrepancy between the testimony of independent seizure witness and the official witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: 7 To prove an offence U s 47 a i of Bihar Orissa Excise Act it is the bounden duty of prosecution to establish that the seizure was from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: But in this case the seizure witness did not support the factum of seizure at all
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further the SI of Excise PW 3 in cross examination admitted that he had not known the accused prior to the incident
label: ANALYSIS

text: The spot is a village road and busy one
label: ANALYSIS

text: He further deposed that he has not produced the seized articles before the court
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though the independent corroboration is not the rule but as the place of seizure is a public place examination of independent witness is necessary to make the judgment free from any criticism
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plea of the defence is that a false case has been foisted against her only for statistical purpose
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: There is no material on record to show the exact place of seizure as no sketch map is prepared or proved by the prosecution in this case to establish that the seizure was from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: More so the SI of Excise neither produced the seized liquor before the court nor sent the same for chemical examination
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Further independent seizure witness did not support the factum of seizure
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In such premises I hold that the prosecution failed to prove the factum of seizure from the possession of the accused for want of independent corroboration
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the prosecution failed to establish the seizure from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 With regard to nature of seized article whether it is liquor or not
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 3 stated that the seized article is I D liquor
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW 3 has filed the xerox copy of distillery training certificate so also xerox copy of experience certificate
label: ANALYSIS

text: But the learned defence counsel vehemently argued that the SI of Excise has not produced his original certificate
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further this witness has admittedly stated in cross examination that he has not produced the seized articles before the court
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has also not seized any document regarding identity of the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has also not proved the chemical examination report and has also not cited the Scientific officer as a witness in this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence I hold that prosecution failed to establish that the seized article is I D Liquor
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 In view of the whole discussions in foregoing paragraphs since the prosecution failed to establish that the seizure is from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused I hold that prosecution failed to establish the charge leveled against the accused person for commission of offence U s 47 a i of Bihar Orissa Excise Act beyond all reasonable doubt
label: RATIO

text: Hence I acquit her therefrom under the provisions of Sec 248 1 Cr P C
label: RPC

text: She be set at liberty and discharged from her bail bond
label: RPC

text: Enter the case as mistake of fact
label: RPC

text: The seized liquor kept at Excise Malkhana be destroyed after four months expiry of appeal period if no appeal is preferred and in case of appeal subject to the orders of the appellate court
label: RPC

text: S D J M Sundargarh 08 09 2016
