text: At present Shri Arup Nayak M A LL B J M F C Sundargarh GR Case No 212 of 2012 T R No 568 of 15 Dated this 24th Day of February 2016 State Prosecution Versus Jogeswar Sai Paikara aged about 30 years S o Late Mangulusai Paikara Vill Veluan Fatebahal P S Tumla Dist Jaspur Chhatisgarh Accused Date of Argument 18 02 2016 Date of Judgment 24 02 2016
label: PREAMBLE

text: For the Prosecution Mrs Tanuja Mohanty APP Sundargarh For the Defence Shri S K Purohit and associates Sundargarh Offences
label: PREAMBLE

text: U s 394 of The Indian Penal Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: 1 The above named accused stands prosecuted U s 394 of The Indian Penal Code herein after referred to as the IPC for the purpose of brevity only
label: FAC

text: 2 The brief facts of the prosecution is that On 22 03 2012 at about 4 45 PM the complainant Sukumar Panda lodged a written report to the effect that on that day at about 4 00 PM his driver namely Saroj Kumar Kaudi was proceeded towards Kinjirkela by taking his Bolero bearing Registration No OR 16C 3387
label: FAC

text: On the way in a lonely place near Khaparilate village three unknown persons suddenly came in front of the vehicle as a result of which the driver stopped the vehicle at the spot
label: FAC

text: The unknown persons assaulted the driver by keeping him on the point of gun and fled away with the said Bolero
label: FAC

text: Basing on the said report the OIC Kinjirkela PS registered PS Case No 13 dated 22 03 2012 U s 394 IPC read with Section 25 27 Arms Act and took up investigation of the case
label: FAC

text: During the course of investigation the IO visited the spot examined the complainant and other witnesses seized the stolen vehicle from ASI Kutwa OP seized the R C book Insurance policy of the said vehicle DL of the driver on production and also left the same along with the vehicle in zima by executing zimanama
label: FAC

text: After completion of investigation submitted charge sheet vide No 08 dated 15 02 2013 U s 394 IPC against the accused persons namely Jogeswar Sai Paikara Deonath Sai Paikara and Ramsingh Sidkar
label: FAC

text: 3 As the accused Ramsingh Sidkar and Deonath Sai Paikara are absconded and their presence could not procured by the court
label: FAC

text: Hence this case has been split up against the accused Jogeswar Sai Paikra to face his trial in the court of law
label: FAC

text: 4 The plea of defense is one of complete denial and of false implication
label: FAC

text: 5 In the present case the following points need to be determined Whether on 22 03 2012 at about 4 00 PM near Khaparilate village Dist Sundargarh the accused Jogeswar Sai Paikra along with Deonath Sai Paikara and Ramsingh Sidkar I committed robbery of a Bolero bearing Registration No OR 16C 3387 from the possession of its driver II Voluntarily caused hurt to the driver of the above said Bolero for committing robbery and thereby committed an offence punishable u s 394 IPC
label: ISSUE

text: 6 During course of trial the prosecution site examined 9 witnesses to substantiate it s case
label: FAC

text: P W 1 is the complainant of the case P W 2 Ranjan Kumar Patel is a chance witness P W 3 Saroj Kumar Kaudi is the driver of the vehicle P Ws 4 5 6 7 and 8 are the seizure witnesses
label: FAC

text: P W 9 is the IO of this case
label: FAC

text: On the other hand no evidence has been adduced by the accused on his behalf
label: FAC

text: 7 P W 1 the informant identified the accused and deposed that on 22 03 2012 in between 4 00 PM to 4 30 PM his driver had gone to Kinjirkela by taking his Bolero
label: FAC

text: On the way near Athtesha jungle some people stopped him and when the driver stopped the vehicle those persons assaulted his driver and fled away by taking the vehicle
label: FAC

text: The driver informed him through telephone about the occurrence and after that he went to the spot along with the driver and searched the vehicle
label: FAC

text: On the same day at about 10 00PM P W 1 got information that his vehicle was seized by the Kotwa OP after that he went to the Kotwa OP and acknowledged his vehicle and brought it back
label: FAC

text: P W 1 lodged an F I R regarding this matter marked vide Ext 1 and also identified his signature on it marked vide Ext 1 1 P W 2 Ranjan Kumar
label: FAC

text: Patel the chance witness identified the accused and stated that he is a school teacher and on 22 03 2012 at about 4 00 PM he was returning from his school by his motor cycle
label: FAC

text: On the way near Khapurilata village he found one white color Bolero was standing on the road two persons were inside the Bolero and the back seated person in the Bolero trying to press the neck of the other person seated in the driver seat by means of a towel
label: FAC

text: There were other two persons urinating by the side of the Bolero
label: FAC

text: By watching him the person seated on the driver seat shouted for help for which P W 2 stopped his motor cycle there
label: FAC

text: Thereby one of the persons urinating outside the Bolero rushed towards him by saying App Yahan Se Jaiye nehito hum apko mar denge
label: FAC

text: Out of fear P W 2 started his vehicle to go but in the mean time he heard the voice of the person seated in the driver seat for help and found that person running towards him
label: FAC

text: He stopped his vehicle and gave him lift upto Kanakjore village
label: FAC

text: On being asked by P W 2 that person said that those persons hired the vehicle from Sundargarh but on the way assaulted him and took away his vehicle
label: FAC

text: In presence of P W 2 that person also contacted to the owner of the vehicle intimating about the occurrence
label: FAC

text: P W 3
label: FAC

text: Saroj Kumar Kaudi the driver of the vehicle identified the accused and deposed that on 22 03 2012 at about 3 00 PM one person hired his vehicle to Gudiadihi then they picked up another two persons near the Hospital Sundargarh and carrying all total three persons P W 3 proceeded towards Gudiadihi from Sundargarh
label: FAC

text: On the way near the village Khaparilata those persons asked him to stop the vehicle for urinal
label: FAC

text: When he stopped the vehicle two persons went outside the vehicle
label: FAC

text: The accused had seated at his back seat and asked him to drive his vehicle when the same was objected by P W 3 the accused started to assault him by means of fist blows
label: FAC

text: After that the other two persons who went outside came near to him and tried to pull him out of the vehicle
label: FAC

text: P W 3 further stated that at that very moment a school teacher came to that spot but the accused persons also threatened him so he left the spot
label: FAC

text: After some time P W 3 by making himself free from those persons came out from that place with the help of that school teacher in his vehicle
label: FAC

text: Thereafter he intimated the owner of the vehicle about the occurrence
label: FAC

text: P W 3 further stated that on the very day Chhatisgarh police called to the owner of the vehicle and informed about the arrest of the accused persons and seizure of the vehicle
label: FAC

text: After that they went to that P S and recognized the accused persons
label: FAC

text: P W 3 further deposed that he took the vehicle and the relevant documents by executing the zimanama marked vide Ext 2 and identified his signature on it marked vide Ext 2 1
label: FAC

text: P W 4 Naiman Soren the seizure witness stated that on 22 03 2012 he had been to Kotwa OP alongwith A S I Kinjirkela
label: FAC

text: At Kotwa OP A S I seized the seizure list regarding that vehicle and also seized one F I R copy in his presence at Kotwa PS
label: FAC

text: Ext 3 is the said seizure list and he identified his signature on it marked vide Ext 3 1 P W 5 Luis Valrian Kiro the seizure witness deposed that on 29 11 2012 OIC Bhagabat Naik seized the F I R No 3 of 2012 of Tumula P S and the property seizure memo of the Bolero Vehicle in his presence
label: FAC

text: Ext 4 is the said seizure list and he identified his signature on it marked vide Ext 4 1 P W 6 Parikhit Majhi the seizure witness deposed that on 23 03 2012 OIC Bhagabat Naik seized one F I R copy and one property seizure memo of the Bolero in his presence of Kotwa PS
label: FAC

text: He identified his signature on the seizure list Ext 3 marked vide Ext 3 1
label: FAC

text: P W 6 further deposed that on 25 03 2012 OIC Bhagabat Naik seized the vehicle documents Driving License R C book and Insurance papers of the Bolero in his presence
label: FAC

text: Ext 5 is the said seizure list and he identified his signature on it marked vide Ext 5 1
label: FAC

text: P W 7 Pankaj Kumar Mohanta the seizure witness deposed that on 25 03 2012 the OIC Bhagabat Naik seized the RC book of the Bolero bearing Registration NO OR 16C 3387 the DL of the driver and Insurance certificate of the vehicle in his presence
label: FAC

text: He identified his signature on the seizure list Ext 5 marked vide Ext 5 1 P W 8 Nabin Chadnra Minz the seizure witness deposed that on 29 11 2012 the OIC Bhagabat Naik seized some documents and prepared the seizure list in his presence but due to passage of time he could not recollect the documents which were seized
label: FAC

text: He identified his signature on the seizure list Ext 4 marked vide Ext 4 2 P W 9 Bhagabat Naik the IO of the case deposed that on the day of occurrence he got information from Hari Sankar Singh the ASI of Kutwa OP about the recovery of the stolen Bolero bearing Registration No OR 16C 3387 and arrest of two accused persons namely Ramsing Sidkara and Deonath Sai Paikrai
label: FAC

text: On 23 03 2012 the I O examined the ASI Kotwa P S and seized one FIR copy and xerox copy of the property seizure memo of the said vehicle and prepared the seizure list marked vide Ext 3 and identified his signature vide Ext 3 3
label: FAC

text: On 25 03 2012 the IO seized RC book Insurance policy of the vehicle DL of Saroj Kumar Kaudi the driver of the vehicle on production and prepared the seizure list marked vide Ext 5 and identified his signature vide Ext 5 3
label: FAC

text: On 29 11 2012 he received information about the arrest of the accused Jogeswar Sai paikrai in another case under Tumula PS
label: FAC

text: The IO seized FIR copy of Tumula PS Case No 03 2012 arrest memo copy of property memo and prepared the seizure list Ext 4 and identified his signature on it marked vide Ext 4 3
label: FAC

text: In the instant case at hand the accused is implicated for the offense U s 394 of I P C
label: ANALYSIS

text: In order to attract the offence U s 394 there must be robbery either committed or attempted and for that purpose the accused must have voluntarily caused hurt
label: ANALYSIS

text: By taking into consideration the materials available on record and as per the allegations of prosecution the offense of Robbery has been committed in broad day light in the form of Extortion
label: ANALYSIS

text: The allegation of the prosecution is that on 22 03 2012 in between 4 00 PM to 4 30 PM the accused along with his two other companion committed robbery of one Bolero by assaulting the driver of the complainant
label: ANALYSIS

text: So this allegation attracts the offense U s 394 of I P C 9
label: ANALYSIS

text: In a whole coming to the discussion P W 1 the owner of the vehicle is the complainant of this case and lodged the F I R at Kinjirikela P S at 4 45 Pm
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 1 stated that he got telephonic information from his driver about the occurrence and after that he went to the Kinjirikela PS and lodged FIR
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 3 the driver of the vehicle stated that he had been assaulted by the accused persons and after that they fled away by taking his Bolero near village khaparilata
label: ANALYSIS

text: He took the help of a school teacher from the spot and after that he gave telephonic information to the owner of the vehicle in presence of that person
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 2 the school teacher deposed that when he was returning from his school at about 4 00 PM he found the driver P W 3 was assaulted by the accused persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 2 gave lift to the driver of the Bolero from that spot and left him at Kanakajore village
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 3 further deposed that the driver informed the owner telephonically in his presence about the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 9 the I O stated that on the day of occurrence during investigation he got telephonic information from the A S I Kotwa OP that the said vehicle has been seized two of the accused persons namely Ramsingh Sidkar and Deonath Sai Paikara were arrested and other accused namely Jogeswar Sai Paikara has been absconded
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the next day I e on 23 03 2012 the I O seized the said vehicle from the A S I Kotwa OP in presence of P W 4 and P W 6 the seizure witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 4 and P W 6 also proved the said seizure by saying that the seizure has been made in their presence by the I O The I O left the vehicle in zima of the driver P W 2 by verifying the relevant documents and by execution of zimanama marked vide Ext 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the above discussion now it can be safely conclude that the Bolero has been robbed near village Khaparilata from the possession of it s driver and recovered at Kotwa P S from the possession of the accused persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 From the allegations and evidences deposed by the prosecution witnesses it comes to light that the driver of the Bolero has been assaulted by the accused persons in a lonely place on the road near village khaparilata which has not been seen by any one except a chance witness who is a school teacher and was returning from his school by that way and time
label: ANALYSIS

text: Here the offense of Robbery has been committed in the form of extortion which ultimately implies the possessor of the property has the knowledge of the incident and he left the property in fear of injury
label: ANALYSIS

text: So it can be safely presume that the driver and the school teacher are the sole eye witnesses in this case to bring the accused into the clutches of law
label: ANALYSIS

text: Now the question is whether this is the said accused who has committed the offense of robbery in the form of Extortion with the help of other two co accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 During the course of argument the Ld defense counsel raised his contentions regarding the time of occurrence and filing of F I R at Kinjirikela P S by the informant who was at Sundargarh at the time of occurrence
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Kinjirikela P S is about 30 Kms distance from Sundargarh which is highly improbable
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The Ld Defense counsel put forth another contention regarding conduct of T I Parade and to strengthen his contention the Ld Defense counsel placed reliance on the decision laid down in AIR 1998 SUPREME COURT 1922 Shaikh Umar Ahmed Shaikh and another Vrs State of Maharastra and AIR 1982 SUPREME COURT 839 Mohanlal Gangaram Gehani Vrs State of Maharastra
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In the case of Shaikh Umar Ahmed Shaikh there was an attack by a mob causing death of a constable and there was requirement of T I parade of 5 to 6 persons out of a mob
label: ANALYSIS

text: So far as the case of Mohanlal Gangaram Gehani is concerned there was presence of dying declaration and the recorder of the dying declaration made contradictory statement and T I parade has not been conducted
label: ANALYSIS

text: So far as both the cases are concerned the facts and circumstances of both the cases are different in relation to the present case at hand
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dealing with the other contention the court is of the view that when occurrence has been sufficiently proved the time regarding the commission of offense and filing of FIR in the present facts and circumstance is immaterial
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 Now coming to the point for discussion about the involvement of the accused in the present case
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this case prosecution has not examined the A S I of Kotwa P S who has seized the vehicle from the possession of the Co accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: Test Identification parade has not been conducted by the I O
label: ANALYSIS

text: In absence of such evidences available evidences may be taken into consideration for conclusion
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 9 the I O stated that he got information from the A S I Kotwa PS that two accused persons Ramsingh Sidkar and Deonath Sai Paikara were arrested from the involved vehicle and one accused namely Jogeswar Sai Paikara has absconded
label: ANALYSIS

text: On 29 11 2012 the I O got information about the arrest of Jogeswar Sai Paikara in Tumla P S case no 3 12 and taken him on remand on 18 12 2012
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 3 the driver of the vehicle clearly identified the accused and stated that the accused had been seated in his back seat
label: ANALYSIS

text: At the place of occurrence accused asked him to drive when he objected the accused assaulted him by means of fist blows
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 2 the chance witness during his examination identified the accused three times
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Para 1 he stated that I do not know the name of the accused standing in the dock but it seems as if I know him
label: ANALYSIS

text: In para 9 of his cross examination he stated that the accused standing in the dock was present on the spot on the day of occurrence but I can not say what he was doing there
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Para 16 of his cross examination he stated that this accused standing in the dock had threatened me in hindi language
label: ANALYSIS

text: The presence of accused on the spot of occurrence is affirmed by both P W 2 and P W 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: However the statement of P W 2 and P W 3 are contradictory about the overt act done by the accused at the place of occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: Both P W 2 and P W 3 deposed in a consistent manner corroborating their previous statements and nothing could have brought from their mouth during their cross examination which put questions on their credibility
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 3 is the victim of the case he spent a long time with the accused persons in comparison to P W 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 2 is a chance witness who has seen two persons inside the vehicle and two persons out side
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 2 left the spot immediately after threatening by one of the accused person
label: ANALYSIS

text: The fact cannot be ignored that in ordinary course a person tends to remember things more particularly which he himself had undergone in comparison to others
label: ANALYSIS

text: The occurrence took place on 22 03 2012 and P W 2 has examined on 16 07 2013
label: ANALYSIS

text: Human memory is subject to deterioration with passage of time
label: ANALYSIS

text: The presence of accused on the spot of occurrence is not disputed by both of the eye witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: So it can be safely conclude with the involvement of the accused in the alleged crime offense
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is an offense which comes under the purview of Joint liability
label: ANALYSIS

text: As per the principle of joint liability where one or more persons having similar intention to commit any crime commits any such crime then each of such persons is liable for that offense jointly and severally as if it was done by him alone
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mere presence of an accused at the scene of the occurrence having the intention to commit such crime offense is sufficient to draw inference against him
label: ANALYSIS

text: Overt act is not necessary
label: ANALYSIS

text: By taking into consideration of the evidences adduced by PW 2 and P W 3 the eye witnesses the involvement of the accused in the present case is sufficiently proved
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus this court is of the view that the prosecution has successfully established the guilt of accused U s 394 of IPC beyond all reasonable doubt
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14 On the basis of the above analysis this court is of the conclusion that the prosecution has successfully established the case against the accused U s 394 IPC beyond all reasonable doubt
label: RATIO

text: The accused is found guilty for offense U s 394 IPC and convicted thereof u s 248 2 Cr P C
label: RPC

text: Pronounced this judgment in the open court in the presence of accused today this 24th day of February 2016 under my signature and seal of the court
label: NONE

text: J M F C Sundargarh
label: NONE

text: Committing robbery in the form of extortion is a grievous offence in nature
label: RATIO

text: Hence having regard to the facts and allegations of the case this court is of the view that if such type of convicts are released under the beneficial provisions of Probation of offenders Act it would send a wrong message to the society
label: RATIO

text: Hence this court is not inclined to extend any of the beneficial provisions under Probation of offenders Act to the convicts
label: RATIO

text: J M F C Sundargarh HEARING ON THE QUESTION OF SENTENCE Heard the convict as well as Learned counsel for the convict and Learned APP for the state
label: NONE

text: The convict and the Learned Defence counsel submitted that being a first time offender lenient view should be taken while imposing sentence
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: On the other hand the counsel for the state submitted that the convict has committed grievous offense hence prayed for exemplary punishment
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Taking into consideration of the circumstances and manner of the commission of the offense the convict namely Jogeswar Sai Paikara sentenced to undergo Rigorous Imprisonment for three years and to pay fine of Rs 10 000 Ten thousand and in default he shall further undergo Simple Imprisonment for 06 six months
label: RPC

text: The period of detention undergone if any by the convict as U T P be set off U s 428 of Cr P C against the sentence of imprisonment
label: RPC

text: Pronounced this sentence in the open court in the presence of accused today this 24th day of February 2016 under my signature and seal of the court
label: NONE

text: J M F C Sundargarh Typed to my dictation and corrected by me JM F C Sundargarh
label: NONE

text: Supply free copy of this judgment to the convict
label: NONE

text: JMFC Sundargarh
label: NONE

text: Typed and corrected by me JMFC Sundargarh
label: NONE

text: Nabin Chandra Minz P W 9 Bhagabat Naik LIST OF DEFENCE WITNESSES NIL LIST OF EXHIBITS MARKED ON BEHALF OF PROSECUTION Ext 1 FIR Ext 1 1 Signature of P W 1 Ext 1 2 Signature of P W 9 Ext 1 3 Formal FIR Ext 1 4 Signature of P W 9 on Ext 1 3 Ext 2 Zimanama Ext 2 1 Signature of P W 3 on Ext 2 Ext 2 2 Signature of P W 9 on Ext 2 Ext 3 Seizure list Ext 3 1 Signature of P W 4 on Ext 3 Ext 3 2 Signature of P W 6 on Ext 3
label: NONE

text: Ext 3 3 Signature of P W 4 on Ext 3 Ext 4 Seizure list Ext 4 1 Signature of P W 5 Ext 4 2 Signature of P W 8 on Ext 4 Ext 5 Seizure list Ext 5 1 Signature of P W 6 Ext 5 2 Signature of P W 7 on Ext 5 Ext 5 3 Signature of P W 9 on Ext 5 Ext 6

text: Non Reportable
label: PREAMBLE

text: IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA
label: PREAMBLE

text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 18830 of 2017 Union of India Ors
label: PREAMBLE

text: Appellant s Versus Chandra Bhushan Yadav Respondent s W I T H
label: PREAMBLE

text: Civil Appeal No 7440 of 2018
label: PREAMBLE

text: J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: L NAGESWARA RAO J
label: NONE

text: 1 The District Court Martial imposed a punishment of dismissal of the Respondent from service and reduction of the ranks apart from sentencing him to rigorous imprisonment for three months
label: FAC

text: The Armed Forces Tribunal Regional Bench Lucknow for short the Tribunal set aside the order of the District Court Martial aggrieved by which the Union of India has filed this Appeal
label: RLC

text: The Respondent was enrolled in the Indian Air Force in the trade of Equipment Assistant on 18 01 1988
label: FAC

text: He was posted to 402 Air Force Station Kanpur in August 1997
label: FAC

text: The Respondent was assigned duty in Diesel and Petrol Store on 02 02 2000
label: FAC

text: Information was received from a civilian on 03 05 2000 that 7 barrels of diesel were unloaded in civil area at Pappu Ka Plot at about 1400 hrs on 02 05 2000
label: FAC

text: The informant informed 4 Provost Security Unit Air Force Kanpur that he saw two airmen in uniform out of which one was of dark complexion
label: FAC

text: The informant further stated that a similar incident of unloading of barrels was observed by him on 20 04 2000 also as well
label: FAC

text: 2 A detailed report was sent by 4 Provost Security Unit Air Force Kanpur by a letter dated 10 05 2000 in which it was indicated that the Respondent herein and Corporal G S Mani Equipment Assistant were involved in taking out POL Petrol Oil Lubricants belonging to Air Force Station Kanpur
label: FAC

text: Air Officer Commanding 402 Air Force Station Kanpur directed a Court of Inquiry to be convened
label: FAC

text: By its report dated 31 05 2000 the Court of Inquiry found that DHPP quantity of 5800 Ltrs and petrol of 5000 Ltrs was misappropriated by the Respondent and the then Corporal G S Mani Equipment Assistant
label: FAC

text: According to the report manipulation was done by raising gate passes for a quantity more than which was authorised by issuance of vouchers and obtaining the signature of Senior Logistic Officer on such gate passes
label: FAC

text: The said gate passes were used to take out kerosene diesel and petrol
label: FAC

text: A second set of vouchers were prepared for the purpose of issuing gate passes when items were taken out of guard room which were later destroyed after safe passage from the guard room
label: FAC

text: The misappropriated items were disposed in the civil area
label: FAC

text: On the basis of the said finding the Court of Inquiry recommended following actions a Initiate strict disciplinary action against Corporal C B Yadav Respondent and others involved in the said action b To make good the loss incurred due to such action and to recover the cost of quantity DHPP 400 Ltrs and quantity 200 Ltrs of petrol Rs 68 520 3
label: FAC

text: An Additional Court of Inquiry was ordered to further investigate into certain other aspects not covered by the Court of Inquiry
label: FAC

text: By the Report dated 12 07 2007 the Additional Court of Inquiry found that the Respondent had prepared the gate passes in advance on some occasions
label: FAC

text: The record of the Court of Inquiry and Additional Court of Inquiry proceedings were forwarded to the Head Quarters Maintenance Command on 26 07 2000
label: FAC

text: The Court of Inquiry proceedings were approved by the AOC in C Maintenance Command pursuant to which disciplinary action was initiated against the Respondent and others
label: FAC

text: A charge sheet was framed containing 14 charges and a hearing of charge under Rule 24 of the Air Force Rules 1969 for short the Rules was conducted before the Air Officer Commanding in Chief
label: FAC

text: The AOC in C ordered evidence to be recorded in writing
label: FAC

text: After considering the summary of evidence the AOC in C found that there was insufficient evidence to sustain Charges 1 to 5 and therefore those charges were dropped
label: FAC

text: A charge sheet containing fresh charges was issued
label: FAC

text: 4 On 27 08 2001 AOC in C Head Quarters Maintenance Command convened a District Court Martial for trial of the Respondent
label: FAC

text: The District Court Martial found the Respondent guilty and imposed a punishment of dismissal from service and reduction of the rank apart from sentencing the Respondent to rigorous imprisonment for three months
label: FAC

text: The order dated 25 10 2001 was set aside by the Tribunal
label: FAC

text: The Respondent was directed to have been in continuous service for the purpose of pension and other service benefits
label: FAC

text: However arrears of salary was confined to 50 per cent
label: FAC

text: 5 The Tribunal held that the allegation against the Respondent being theft and misappropriation of kerosene and diesel the loss caused due to theft required to be reported to the civil police as per Para 804 b of the Regulations
label: FAC

text: By referring to Section 154 of the Code of Criminal Procedure 1973 for short the Cr PC the Tribunal held that it is mandatory that a First Information Report FIR had to be registered in a cognizable case
label: FAC

text: The Tribunal observed that the Respondent was not given an opportunity in terms of Rule 156 of the Rules during the Court of Inquiry proceedings
label: FAC

text: In view of the violation of sub rule 2 6 and 7 of Rule 156 of the Air Force Rules the Tribunal was of the view that the proceedings of the Court of Inquiry were vitiated
label: FAC

text: The contention on behalf of the Respondent that there was violation of Rule 24 of the Rules and that the summary of evidence was also not recorded in accordance with the prescribed procedure was not accepted by the Tribunal
label: FAC

text: Group Captain A K
label: FAC

text: Gurtu Senior Personnel Staff Officer SPSO Head Quarters for Air Officer Commanding in Chief signed the order by which the District Court Martial was convened which according to the Tribunal was in violation of Section 111 of the Act and Rule 43 4 of the Rules
label: FAC

text: The Tribunal observed that only the AOC in C is competent to convene the District Court Martial
label: FAC

text: The Tribunal re appreciated the evidence and came to the conclusion that the charges against the Respondent were not proved beyond reasonable doubt
label: FAC

text: First Information Report FIR 6
label: FAC

text: Mr Vinay Kumar Garg learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of the Respondent submitted that Para 804 b of the Regulations imposes an obligation that a loss caused due to theft should be reported to the civil police
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: He supported the finding of the Tribunal that there is requirement of compulsory registration of FIR in view of the provisions of Section 154 Cr PC
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Mr R Balasubramanian learned Senior Counsel appearing for the Union of India submitted that Para 804 b of the Regulations is not mandatory
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It is open to the authorities to report a theft to the civil police if the situation warrants
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He submitted that the Air Force Act 1950 and Air Force Regulations 1964 govern the conduct and discipline of the Air Force
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Air Force Act 1950 is a special law in which detailed procedure for conducting of trial by a Court Martial has been prescribed and no requirement for registration of an FIR is mandatory under the Rules therein
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The conduct of trial including investigation is covered under Air Force Act and the Rules
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He referred to Section 5 of the Cr PC to submit that the Cr PC is not applicable to the personnel governed under the Air Force Act
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He relied upon the judgment of this Court in Ajmer Singh Ors v Union of India Ors 1 in support of his argument
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 7 In Ajmer Singh supra it was held as follows 7 Section 5 of the Code of Criminal Procedure lays down that nothing contained in the said Code shall in the absence of a specific provision to the contrary affect any special or local law for the time being in force or any special jurisdiction or power conferred or any special form of procedure prescribed by any other law for the time being in force
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The relevant Chapters of the Army Act the Navy Act and the Air Force Act embody a completely self contained comprehensive Code specifying the various offences under those Acts and 1 1987 3 SCC 340 prescribing the procedure for detention and custody of offenders investigation and trial of the offenders by court martial the punishments to be awarded for the various offences confirmation and revision of the sentences imposed by court martial the execution of such sentences and the grant of pardons remissions and suspensions in respect of such sentences
label: PRE_RELIED

text: These enactments therefore constitute a special law in force conferring special jurisdiction and powers on court martial and prescribing a special form of procedure for the trial of the offences under those Acts
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The effect of Section 5 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is to render the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure inapplicable in respect of all matters covered by such special law
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 8 It is clear from the above that the Air Force Act is a special law conferring jurisdiction and powers on the Court Martial and prescribing the procedure for trial of offences
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It is also clear that the Code of Criminal Procedure is not applicable in respect of matters covered by the Air Force Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence the finding recorded by the Tribunal that it is mandatory for the authorities to report the offences to civil police for registration of an FIR is unsustainable
label: FAC

text: The Tribunal further relied upon Para 804 b of the Regulations to hold that it is incumbent on the part of the authorities to report an offence to the civil police for registration of an FIR
label: FAC

text: Para 804 b is as follows 804 Loss of Air Force Equipment and Foodstuffs a b A loss which is supposed to be due to theft will be reported at once to the civil police when the circumstances warrant the course of action
label: FAC

text: In any court of inquiry which may subsequently be held evidence will be taken to show the date on which the loss was so reported
label: FAC

text: 9 There can be no doubt from a plain reading of the Regulations that the reporting of an offence of theft to the civil police is optional
label: FAC

text: Only when the circumstances warrant such reporting to the civil police the competent officer can do so
label: FAC

text: For the aforementioned reasons para 804 b of the Regulations of the Air Force Act cannot be said to be mandatory
label: FAC

text: Court of Inquiry 10
label: FAC

text: The contention of the Respondent which was accepted by the Tribunal relates to the violation of sub Rule 2 6 and 7 of Rule 156
label: FAC

text: It is necessary to reproduce sub Rule 2 6 and 7 of Rule 156 which are as under 156 Courts of inquiry other than those held under section 107 1 2 Save in the case of a prisoner of war who is still absent whenever any inquiry affects the character or service reputation of a person subject to the Act full opportunity must be afforded to such person of being present throughout the inquiry and of making any statements and of giving any evidence he may wish to make or give and of cross examining and witness whose evidence in his opinion affects his character or service reputation and producing any witnesses in defence of his character or service reputation 3 4 5 6 The proceedings of a court of inquiry or any confession or statement or answer to a question made or given at a court of inquiry shall not be admissible in evidence against a person subject to Air Force Law nor shall any evidence respecting the proceedings of the court be given against any such person except upon the trial of such person for wilfully giving false evidence before that court
label: FAC

text: 7 Any person subject to the Act whose character or service reputation is in the opinion of the Chief of the Air Staff affected by anything in the evidence before or in the report of a court of inquiry shall be entitled to a copy of the proceedings of such court unless the Chief of the Air Staff sees reason to order otherwise 11
label: FAC

text: The Tribunal was of the view that the Respondent was not given sufficient opportunity to defend himself during the course of the proceedings before the Court of Inquiry
label: FAC

text: 12 According to the Respondent he was not permitted to be present during the recording of statement of witnesses
label: FAC

text: He was also deprived of an opportunity to cross examine the witnesses
label: FAC

text: The contention on behalf of the Union of India is that the Respondent was given an opportunity to make a statement and to cross examine witnesses
label: FAC

text: He was also given a chance to produce documentary evidence
label: FAC

text: The Respondent made a statement on 19 07 2000 to the effect that he did not wish to cross examine witnesses and to produce any documentary evidence in his defence
label: FAC

text: 13 The statement made by the Respondent was produced before us which indicates that he did not utilize the opportunity given to him
label: FAC

text: Therefore it cannot be held that there is violation of Rule 156 of the Rules and the Tribunal committed an error in holding that the proceedings of Court of Inquiry are vitiated
label: FAC

text: Convening Order 14
label: FAC

text: The contention of the Respondent is that Group Captain A K Gurtu Senior Personnel Staff Officer SPSO Head Quarters MC IAF signed the order by which the District Court Martial was convened
label: FAC

text: It is urged that AOC in C is the competent authority to convene the Court Martial
label: FAC

text: The Union of India justified the order by which the District Court Martial was convened in accordance with the Air Force Rules
label: FAC

text: 15 Section 111 of the Air Force Act provides that District Court Martial may be convened by an officer having power to convene a General Court Martial or by an officer empowered by warrant of any such officer
label: FAC

text: Rule 43 deals with convening of General and District Court Martials
label: FAC

text: Rule 43 4 which is relevant for our purpose reads as under 43 Convening of general and district court martial
label: FAC

text: 4 After the convening officer has appointed or detailed the officer to form a Court Martial under sub rule 3 convening order of the Court Martial and endorsement on the charge sheet for trial of the accused by court martial may either be signed by convening officer or by a staff officer on his behalf
label: FAC

text: The charge sheet on which the accused to be tried the summary of evidence and the convening order for assembly of Court Martial
label: FAC

text: shall then be sent to the senior officer of Court Martial and the Judge Advocate if appointed
label: FAC

text: 16 In Union of India Ors v Ex Flt Lt G S Bajwa2 this Court examined the issue pertaining to the authority competent to convene the Court Martial and held as follows 44
label: PRE_RELIED

text: A ground was taken before the High Court Ground f that the convening of the General Court Martial was signed by an officer in whose name no delegation or such authority had ever been made
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In reply thereto the appellant had submitted that the convening order was signed by the said officer on behalf of the Air Officer In charge Personnel who had after due application of mind issued the order for convening the above Court Martial
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It was not disputed before us that the Air Officer In charge Personnel AOP was empowered to convene a Court Martial
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The only question which therefore requires consideration is 2 2003 9 SCC 630 whether the order convening the General Court Martial was passed by the AOP and it was only formally communicated under signatures of the Air Commodore concerned or whether the Air Commodore named therein who was not empowered himself passed the convening order
label: PRE_RELIED

text: With a view to avoid any controversy on this factual position we directed the appellant to produce before us the original file
label: PRE_RELIED

text: We have perused the file and we find that the order for convening the General Court Martial was approved by Air Marshal D A LaFontaine AOP
label: PRE_RELIED

text: There is therefore no force in the submission that the convening order was unauthorized and therefore illegal 17
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The order dated 18 08 2001 by which the District Court Martial was convened is issued in the name of Air Marshall S S Gupta PVSM AVSM VSM ADC Air Officer Commanding in Chief Maintenance Command
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no doubt that the order was signed by Group Captain A K Gurtu SPSO Head Quarters MC IAF who is the Personnel Staff Officer for Air Officer Commanding in Chief Maintenance Command IAF
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 43 4 provides that a convening order may be signed by the Commanding Officer or by the Senior Staff Officer on his behalf
label: ANALYSIS

text: The fact that Group Captain A K Gurtu was the Senior Personnel Staff officer for the AOC in C Maintenance Command IAF is not in dispute
label: ANALYSIS

text: A perusal of the Record reveals that the convening order had the approval of the competent authority and as such it cannot be termed as unauthorized
label: ANALYSIS

text: Another submission that was made by the learned Senior Counsel for the Respondent is that according to the Organizational Chart of Head Quarters MC IAF it is only Senior Air Administrative Staff Officer SAASO who can be the Staff Officer of the AOC in C
label: ANALYSIS

text: The said submission was countered by the learned Senior Counsel for the Union of India
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was contended that that Group Captain A K Gurtu was Senior Personnel Staff Officer SPSO and lesser than that of Senior Air Administrative Staff Officer SAASO in the hierarchy
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no requirement that only SAASO can be the Staff Officer to AoC in C
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even Officers lower than SAASO can be appointed as Staff Officers
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to Mr R Balasubramanian learned Senior Counsel it is evident from the order itself that Group Captain A K Gurtu who is Senior Personnel Staff Officer SPSO was the Staff Officer and competent to sign the convening order
label: ANALYSIS

text: 18 The convening order which was signed by the Staff Officer of the AOC in C is in accord with Rule 43 4 of the Rule and no fault can be found with the order
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Tribunal committed an error in holding that the convening order was by an officer who was not competent
label: ANALYSIS

text: Charges 5 6 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: The District Court Martial found the Respondent guilty of Charges 1 2 5 and 6
label: ANALYSIS

text: He was exonerated of Charges 3 and 4
label: ANALYSIS

text: The confirmation authority held that there was no sufficient evidence in relation to Charges 1 and 2 and they were dropped
label: ANALYSIS

text: What remains to be seen is whether Charges 5 6 are established
label: ANALYSIS

text: Charges 5 6 are as follows Fifth Charge Committing Criminal Breach of Trust Section 52 c in Respect of property belonging to Air Force Act the Govt In that he 1950 At 402 AF Station on 20 April 2000 being the NCO i c POL Stores of 402 Sixth charge AF Station and in that capacity Section 52 c entrusted with POL Stores of the unit Air Force Act dishonestly misappropriated 1400 1950 Ltrs of DHPP N by raising IAFF Q 429 No EX IV P 10 2000 2001 for 200 ltrs of Petrol 87 MT 800 ltrs of DHPP N but physically issuing 702670 K Cpl Mani GS Eqpt Asst of 7 AF Hospital 200 ltrs of Petrol 87 MT 2200 ltrs DHPP N and nil Kerosene oil quantity by writing quantity 200 ltrs of Petrol 87 MT 800 Ltrs of DHPP N and 1400 ltrs of kerosene Oil on gate pass No 3129 dated 29 April 2000 Committing criminal breach of trust in respect of property belonging to the Govt In that he At 402 AF Station on 02 May 2000 being the NCO i c POL stores of 402 AF Station and in that capacity entrusted with POL stores of the unit dishonestly misappropriated 1400 lrts of DHPP N by making use of two sets of IAFF Q 429 bearing same serial No EX IV P 16 2000 20010 for a single transaction of issue of POL to 7 AF Hospital first set receipted blue showing issue of 2400 ltrs of Kerosene oil only and second set original black showing issue of 2400 ltrs of kerosene oil and 1400 ltrs of DHPP N and physically issuing to 702670 K Cpl Mani GS Eqpt Asst of 7 AF Hospital as per second set and gate pass No 3131 dated 02 May 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Tribunal on a reconsideration of the evidence on record concluded that Charges 5 and 6 were not established beyond reasonable doubt
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW1 Corporal M K Sharma failed to identify the signatures appended on the vouchers
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW2 Sergeant L Singh who was the Record Keeper in Security Section deposed that he was not aware as to who was responsible for the issuance of kerosene oil
label: ANALYSIS

text: W O S K Singh who was examined as PW3 does not remember the dates and data with regard to deficiencies of POL
label: ANALYSIS

text: He stated that no deficiency was found in POL during the weekly snap checks from February May 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: He further stated that the Respondent was not related to issuance of kerosene oil during the months of February May 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: Wing Commander J K Chakraborty who appeared as PW4 admitted that there was no deficiency of diesel at the time of handing and taking over of duty by the Respondent
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW5 Flight Lieutenant Arvind Kumar had no personal knowledge of the evidence as he was on leave
label: ANALYSIS

text: However he stated that there was no surplus or deficiency of POL
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW6 Corporal G S Mani admitted to unloading seven empty barrels at Pardevanpurwa on 20 04 2000 at the request of the Respondent
label: ANALYSIS

text: He further stated that an amount of Rs 1 500 was forcibly given by the Respondent
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also stated that he carried 20 barrels for collecting 2400 liters of kerosene oil and again collected seven barrels on 02 05 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: During cross examination he was confronted with his previous statement wherein he stated that he was coerced to make a statement against the Respondent
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of the contradictions made by PW6 who is the co accused the Tribunal held that he is not a reliable witness
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW7 Corporal S Singh categorically stated that the loading of barrels containing POL was at the behest of Corporal G S Mani
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW8 Hasan R Lascar who was working in the Medical Ward stated that he loaded empty barrels on the instructions of Corporal G S Mani
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW9 Rajendra Prasad Lascar also stated that loading and off loading of diesel at Pardevanpurwa was in the presence of Corporal G S Mani
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21 We have examined the evidence to satisfy ourselves as to whether there is any iota of evidence against the Respondent
label: RATIO

text: It appears from the evidence that Corporal G S Mani was actively involved in the transportation of diesel barrels and loading and off loading in the civil area
label: RATIO

text: Curiously no action was taken against Corporal G S Mani
label: RATIO

text: There is no evidence on record to connect the Respondent to the offence of illegal transportation of POL
label: RATIO

text: Though we are not in agreement with the Tribunal on the other issues in view of lack of any evidence against the Respondent we are inclined to uphold the judgment of the Tribunal
label: RATIO

text: The Appeal is dismissed
label: RPC

text: Civil Appeal No 7440 of 2018 22
label: RPC

text: This appeal has been filed by the Respondent aggrieved by the directions of the Tribunal that the Appellant shall pay only 50 per cent of the arrears of salary
label: RPC

text: After considering the submissions of the learned Senior Counsel we are not inclined to interfere with the order of the Tribunal
label: RPC

text: The appeal is accordingly dismissed
label: RPC

text: J
label: NONE

text: L NAGESWARA RAO
label: NONE

text: J DEEPAK GUPTA New Delhi January 17 2020
label: NONE

text: IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 17TH DAY OF NOVEMBER 2018
label: PREAMBLE

text: PRESENT THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE SREENIVAS HARISH KUMAR AND THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE ASHOK G NIJAGANNAVAR CRIMINAL APPEAL No 1139 OF 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: BETWEEN Premkumar Appellant
label: PREAMBLE

text: S o Late Devappa Aged about 21 years R o Vijayapura 2nd Cross Chikmagalur Town N o Doopadahalli Shikaripura Taluk
label: PREAMBLE

text: Shimoga District 577427
label: PREAMBLE

text: By Sri Venkatesh P Dalwai Advocate
label: PREAMBLE

text: AND The State of Karnataka Respondent
label: PREAMBLE

text: By Chikmagalur Town Police Station Represented by State Public Prosecutor High Court Building Bangalore 560001 By Sri Vijayakumar Majage Addl SPP
label: PREAMBLE

text: This Criminal Appeal is filed under Section 374 2 of Criminal Procedure Code praying to set aside
label: PREAMBLE

text: the conviction order and sentence dated 16 08 2013 passed by the Prl Sessions Special Judge Chikmagalur in S C No 137 2010 convicting the appellant accused for the offence punishable under Sections 376 506 of IPC This Criminal Appeal coming on for hearing this day Sreenivas Harish Kumar J delivered the following JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Principal Sessions Judge Chikmagalur by his judgment dated 16 8 2013 in S C 137 2010 convicted the appellant for the offences punishable under sections 376 and 506 of the Indian Penal Code for short IPC and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for life and pay fine of Rs 50 000 and in default to undergo simple imprisonment for two years in relation to offence under section 376 IPC and also sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for five years and pay fine of Rs 10 000 with a default clause of simple imprisonment for six months in relation to offence under Section 506 IPC
label: RLC

text: The Sessions Court also ordered for payment of Rs 50 000 as compensation to the victim girl from out of the fine amount by exercising its power under section 357 of the Criminal Procedure Code for short Cr P C
label: RLC

text: Aggrieved by this judgment the accused has preferred this appeal
label: FAC

text: 2 The prosecution case is as follows On 29 7 2010 the victim girl made a report to the police stating that on 25 7 2010 at about 9 00 pm she went to a bakery situated near Syndicate Bank on IG road Chikmagalur for buying some eatables
label: FAC

text: When she was returning to her house at about 9 15 pm the accused forcibly took her to a nearby dilapidated house and tried to outrage her modesty
label: FAC

text: As she screamed he left that place by putting a threat to her that if she would disclose that incident to anybody he would kill her
label: FAC

text: She returned to the house but did not disclose the same to anybody in her house
label: FAC

text: On 29 7 2010 at 5 00 pm she disclosed about the incident dated 25 7 2010 to her father
label: FAC

text: Thereafter the father brought her to the police station where she gave a report to the police which came to be registered in Cr No 160 2010 for the offences punishable under sections 354 and 506 IPC 3
label: FAC

text: On 30 7 2010 the victim girl was taken to hospital by a women constable for medical examination
label: FAC

text: The doctor who conducted medical examination gave a report that he noticed the evidence of recent sexual intercourse
label: FAC

text: Therefore the charge sheet was filed for the offences under Section 376 and Section 506 IPC 4
label: FAC

text: After charging the accused the Sessions Court conducted trial
label: FAC

text: The prosecution examined 12 witnesses PWs1 to 12 and got marked 10 documents as per Exs P1 to P10
label: FAC

text: The appellant was examined under section 313 Cr P C
label: FAC

text: After appreciating the evidence the trial court came to conclusion that the prosecution was able to prove its case and therefore convicted and sentenced the accused as aforesaid
label: FAC

text: The trial court has given the following findings to hold the accused guilty of the offence 4 1
label: RLC

text: The evidence given by PW1 the victim girl is believable
label: RLC

text: There is nothing on record showing that PW1 is an unworthy witness
label: RLC

text: The evidence of PWs3 and 4 further testifies the evidence given by PW1
label: RLC

text: These two witnesses have not been discredited in the cross examination
label: RLC

text: It is for the accused to have explained as to what made him to be present along with PW1
label: RLC

text: The entire testimony of PW1 stands corroborated by the medical evidence given by PW9
label: RLC

text: With regard to delay the trial court has held that whenever an incident of this nature takes place it is usual that the victim does not reveal the incident immediately
label: RLC

text: Therefore delay does not come in the way of believing the case of the prosecution
label: RLC

text: 5 Impugning the findings of the Sessions Court the counsel for the appellant firstly argues that the charge framed against the accused is defective
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In the charge it is stated that the age of the girl was 15 years on the date of the incident
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: But Ex P3 the document produced by the prosecution to prove the age of the girl shows her date of birth as 16 1 1994
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Therefore her age on the date of alleged incident was 16 years 6 months
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: If the correct age had been mentioned in the charge it would have given the accused an opportunity to take a line of defence that it was not an incident of rape rather a consensual intercourse
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Since the charge is defective the accused was denied of taking defence in this manner and therefore his interest is prejudiced
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: For this reason the case requires to be remanded to the trial court for correcting the charge and holding denovo trial
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 5 1 Secondly he argues that in Ex P1 the first information the offences mentioned are 354 and 506 IPC
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Even if Ex P7 is read it only gives an impression that some attempt might have been made to outrage the modesty of the girl
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The victim girl was studying in I year PUC
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: If really an incident of rape had taken place she could have revealed the same in Ex P1
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It is in her handwriting
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He further refers to Ex P8 the medical certificate and argues that the doctor noticed only two external injuries namely an abrasion over the right knee and an abrasion over the left thigh
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: These injuries show that the girl was not subjected to rape
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Indirectly the medical certificate supports the defence version that there was consent on the part of the girl
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: If it was a case of rape the doctor would have noticed some other injuries near the genital organ of the girl or some other resistance marks
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: If Ex P8 does not disclose injuries of this nature the inference that can be drawn is that it was a case of consent only
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In this regard he further argues that the alleged date of incident is 25 7 2010 i e before amendment was brought to section 375 of IPC in the year 2013
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Before amendment a consensual act of intercourse with a female up to the age of 16 years was not an offence and for this reason the entire case of the prosecution could be brought within the purview of sixthly of section 375
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He garnered support for his argument from Ex P3 in which the date of birth of the girl is shown as 16 1 1994
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: His another point of argument is that nothing prevented the victim s father examined as PW2 from disclosing the incident before the police to see that a complaint under section 376 was registered
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Therefore PW2 also becomes untrusty witness
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He argues that PWs3 and 4 are the chance witnesses
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Even if the evidence of these two witnesses is believable it is possible to say that their evidence also shows consent on the part of the girl
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Therefore it is his argument that if all these aspects are taken into consideration though a specific defence of consent was not introduced during cross examination it is possible to draw inferences in this manner
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The trial court has failed to appreciate the evidence in proper perspective and thus the judgment of the trial court is erroneous
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 6 Countering the argument of the learned counsel for the appellant Sri Vijayakumar Majage Additional SPP argues that any defect in charge is not a matter to be considered seriously unless the accused is able to demonstrate as to how his interest is prejudiced
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Moreover there is evidence of doctor PW8 that the age of the girl was 13 to 14 years
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The theory of consent is not available as PW1 was not cross examined in that angle
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The cross examination of PW1 shows that she has not been discredited
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The evidence of the doctor PW 9 who examined the girl has not been discredited
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In fact two external injuries noticed by the doctor shows that the girl was forcibly dragged to a dilapidated house where the offence was committed
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: There are no infirmities in the findings given by the trial court and therefore the judgment of the trial court should not be interfered with
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 7 We have considered the points of arguments and perused the evidence both oral and documentary
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is true that when the first information was given to the police as per Ex P1 on 29 7 2010 the victim girl just stated that she was sought to be outraged by a boy who met her while she was returning from a bakery at about 9 15 pm
label: ANALYSIS

text: The actual incident as disclosed in Ex P1 is said to have taken place on 25 7 2010
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is a delay of 4 days in reporting to the police
label: ANALYSIS

text: In regard to delay we too are of the opinion that no girl dares to reveal the incident soon after the incident and therefore delay cannot be seriously considered
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 With regard to one line of argument advanced by the learned counsel for the appellant regarding defect in charge we have to state that though the age is mentioned as 15 years in the charge Ex P3 the age proof produced by the prosecution shows that date of birth of the girl is 16 1 1994
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution cannot go back upon this document
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore on the date of the alleged incident the age of the girl appears to be 16 years 6 months
label: ANALYSIS

text: But the argument of the learned counsel that on account of defect in charge he was deprived of the defence cannot be accepted
label: ANALYSIS

text: Defect in charge is not a matter that can be taken note of unless that defect seriously prejudices the interest of the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: Having noticed the correct date of birth nothing prevented the accused from making an application before the trial court to correctly mention the age of the girl in the charge or taking up a defence with regard to consent while cross examining the material witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: Neither the victim girl nor the investigation officer has been questioned
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore this argument is not acceptable
label: ANALYSIS

text: However on perusing the evidence of the other material witnesses PWs1 and 2 and also the doctor PW9 we have to arrive at a conclusion different from the findings given by the trial court for the following reasons 8 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW1 the prosecutrix has stated that on 25 7 2010 at about 9 00 pm she went to a bakery
label: ANALYSIS

text: While she was returning to her house the accused closed her mouth and forcibly took her to a dilapidated house near Seethamma Mysore Krishnappa Municipal Hospital and there he removed her clothes and he also removed his clothes
label: ANALYSIS

text: She has clearly stated that he spread her veil on the ground and thereafter sexually assaulted on her forcibly without her consent
label: ANALYSIS

text: She screamed at that time
label: ANALYSIS

text: She has stated that he put a threat to her that he would kill her in case she would disclose this incident to anybody
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to her when she was wearing the clothes PWs3 4 and CW6 came to that place as they heard a screaming voice
label: ANALYSIS

text: She narrated the entire incident to them
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused ran away seeing these three people coming there
label: ANALYSIS

text: All the three escorted her till her house
label: ANALYSIS

text: After returning to the house she did not disclose the same to her father and other members of the family
label: ANALYSIS

text: She took bath and washed her clothes
label: ANALYSIS

text: She has stated that she did not inform about the incident to anybody fearing injury to her reputation
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the cross examination she has been questioned as to why she did not disclose to her parents at least
label: ANALYSIS

text: She has answered that she could not disclose the same as it was not a matter to be disclosed
label: ANALYSIS

text: She has denied the suggestion that at the time of incident her age was more than 18 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: The other portion of the cross examination need not be mentioned here as nothing worth is elicited from her
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 2 PW2 is the father of the victim girl
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has only spoken that on 29 7 2010 at about 5 30 pm his daughter told him that while she was returning from bakery the accused closed her mouth took her to a dilapidated house and thereafter committed rape on her and also put life threat to her if she disclosed the incident to anybody
label: ANALYSIS

text: Except giving suggestions to this witness nothing worth has been elicited from him in the cross examination
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 3 PWs3 and 4 have given evidence that on 25 7 2010 at about 9 20 pm when they were going near Srinagar Circle near Seethamma Krishnappa Mysuru Hospital they heard a screaming voice
label: ANALYSIS

text: Immediately they went to that place and saw PW1 and the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: They have stated that the accused ran away from that place seeing them
label: ANALYSIS

text: When they asked PW1 as to what happened she told that the accused closed her mouth and brought to that place removed the clothes and raped her
label: ANALYSIS

text: Their evidence in examination in chief shows that she told them that the accused spread her veil on the ground before having intercourse with her
label: ANALYSIS

text: They have denied the suggestions given to them in the cross examination
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW5 is the Principal of the college where PW1 was studying
label: ANALYSIS

text: She speaks about Ex P3 a certificate stating that the date of birth of PW1 was 16 1 1994
label: ANALYSIS

text: Very strangely a suggestion is given to PW5 that the date of birth 16 1 1994 was not the correct date of birth
label: ANALYSIS

text: She has denied that suggestion
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 5 The other two important witnesses whose evidence needs consideration are PWs8 and 9
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW8 has given evidence that on 30 7 2010 he examined PW1 and then sent her to a dentist
label: ANALYSIS

text: As per the certificate given by the dentist he mentioned the age of PW1 as 13 to 14 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex P6 is the said certificate
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW9 is the doctor who examined the victim girl
label: ANALYSIS

text: He found her hymen ruptured
label: ANALYSIS

text: There was no be bleeding but there was tenderness
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the clinical examination he arrived at a conclusion that there were signs of recent intercourse and he issued the certificate as per Ex P8
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 6 PW10 is the investigation officer he has given an account of investigation conducted by him
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 On re appreciation of evidence of these witnesses it is possible to say that the age of the girl on the date of incident was not 15 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though a suggestion has been given to PW5 that the date mentioned in Ex P3 is not correct it cannot be given much importance because it is just a suggestion
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution cannot make use of this suggestion to hold that the age of the girl on the date of incident was 15 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex P3 is produced by the prosecution and it binds the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the age of the girl on the date of incident was not 15 years her correct age was 16 years 6 months
label: ANALYSIS

text: What we need to examine here is whether consent on the part of the girl can be inferred although such a defence has not been put forward in the cross examination
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion such inferences can certainly be drawn from the evidence in examination in chief itself if inklings to that effect are available though sometimes specific defence is not introduced in cross examination or defence evidence not lead
label: ANALYSIS

text: If this benefit is available to the accused that has to be given notwithstanding such a defence being not taken
label: ANALYSIS

text: As has been referred to above PW1 has clearly stated the way in which she was taken to a dilapidated place and subjected to intercourse
label: ANALYSIS

text: The same thing is revealed by her before PWs 3 and 4 also
label: ANALYSIS

text: If evidence of PWs1 3 and 4 is scrutinized it can be very much said that she knew the accused even before the incident took place as he happened to be her neighbour
label: ANALYSIS

text: In addition to evidence of PW1 about removal of clothes and spreading a piece of cloth on the floor what can be made out from medical certificate Ex P8 is also important
label: ANALYSIS

text: Only two injuries were noticed by the doctor
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has mentioned the same in Ex P8
label: ANALYSIS

text: They are abrasions on the right knee and left thigh
label: ANALYSIS

text: The State Public Prosecutor has argued that these injuries in fact show that she was forcibly taken to a dilapidated house or otherwise such injuries would not have occurred
label: ANALYSIS

text: Of course this argument is plausible
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also true that the evidence of PW9 shows that he noticed signs of recent intercourse when he examined the girl
label: ANALYSIS

text: But these injuries and evidence of PW9 by themselves will not lead to conclusion being drawn about rape
label: ANALYSIS

text: There are other circumstances also
label: ANALYSIS

text: In an incident relating to rape the evidence of prosecutrix must be trustworthy only then her sole testimony can be relied upon
label: ANALYSIS

text: The medical evidence is only corroborative nothing more
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 There remains the evidence of PW3 and PW4 who have stated they heard the scream of PW1 and went to the place of incident
label: ANALYSIS

text: But their evidence is difficult to be believed
label: ANALYSIS

text: If they accompanied PW1 till her house they did not inform the father of PW2 about what they came to know from PW1
label: ANALYSIS

text: If PW2 was present in the house when PW3 or PW4 brought her the former should have spoken in examination in chief that PW3 or PW4 brought his daughter to house on that night
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if he was not present he should have deposed so because such a testimony of PW2 would have corroborated the testimonies of PW3 and PW4
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is an important circumstance which if established makes the testimony of PW1 believable
label: ANALYSIS

text: The answer given by PW4 in the cross examination clearly shows that he and PW3 met PW2 on the date of incident but they did not tell him anything
label: ANALYSIS

text: Added to this PW4 has also stated that PW3 CW4 and he had gone to that place and did not see accused running away from that place
label: ANALYSIS

text: This being the evidence of PW4 it is not safe to place reliance on evidence of PW3 and PW4
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of PW2 is also difficult to be relied upon for he being the father of PW1 could have at the time of lodging FIR by PW1 brought to the notice of police about actual incident of rape
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 The age of the girl as per Ex P3 appears to be 16 years 6 months
label: ANALYSIS

text: Evidence in examination in chief shows semblance of consent and her evidence lacks credit worthiness
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore we arrive at a conclusion that the reasons ascribed by the learned Sessions Judge for holding that the prosecution has proved its case beyond reasonable doubt cannot be accepted
label: RATIO

text: The doubts that arise from the scrutiny of the evidence of PW1 PW2 PW3 or PW4 have remained answered
label: RATIO

text: The findings given by the trial court cannot be accepted
label: RATIO

text: Hence we proceed to pass the following order a Appeal is allowed b The judgment dated 16 8 2013 in S C 137 2010 passed by the Principal Sessions Judge Chikmagalur is set aside c The accused is acquitted of the offence He shall be let free from custody forthwith if his presence is not required in any other case
label: RPC

text: The learned counsel for the appellant has filed application I A 1 2018 under section 8 read with section 12 1 G of the Legal Services Authority Act 1987 seeking a direction to the State Legal Services Authority and High Court Legal Services Committee to ensure time bound compliance of directions given by the Hon ble Supreme Court in SLP Cri 6740 2018 in the case of Imtiyaz Ramzan Khan vs State of Maharastra
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The learned counsel submits that in cases where legal aid is given to accused it is difficult for the advocates rendering legal aid to contact the accused who are languishing in jail and take suitable instructions
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He also submits that the accused should also be aware that their case are posted before the court and they should be in a position to contact their lawyers
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Therefore suitable directions may be issued in accordance with the Supreme Court judgment
label: ANALYSIS

text: Learned counsel for the appellant has produced a letter communicated to him by the High Court Legal Services Committee to the effect that there is already a video conferencing facility to enable the advocates to contact the accused undergoing sentence in the jail
label: ANALYSIS

text: If any counsel wants to obtain instructions from the accused who are in custody they should approach the Committee for providing video conferencing facility
label: ANALYSIS

text: From this letter it is clear that the Legal Services Authority has already taken steps to facilitate video conference to enable the advocates to contact the accused who are in custody
label: ANALYSIS

text: But at the same time we have to state that the accused should also be aware about their cases being posted before the court
label: ANALYSIS

text: We do not find such a facility is made available to the accused in the jail
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore Karnataka State Legal Services Authority and the High Court Legal Services Committee are hereby directed to instruct the Jail Superintendents that necessary arrangements be made to enable the accused to contact the advocates who have been engaged by Legal Aid Committee for rendering assistance to them
label: RPC

text: The Jail Superintendents should also bring to the notice of the accused that their cases are posted before the Court so that the accused can give suitable instructions to their advocates through video conference before their cases are argued
label: RPC

text: The Registry may take suitable steps for notifying the Jail Superintendents about listing of cases in which legal aid is given for final hearing
label: RPC

text: With these observations I A 1 2018 is disposed of
label: RPC

text: Sd JUDGE Sd JUDGE Ckl
label: NONE

text: 56 IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI Judgment delivered on 17 01 2017 W P C 8374 2016 SELECT INFRASTRUCTURE PRIVATE LIMITED Petitioner versus COMMISSIONER VALUE ADDED TAX ORS Respondents Advocates who appeared in this case For the Petitioner Mr Harsh Sethi and Mr Ruchir Bhatia For the Respondents Mr P Roychaudhuri for R 1 Mr Rahul Malhotra for R 2 CORAM HON BLE MR JUSTICE SANJEEV SACHDEVA JUDGMENT 17 01 2017 SANJEEV SACHDEVA J ORAL 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: The petitioner seeks quashing of the sealing order under Section 60 of the Delhi Value Added Tax Act 2004 dated 11 12 2015 in respect of the premises bearing No S 21 22 on the Second Floor Select City Walk District Centre Saket New Delhi and for de sealing of the premises
label: FAC

text: 2 It is contended that the petitioner is the owner of the Select City Walk as also the said premises bearing No S 21 22 on the Second Floor Select City Walk District Centre Saket New Delhi 3 It is submitted that by Agreement of Licence dated 06 03 2007 the premises was licensed to respondent No 2 to open and run a restaurant and Bar in the name and style of Geoffreys 4 It is contended that on 11 12 2015 the officers of respondent No 1 Commissioner Value Added Tax came and sealed the said premises on account of alleged violation of the provisions of Delhi Value Added Tax by respondent No 2 5
label: FAC

text: It is contended that respondent No 2 was a mere licensee and has no right title or interest in the said premises
label: FAC

text: Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner is willing to make available some space in the same Complex where the goods of the respondent No 2 can be shifted so that the premises of the petitioner can be de sealed
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Learned counsel for the respondent No 2 submits that respondent No 2 has no objection to the goods being shifted to another premises within the same Complex
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: He further submits that respondent No 2 has no right title or claim to the said premises and is also not seeking to enforce the rights granted under the Licence Agreement any further
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Learned counsel appearing for the Commissioner Value Added Tax submits that the Commissioner has no objection to the goods being shifted to some other portion in the same Complex provided that the respondent No 2 is not permitted to deal with the goods till the Commissioner Value Added Tax is in a position to take appropriate step with regard to attachment seizure of the same
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It is submitted that since the premises had been sealed the Commissioner did not take any step for initiating any action for attachment seizure of the goods as the goods were lying in the sealed premises
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: He further submits that the petitioner should ensure that the goods that are shifted are secured till further action is taken by the Commissioner Value Added Tax and further the respondent No 2 is not permitted to deal with the goods 10
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In view of the above submission the petitioner is directed to make an appropriate arrangement of space in the same complex for shifting the goods of respondent No 2 lying in the premises bearing No S 21 22 on the Second Floor Select City Walk District Centre Saket New Delhi
label: RPC

text: 11 The petitioner should ensure that the location where the goods are shifted are of a condition which can be sealed and secured
label: RPC

text: 12 Accordingly Ms Sumedha Dang Advocate who is present in Court Mobile No 9717325769 is appointed as a Local Commissioner to supervise the dismantling of equipment and shifting of the equipment and goods furniture fittings and fixtures to a secured location within the same complex
label: RPC

text: 13 The Commission shall be executed commencing from Friday the 20th January 2017
label: RPC

text: In case the dismantling and shifting cannot take place in a day the Commissioner shall ensure that the shifting carries on on day to day basis
label: RPC

text: 14 The officers of the respondent No 1 and representative of respondent No 2 shall also be permitted to be present at the time of the dismantling and shifting of the equipment fittings fixtures and furniture belonging to respondent No 2 from the said premises
label: RPC

text: 15 The Local Commissioner shall also prepare an inventory of the equipment fittings fixtures and furniture belonging to respondent No 2 which is shifted
label: RPC

text: The petitioner shall make arrangement for video graphy of the entire exercise
label: RPC

text: Copy of the video graph shall also be deposited in Court by the Local Commissioner
label: RPC

text: 16 The Local Commissioner shall ensure that the premises where the equipment fittings fixtures and furniture belonging to respondent No 2 is shifted is secured and sealed
label: RPC

text: The keys shall be deposited with the Registrar General of this Court
label: RPC

text: 17 The fee of the Local Commissioner shall be Rs 75 000 per day to be borne equally by the petitioner as well as the respondent No 2
label: RPC

text: 18 Respondent No 1 is granted four weeks time to take appropriate steps as may be permissible in law with regard to the equipment fittings fixtures and furniture belonging to respondent No 2
label: RPC

text: 19 In case no steps are taken by respondent No 1 for seizure attachment of the said equipment fittings fixtures and furniture belonging to respondent No 2 within the period of four weeks the same shall be liable to be handed over to respondent No 2 20
label: RPC

text: The officers of respondent No 1 shall be present on the said premises at 11 A M on 20th January 2017 for the purposes of desealing of the premises and commencement of the process of shifting
label: RPC

text: 21 After the process of shifting is completed the said premises i e premises bearing No S 21 22 on the Second Floor Select City Walk District Centre Saket New Delhi shall not be sealed and the possession of the premises shall be handed over to the Petitioner
label: RPC

text: 22 The Writ Petition is accordingly disposed of in the above terms 23 List for reporting compliance on 22nd February 2017
label: RPC

text: 24 Dasti under signatures of the Court Master
label: NONE

text: SANJEEV SACHDEVA J JANUARY 17 2017 Sn
label: NONE
