text: 1 This order disposes of all the above seventeen Sales Tax References and two Writ Petitions
label: FAC

text: For the purpose of the present judgment we refer to the facts and issues raised in Sales Tax Reference No 11 of 2006 Writ Petition No 2055 of 2003 and Sales Tax Reference No 49 of 2006
label: FAC

text: The issues that arise for consideration pertains to additive flavour compounds only and synthetic essential oils fragrances etc
label: FAC

text: Vide order 31st March 2006 the following questions were referred to this Court i Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case was the Tribunal justified in negating the revenue s interpretation of the words and their compounds in schedule entry C I 19 as covering only the compounds of natural and synthetic essential oils as not quite proper and interpreting the words and their compounds therein to mean the compounds of the aromatic chemicals as well
label: ISSUE

text: ii Whether on the facts an circumstances of the case was the Tribunal justified in holding that the impugned product i e flavouring compound is compound covered by Schedule Entry C I 19 and liable to tax 4 per cent from 1 1 1988 to 10 8 1988 and 1994 95
label: ISSUE

text: iii Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case was the Tribunal justified in concluding that the impugned product i e perfumery compound are compounds or aromatic chemicals within the meaning of Schedule Entry C I 19 and hence liable to tax 4 for the period 1 1 1998 to 31 3 1995
label: ISSUE

text: 2 For the purpose of this judgment we refer to the facts in the case of Sales Tax Reference No 47 of 2009
label: FAC

text: The Respondent assessee is a manufacturer of Aromatic Chemicals Flavouring Compounds Natural and Synthetic Essential Oil and Fragrances etc
label: FAC

text: The assessing authority levied a tax at 15 on the sales of flavouring compounds and perfumery compounds treating them as covered under entry C II 78 with effect from 11th August 1988
label: FAC

text: Perfumery compounds were also taxed under C II 86 as fragrances and penalties were also levied
label: FAC

text: 3 According to the Respondent assessee sales of flavouring compounds and perfumery compounds were covered under entry C I 19
label: FAC

text: The assessee filed a first appeal before the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax who considered the above submissions but rejected them holding that the assessing officer had not erred in treating the impugned sale as covered in schedule entry C I 19
label: FAC

text: The first Appellate Authority thus confirmed the order of the assessing authority with regard to levy of taxes
label: FAC

text: 4 Being aggrieved by the order of the first appellate authority the appellant filed a second appeal before the Tribunal
label: FAC

text: The Appellate Tribunal after hearing both sides partly allowed the second appeal vide order dated 31st March 2003 and held that during the period 11th August 1988 to 31st March 1994 the sale of flavouring compound was liable to be taxed at the rate of 15 being covered under schedule entry C II 78
label: FAC

text: After the period 1st January 1988 to 11th August 1988 and during 1994 95 flavouring compounds were liable to be taxed at 4 being covered under entry C I 19
label: FAC

text: It was further held that perfumery compounds were liable to sales tax at 4 during the period 1st January 1988 to 31st March 1995
label: FAC

text: The claims pertaining to goods returned set off sale of REP licence etc were remanded to the Deputy Commissioner
label: FAC

text: 5 Mr Sridharan learned Senior Counsel appearing on behalf of the assessee in all these matters submitted that the arguments raised by the revenue before the Maharashtra Sales Tax Tribunal were as follows a Entry C I 19 does not cover compounds of aromatic chemicals but the entry covers only the compounds of natural synthetic essential oils and no other compounds b Entry C I 19 covers only the compounds which are sold as single entity in form which is almost pure
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: c Entry C I 19 relates only to compounds treated individually i e without requirement of specific formulation
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In other words it does not cover any prepared mixture
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: On the three questions framed he submitted that as far as the first question reproduced above the Tribunal had answered this question in its judgment dated 31st March 2003 as follows The reading of the entry C I 19 done by the revenue is not quite proper
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The words their compounds therein would obviously mean the compounds of the Aromatic Chemicals and Synthetic and Natural Essential Oils
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: They would certainly not mean compounds merely of synthetic and natural essential oils as sought to be interpreted by the revenue
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: When the synthetic and natural oils themselves were covered by C I 19 there was obviously no need to specify that even the compounds of such oils would also be covered by the same entry
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: As compounds of various chemicals are covered by the term chemicals the compounds of the aforesaid oils are also covered by the term synthetic and natural essential oils
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In that view of the matter it is absolutely clear that the words their compounds in C I 19 means not the compounds of oils but the compounds of aromatic and oils
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Therefore C I 19 does include mixtures except culinary and flavour essences
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 6 Mr Sridharan submitted that ordinarily the use of semicolon in a classification creates a distinction between the terms of inputs before and after the semicolon
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He relies upon the decision of the Supreme Court in Falcon Tyres V s
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: State of Karnataka reported in 2006 6 SCC 530 in support of his submission that in the impugned entry C I 19 no such semicolon is used in the entry and there was no distinction between aromatic chemicals on the one other and natural and synthetic essential oils on the hand
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Consequently it is submitted that the words and their compounds will refer to both compounds of aromatic chemicals as well as compounds of natural and synthetic essential oils
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Sridharan further submits that in Union of India V s Pesticides Mfg Formulators Assn Of India reported in 2002 7 SCC 410 the Apex Court has held that a compound is mixture of components and therefore entry at C I 19 includes mixtures of aromatic chemicals and natural and synthetic essential oils
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The impugned products will not fall outside the entry merely on account of being a mixture
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 7 As far as the second question is concerned Mr Sridharan has submitted that the second question was relevant only for matters pertaining to M s International Flavours and Fragrances
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He submitted that the terms in a classification entry must be interpreted using the principle of noscitur a socis
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Sridharan relied on the Apex Court in Gordhandas Tokersey Pardeep Agarbatti and G Radhakrishna Murti supra
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He submitted that the principle must be applied even when interpreting an entry containing two or more terms
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In this behalf he relied upon Bennion on Statutory interpretation 5th Edition at page 1197
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Sridharan further submitted that the terms culinary and flavouring is used only as a composite expression i e two words wherein one gives meaning to the other and there is no specific reason as to why the terms are used separately
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Sridharan submitted that this Court in the case of Commissioner of Sales Tax V s Khosla Kesharwala reported in 2006 145 STC 57 Bom also indicates that a classification under entry C II 78 requires the impugned product to predominantly relate to cooking as a colouring and flavouring agent 8
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In effect Mr Sridharan submitted that only those products which are in relation to culinary i e used in a kitchen which are covered under C II 78
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The impugned product i e flavouring essence is not used directly in a kitchen or in cooking or any other similar manner but used as raw materials in industries such as pharmaceuticals confectionery products
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He submitted that this aspect has been considered by the Tribunal in its judgment on 31st March 2006 in paragraphs 7 to 9
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: For all these reasons it is submitted that the impugned product does not fall within entry C II 78 but falls under C I 19 9
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: With reference to the third question Mr Sridharan submitted that it is relevant only in the matter of S H Kelkar Respondent in Sales Tax Reference No 47 of 2006 and others
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In that case he submitted that the limited question is whether the impugned product determined as perfumery compound is found to be falling within entry C I 19 and hence not under entry C II 86 dealing specifically with perfumes other than those covered under C I 19
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Sridharan submits that the test of common commercial trade parlance has to b applied in interpreting schedule entries pertaining to classification relying upon the judgments of the Supreme Court in Chemical and Fibres of India Ltd
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: V s Union of India reported in 1997 2 SCC 664 and Ramavatar Budhaiprasad V s
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Asst Sales Tax Officer Akola reported in 1961 12 STC 286 in support of his contention
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He further submitted that the specification and standards prepared by the Bureau of Indian Standards as published have been considered strong indicators of commercial and consumer parlance and glossaries published by the Indian Standards Organization have been relied by Courts in various judgments
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 10 In support of his contention he placed reliance upon the decision of Chemical and Fibres of India Ltd supra Warden Co V s CCE Thane reported in 1995 Suppl 1 SCC 740 and CCE Kanpur V s Krishna Carbon reported in 1989 1 SCC 150
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He further submitted that as per the Indian Standard Glossary of terms relating to natural and synthetic perfumery material the term perfumery compound has been specifically defined as a concentrated base which is further diluted and modified to suit various end uses
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Perfume has been distinctly defined as a solution of perfumery compound in ethanol or other suitable solvent meant for use as a personal adornment
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 11 Mr Sridharan further submits that there is a distinction between perfumery compound and perfume which clearly indicates that both terms are to be treated distinctly in commercial or trade parlance therefore it is submitted that perfume fragrance cannot fall within entry relating to perfumes C II 86 the product will remain classified under C I 19
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Sridharan and Mr Patkar further submitted that the entry relating to perfumes under the Bombay Sales Tax Act prior to 1981 E I 19 is specifically interpreted in the case of CST V s
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Gordhandas Tokersey reported in 1983 52 STC 381 using the principle of noscitur a sociis to refer to preparations as are commonly known in market for use on the body as perfumes
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 12 This interpretation was referred in Pandurang Agarbatti V s
label: PRE_RELIED

text: State of Punjab reported in 1997 107 STC 56 and G Radhakrishna Murti Co Ors V s
label: PRE_RELIED

text: CFTO Vijaywada reported in 1999 113 STC 161 SC
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The entry being interpreted in the above mentioned decisions is similar to the entry C II 86 dealing with perfumes therefore what is covered by entry C II 86 are those goods commonly used directly on the human body
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is an undisputed fact that the impugned products are not used directly on the human body and are used in various industries for the purpose of respective end products
label: ANALYSIS

text: The revenue itself has accepted that the impugned products were sold to various manufacturers of soaps cosmetics agarbattis etc
label: ANALYSIS

text: The impugned products therefore cannot fall within entry C II 86
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 Mr Sridharan submitted that in G Radhakrishna supra the Apex Court had held that the meaning of the word perfume in modern times has undergone a change observing that the etymological meaning or the original meaning of perfume may come from the word fumare smoke but in modern parlance it has undergone a change
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The word perfume orginates from the word fumare which means smoke or to emit vapour
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: These are the meaning given by the Oxford Dictionary
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The word Perfume is also considered in Gordhandas Tokersey supra
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In that case the Court observed that when two or more words which are capable of being understood in an analogous manner are coupled together they should be understood in the common analogous sense and not in a general sense
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: By applying this principle the Court held that perfume in C I 19 referred to such preparation as they are commonly known in the market for use on the body as perfumes
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Patkar learned counsel appearing for the Petitioners in the Writ Petitions relied upon the judgment of this Court in Gordhandas Tokersey supra and adopted the submissions of Mr Sridharan
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 14 Mr Sridharan further submits that it is well accepted that in cases of classification the burden of proof is placed on the revenue which must be discharged in order to sustain an assessment as valid
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In this behalf he relied on the judgment of the Supreme Court in Hindustan Ferodo Vs CCE reported in 1997 89 ELT 16 SC and Union of India V s Garware Nylons reported in 1996 10 SCC 413
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In his view the revenue has failed to discharge its burden by placing evidence on the basis of which the impugned product can be classified as perfumery compounds under C II 86
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 15 Mr Sonpal on the other hand supported the impugned order
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Mr Sonpal learned counsel appearing for the revenue relied upon the decision of this Court in Bradma of India Limited V s
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: State of Maharashtra reported in 1998 110 339 and submitted that if there are two entries one general and the other special the special entry should be applied for the purpose of levying tax
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The general entry should give way to the special entry
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Accordingly he submits that the impugned order cannot be faulted
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Mr Sonpal then relied upon the decision of this Court in Gordhandas Tokersey
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: He has also relied upon the judgment of G Radhakrishna supra
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 16 Having considered the rival contentions statutory interpretations we agree with Mr Sridharan that a composite expression must be construed as a whole and in the words of Bennion it is incorrect to assume that the whole is necessarily the sum of its parts because a certain meaning can be collected by taking each word in turn and then combining their several meanings
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this connection we find that it will be appropriate to refer to dictionary meanings of certain words which will throw light on various terms with which we are now concerned
label: ANALYSIS

text: 17 The definition of the term in the Indian Standards Glossary of terms relating to natural and synthetic perfumery published by the Bureau of Indian Standard and referred to the definition of aromatic chemicals at item 2 7 essential oil 2 47 essential oil and synthetic 2 48 perfumery compound 2 87
label: ANALYSIS

text: The aforesaid definitions are reproduced below 2 7 Aromatic Chemicals Aroma Chemicals Organic chemicals derived by organic synthesis oras isolate from natural essential oils possessing distinct aroma
label: ANALYSIS

text: Used as a raw material of terms and it may not necessarily include all the legal meaning of the terms
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 47 Essential Oil It is a volatile perfumery material derived from a single source of vegetable or animal origin by a process such as hydrodistillation steam distillation dry distillation or expression
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 48 Essential Oil Synthetic
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is a composition generally consisting of natural essential oils aromatic chemicals resinoids concretes absolutes etc but excluding animal or vegetable non essential oils and not having volatile residue in excess of 10 percent by mass
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is so composed that it bears a close resemblance primarily in odour to a naturally occurring essential oil
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 87 Perfumery Compound A concentrated base which is further diluted with or without toning and further modification to suit various end uses Entry No C I 19 reads as under 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: Aromatic Chemicals and 4 4 1 7 1981 natural and synthetic oils 31 3 1984 and their compounds 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: Aromatic chemicals and 4 4 1 4 1984 to their residue and natural 10 8 1988 and synthetic essential oils and their compounds 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: Aromatic chemicals and 4 4 1 8 1988 to their residue and natural 30 4 1992 and synthetic essential oils and their compounds except the culinary and flavouring essences covered by entry 78 of Part II of this Schedule 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: Aromatic chemicals and 4 4 1 5 1992 to their residue and natural 8 9 1992 and synthetic essential oils and their compounds except the perfumes and culinary and flavouring essences whether in a concentrated or diluted form 19 Aromatic chemicals and 4 4 9 9 1992 to their residue and natural 31 3 1994 and synthetic essential oils and their compounds except the culinary and flavouring essences covered by entry 78 of Part II of this Schedule 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: 1 Raw materials for 4 4 1 4 1994 to preparation of perfumes 30 9 1995 fragrances and flavors that is to say a Natural and synthetic oils and their compounds b Fragrance and flavour chemicals
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 Industrial flavours and 4 4 1 4 1994 to fragrances in 30 9 1995 concentrated form 18
label: ANALYSIS

text: A bare reading of the entry reveals that Aromatic chemicals and their compounds are not intended to be treated separately from natural and synthetic essential oils
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our view the use of the conjunction and with the word and their compounds is intended to apply to the compounds of natural synthetic oil and also compounds of aromatic chemicals and natural and synthetic oils
label: ANALYSIS

text: It will also be seen from the fact that wherever it was intended that the product or derivative chemicals were to be grouped to create a distinct category specific language has been used
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19 For instance for the period 1 1 1984 to 10 8 1988 apropos Raw Materials aromatic chemicals and their residues on one hand and Natural and Synthetic oils and their compounds on the other the words and their compounds does not apply to aromatic chemicals and their residues
label: ANALYSIS

text: For the period 11 8 1988 to 30 4 1992 a further modification is shown by way of exclusion from C I 19 of culinary and flavour essences covered by entry 78 of Part II
label: ANALYSIS

text: For the period 1 5 1992 to 8 9 1992 the perfumes and culinary and flavouring essences whether in a concentrated or diluted form have been excluded
label: ANALYSIS

text: For the period 9 9 1992 to 31 3 1994 the product described in the entry is identical to that for the period 11 8 1988 to 30 4 1992
label: ANALYSIS

text: For the period 1 4 1994 to 30 9 1995 further change is made in the system which distinguishes perfumes fragrance and flavour
label: ANALYSIS

text: The natural and synthetic oil and their compounds and fragrance and flavouring chemicals 20
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus although in the case of Raw materials it is seen that the expression and their compounds is applicable only to the natural and synthetic essential oils but not applicable to fragrance and flavour chemicals or industrial flavours and fragrance in concentrated form
label: ANALYSIS

text: A perusal of the definition of Aromatic Chemicals Essential Oil and Essential Oil Synthetic referred in 2 7 2 47 and 2 48 below reveals that they can be combined with each other
label: ANALYSIS

text: For example Essential Oil Synthetic is shown as a composition of natural essential oils and aromatic chemicals etc
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Tribunal was justified in negating the revenue s interpretation of the word and their compounds in schedule entry C I 19 covers only the compounds of natural and synthetic oil and essential oils to the exclusion of aromatic chemicals
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21 We are also of the view that the perfumery compounds are compounds of aromatic chemicals within the meaning of entry C I 19 and in view thereof we hold that the perfume is covered under C II 86 which is reproduced below 86
label: RATIO

text: Perfumes excluding those 15 15 1 7 1981 to covered by entry 19 of 31 3 1989 Part I of this Scheduled depilatories cosmetics toilet articles and preparations whether medicated or otherwise including hair creams hair tonic and liquid shampoo but excluding those covered by any other entry of this or any other schedule
label: RATIO

text: 22 In conclusion we answer the three questions in the affirmative namely in favour of the assessee and against the revenue
label: RPC

text: The References are disposed of accordingly
label: RPC

text: In view thereof Writ Petitions are also disposed off
label: RPC

text: Rule discharged therein
label: RPC

text: No order as to costs
label: RPC

text: A K MENON J S C DHARMADHIKARI J 23
label: NONE

text: After the judgment was pronounced the parties informed us that the Petitioners in two Petitions namely Writ Petition No 2055 of 2003 and Writ Petition No 2056 of 2003 have furnished bank guarantees pursuant to the interim orders of this Court
label: RPC

text: Since the issues raised in the Writ Petitions were subsequently considered as subject matter of Sales Tax References the Writ Petitions moved do not survive and disposed of in this manner
label: RPC

text: In such circumstances the request made by the Petitioners for discharging the bank guarantees is accepted
label: RPC

text: The bank guarantees to stand discharged
label: RPC

text: TAX INTERNATIONAL TAXATION II Appellant Through Mr Rahul Kaushik Senior Standing Counsel versus ROLLS ROYCE INDUSTRIAL POWER INDIA LTD Respondent Through Mr M S Syali Senior Advocate with Mr Satyen Sethi Mr Mayank Negi Mr Arth Taran Panda Advocates CORAM JUSTICE S MURALIDHAR JUSTICE CHANDER SHEKHAR ORDER
label: PREAMBLE

text: Dr S Muralidhar J 1
label: NONE

text: These are three appeals by the Revenue under Section 260A of the Income Tax Act 1961 Act against the common order dated 5th October 2010 passed by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal ITAT in ITA Nos 1410 1411 and 1413 Del 2007 relating to Assessment Years AYs 1998 1999 1999 2000 and 2001 2002 2
label: FAC

text: It must be mentioned at the outset that at the time of admission of these appeals on 23rd March 2012 there were 7 4 and 6 questions of law framed in ITA Nos 1058 1061 and 1063 of 2011 respectively
label: FAC

text: In each of the said appeals the first question framed reads as under 1 Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case ITAT was right in law in holding that assumption of jurisdiction under section 148 of the Income tax Act 1961 was not valid 3
label: FAC

text: The other questions pertain inter alia to the treatment of payments received by the Assessee from the operation and maintenance of power plant projects i e whether these receipts were taxable either as business income or as fee for technical services FTS
label: FAC

text: In these three appeals however the Court proposes to confine its examination to the first question viz the validity of the assumption of jurisdiction under Section 148 of the Act
label: ISSUE

text: 4 Having heard learned counsel for the parties the Court is satisfied that the said question has for reasons to follow to be answered in favour of the Assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: Resultantly all consequential assessment orders are rendered invalid thus obviating the need to examine the other questions that pertain to the additions made under the consequential assessment orders
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Court however clarifies that the other questions framed in these appeals and which arise in certain other connected appeals of the Revenue against the Assessee for other AYs are left open to be decided in the other appeals
label: ANALYSIS

text: 5 The Assessee a company incorporated under the laws of the United Kingdom U K during the AYs in question was engaged inter alia in the business of erection commissioning supervision operation and maintenance of power plants
label: FAC

text: The business activities in India were carried out by the Assessee through various projects offices located in India
label: FAC

text: These according to the Revenue constituted the Assessee s permanent establishment in India under Article 5 of the Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement DTAA between India and U K 6
label: FAC

text: The Assessee s returns for the three AYs in question i e AYs 1998 99 1999 2000 and 2001 2002 were picked up for scrutiny and the assessments were completed by the Assessing Officer AO by passing assessment orders under Section 143 3 of the Act
label: FAC

text: Placed before the Court are copies of the questionnaires issued by the AO for the relevant AYs and the replies thereto filed by the Assessee
label: FAC

text: These questionnaires refer to the nature of the transactions and the payments received in relation thereto
label: FAC

text: 7 For the Financial Year 2004 2005 the Assessee filed applications dated 25th June 2004 and 27th May 2004 under Section 195 3 of the Act for issuance of nil deduction of Tax Deducted at Source TDS
label: FAC

text: The Assistant Director of Income Tax ADIT Circle II 1 International Transactions by an order dated 20th July 2004 declined the application
label: FAC

text: He inter alia proposed to initiate reassessment revision proceedings under Sections 147 263 in respect of the earlier orders to bring the correct income to tax in accordance with law
label: FAC

text: The plea taken in this order was that payments received by the Assesse pursuant to the Operations and Maintenance O M Agreements should be treated as fees for technical services FTS within the meaning of Explanation 2 to Section 9 1 vii of the Act and Article 13 4 c of the DTAA between India and U K 8
label: FAC

text: Aggrieved by the above order the Petitioner applied to the Director of Income Tax DIT under Section 264 of the Act
label: FAC

text: By an order dated 20th December 2004 the DIT set aside the order of the ADIT holding that the Assesse here is neither making available technical knowledge experience nor is developing and transferring technical plan or design
label: FAC

text: He concluded that the services rendered under the O M Agreements cannot be considered as ancillary or subsidiary to the enjoyment of any right prescribed as royalty
label: FAC

text: Further under Article 13 therefore the fee for technical services does not fit into the nature of receipt the assessee is having 9
label: FAC

text: Notwithstanding the above orders the AO proceeded to reopen the assessments under Section 147 read with 148 of the Act for the three AYs in question i e 1998 1999 1999 2000 and 2001 2002
label: FAC

text: The reasons therefor were issued by the AO on 28th March 2005
label: FAC

text: It was noted inter alia by him therein that in the original assessment orders under Section 143 3 of the Act no opinion with regard to taxation of these technical services has been formed by the then AO
label: FAC

text: It was further stated that the facts relating to the nature of income being fees for technical services have never been brought to the notice of the AO 10
label: FAC

text: The Assessee objected to the reopening inter alia on the ground that it was based on mere change of opinion
label: FAC

text: Its objections were rejected by an order dated 9th September 2005 11
label: FAC

text: The reassessments were completed by treating the payments as FTS
label: FAC

text: The Assessee then carried the matter by way of appeals to the Commissioner of Income Tax Appeals CIT A
label: FAC

text: By a common order dated 29th December 2006 passed in the appeals pertaining to the three AYs in question the CIT A relying on the decision of the Division Bench DB of this Court in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax 2006 281 ITR 394 Del came to the conclusion that since the original assessment orders were silent on the aspect of treating the payments received by the Assessee as FTS the jurisdictional pre condition for attracting Section 147 stood fulfilled
label: FAC

text: 12 Aggrieved by the above order the Assessee went before the ITAT
label: FAC

text: In the impugned order the ITAT noted that while for AYs 1998 1999 and 1999 2000 the notices under Section 148 of the Act were issued after four years the notice for the AY 2001 2002 had been issued within four years
label: FAC

text: The ITAT referred to the decision of the Full Bench FB of this Court in CIT v Kelvinator of India Ltd 2002 256 ITR 1 Del
label: ANALYSIS

text: It also noted the decision of this Court in CIT vs Eicher Ltd 2007 294 ITR 310 Del where it was held that if the entire material had been placed by the Assessee before the AO at the time when the original assessment was made and the AO had applied his mind to material and accepted the view of the Assessee then the assessment cannot be reopened merely on the basis of change of opinion
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 The ITAT examined the assessment orders queries raised by the AO and the other material on record and concluded that the Assessee had duly disclosed the very nature of its activities
label: ANALYSIS

text: As regards the observation of the AO that the Assessee should have filed the accounts of each project individually instead of filing the consolidated statement of accounts the ITAT noted that the Assesse had been filing audited accounts
label: ANALYSIS

text: It opined that it was the duty of the AO to have examined this aspect in the scrutiny assessment
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further the AO had called for information in that regard and the Assessee had submitted an explanation on its activities
label: ANALYSIS

text: The ITAT therefore held that it was a different perception of the new incumbent on the same details
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus the assessment has been reopened by the AO only on the basis of the change of opinion
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further the ITAT noted that for the AYs 1998 1999 and 1999 2000 the AO was unable to point out which material facts had not been disclosed by the Assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Assessee s appeals were allowed and the reassessment orders set aside
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14 This Court has heard the submissions of both Mr Rahul Kaushik learned Senior Standing Counsel for the Revenue and Mr M S Syali learned Senior Counsel for the Assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Court has also perused the notices questionnaires issued by the AO in the course of the assessment proceedings and the replies thereto by the Assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Court has also perused the original assessment orders passed under Section 143 3 of the Act and the reasons for the reopening of the assessments
label: ANALYSIS

text: 15 The main plank of the submission of the Revenue before the CIT A which has been adverted to by the ITAT in the impugned order is the decision of the DB of this Court in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax supra
label: ANALYSIS

text: In particular reliance is placed on the following observations 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: The argument that the proposed reopening of assessment was based only upon a change of opinion has not impressed us
label: ANALYSIS

text: The assessment order did not admittedly address itself to the question which the assessing officer proposes to examine in the course of re assessment proceedings
label: ANALYSIS

text: The submission of Mr Vohra that even when the order of assessment did not record any explicit opinion on the aspects now sought to be examined it must be presumed that those aspects were present to the mind of the assessing officer and had been held in favour of the assessee is too farfetched a proposition to merit acceptance
label: ANALYSIS

text: There may indeed be a presumption that the assessment proceedings have been regularly conducted but there can be no presumption that even when the order of assessment is silent all possible angles and aspects of a controversy had been examined and determined by the assessing officer
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is trite that a matter in issue can be validly determined only upon application of mind by the authority determining the same
label: ANALYSIS

text: Application of mind is in turn best demonstrated by disclosure of mind which is best done by giving reasons for the view which the authority is taking
label: ANALYSIS

text: In cases where the order passed by a statutory authority is silent as to the reasons for the conclusion it has drawn it can well be said that the authority has not applied its mind to the issue before it nor formed any opinion
label: ANALYSIS

text: The principle that a mere change of opinion cannot be a basis for reopening computed assessments would be applicable only to situations where the assessing officer has applied his mind and taken a conscious decision on a particular matter in issue
label: ANALYSIS

text: It will have no application where the order of assessment does not address itself to the aspect which is the basis for reopening of the assessment as is the position in the present case
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is in that view inconsequential whether or not the material necessary for taking a decision was available to the assessing officer either generally or in the form of a reply to the questionnaire served upon the assessed
label: ANALYSIS

text: What is important is whether the assessing officer had based on the material available to him taken a view
label: ANALYSIS

text: If he had not done so the proposed reopening cannot be assailed on the ground that the same is based only on a change of opinion 16
label: ANALYSIS

text: The fact of the matter is that later Benches of this Court including two Full Benches in CIT v Kelvinator of India Ltd supra and CIT v Usha International Ltd 2012 348 ITR 485 have disagreed with the view expressed by the DB in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax supra
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact the decision of the FB in CIT v Kelvinator of India Ltd supra was affirmed by the Supreme Court in CIT v Kelvinator of India Ltd 2010 320 ITR 561 SC
label: ANALYSIS

text: 17 The Full Bench of this Court in CIT v Usha International Ltd supra specifically overruled the decision of the DB in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax supra
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even prior thereto in KLM Royal Dutch Airlines v ADIT 2007 292 ITR 49 another DB of this Court noticed the anomaly that had resulted from the decision in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax supra which was contrary to other decisions including the decision of the FB in CIT v Kelvinator of India Ltd supra
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was noticed by the DB in KLM Royal Dutch Airlines v ADIT supra where it observed 16
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Full Bench of this Court in Commissioner of Income Tax v Kelvinator of India Ltd
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2002 256 ITR 1 had opined that the amendments introduced into Section 147 with effect from 1 4 1989 have not altered the position that a mere change of opinion of the AO was not sufficient ground for embarking on a reassessment
label: ANALYSIS

text: Calcutta Discount was duly considered and applied by the Full Bench
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Full Bench further observed that an order of assessment must be presumed to have been passed by the AO concerned after due and proper application of mind
label: ANALYSIS

text: In these circumstances the decision of the Division Bench in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax inasmuch as it is irreconcilable with the views of the Full Bench must be held not to lay down the correct law
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is especially so since the assessment proceedings had not come to an end under the first sub section of Section 143 but under the third Sub section
label: ANALYSIS

text: A Division Bench of a particular High Court is fully bound by the view preferred by a larger Bench of that Court regardless of the fact that another High Court prefers a different view in this case that of the Gujarat High Court as in Gruh Finance Ltd v Joint Commissioner of Income Tax Assessment Praful Chunilal Patel v M J Makwana Assistant CIT and Garden Silk Mills Ltd v Deputy CIT No 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Full Bench of this Court has taken into consideration both Praful Chunilal Patel as well as Garden Silk Mills
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Kelvinator the Full Bench had also analysed the earlier Division Bench decisions namely Jindal Photo Films Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax presided over by R C Lahoti J as learned Chief Justice of India then was and Bawa Abhai Singh v Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax 2002 253 ITR 83 comprising Arijit Pasayat and D K Jain JJ as their Lordships then were
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is quite possible that had the Court in Consolidated Photo been made aware of the consistent opinion of this Court in Jindal Photo and Bawa Abhai Singh their conclusion may have been totally different notwithstanding alternative view of the Gujarat High Court 18
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no manner of doubt that the decision of the DB of this Court in Consolidated Photo and Finvest Ltd v Assistant Commissioner of Income Tax supra is no longer good law
label: ANALYSIS

text: The main plank of the Revenue s case before this Court therefore fails
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nevertheless the Court proceeds to examine the question of validity of the reopening of the assessments for the AYs in question
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19 The fact of the matter is that during the course of the original assessments under Section 143 3 the AO did serve upon the Assessee a detailed questionnaire
label: ANALYSIS

text: The AO examined the nature of the transactions involving the Assessee and the payments received therefor
label: ANALYSIS

text: The reopening was not based on any fresh material
label: ANALYSIS

text: By revisiting the same materials the successor AO now concluded that the payments received by the Assessee pursuant to the O M Agreements should be treated as FTS
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the circumstances the view taken by a successor AO on the same material was indeed nothing but a mere change of opinion
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is a well settled legal proposition as explained in Calcutta Discount Co Ltd v ITO 1961 41 ITR 191 SC that once an Assessee has discharged the burden of not only producing the account books and other documents but also the specific material relevant to the assessment it is for the Income tax Officer to draw the proper inferences of fact and law therefrom and the Assessee cannot further be called upon to do so for him
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Indian Oil Corporation v ITO 1986 159 ITR 956
label: ANALYSIS

text: the Court pertinently observed it is for the taxing authority to draw inference
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not necessary for the Assessee to draw inference
label: ANALYSIS

text: These observations apply on all fours to the case on hand
label: RATIO

text: Here the Assessee had discharged its burden of disclosing fully and truly all the material facts before the AO during the original assessments
label: RATIO

text: There was no basis for the successor AO to conclude that no opinion with regard to taxation of the payments received for the services rendered had been formed by the AO
label: RATIO

text: It is plain that the pre condition for invoking Section 147 did not exist
label: RATIO

text: The assumption of jurisdiction under Section 148 of the Act was not valid
label: RATIO

text: 20 Consequently the question framed by this Court on the above aspect is answered in the affirmative i e in favor of the Assesse and against the Revenue
label: RPC

text: The appeals are dismissed but with no order as to costs
label: RPC

text: S MURALIDHAR J CHANDER SHEKHAR J MAY 18 2017 tp
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER NIMEON SANGMA ORS Vs RESPONDENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: HOME SECRETARY GOVT OF MEGHALAYA ORS
label: PREAMBLE

text: DATE OF JUDGMENT30 04 1979
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH KRISHNAIYER V R BENCH KRISHNAIYER V R PATHAK R S KOSHAL A D CITATION 1979 SCR 3 785 1979 AIR 1518 1979 SCC 1 700 ACT of Justice Pre trial detention Administration of cases including investigations and 209 309 of Criminal Procedure Code Expeditious disposal trials Sections 167 1973 HEADNOTE In their petition for the issue of a writ of habeas corpus the petitioners alleged illegal detention of a large number of persons under guise of the judicial process HELD 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: Criminal Justice breaks down at a point when expeditious trial is not attempted while the affected parties are languishing in jail The Criminal Procedure Code in Sections 167 209 and 309 has emphasised the importance of expeditious disposal of cases including investigations and trials
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 The State Government to take a policy decision with a view to ensure that accused persons too indigent to set in motion the judicial process do not suffer incarceration silently
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Government will do well to comply with the spirit of the Code of Criminal Procedure especially in the matter of persons sought to be bound over for good behaviour persons against whom summons cases are pending and persons who have been in custody for more than six months
label: PREAMBLE

text: This will involve a mass release from jails but Government has to pay homage in substance and reality to the provisions of the Constitution and the Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: 787C The Court directed that a The State do consent to release all persons who have been in custody for over six months and whose trials have not commenced or against whom charge sheets have not
label: PREAMBLE

text: been laid
label: PREAMBLE

text: excepting in those cases under Sections 302 and 395 I P C
label: PREAMBLE

text: 786G b The State shall complete investigation within two months in cases where charge sheets have not been laid
label: PREAMBLE

text: 786H c The Sessions Court concerned should dispose of the cases where chargesheets have been laid and commitment has been made within six months
label: PREAMBLE

text: 786H JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No 211 of 1979 K Hingorani for the Petitioners
label: NONE

text: D N Mukherjee for the Respondents
label: NONE

text: The Order of the Court was delivered by KRISHNA IYER J
label: NONE

text: This is a petition for the issuance of a writ of habeas corpus in view of alleged illegal detention of a large number of persons under guise of the judicial process
label: FAC

text: Even without going into details we are satisfied that petitioners Nos 3 and 4 should be released on their own bonds to the satisfaction of the trial court subject to their reporting to the nearest police station once every fortnight and appearing in court whenever called upon to do so to take their trial
label: ANALYSIS

text: We direct accordingly
label: ANALYSIS

text: So far as petitioner No 1 is concerned the State in its affidavit swear that there is no such person in custody in connection with any case
label: ANALYSIS

text: This matter will be scrutinised further by the State so that it may satisfy itself that no one is in custody except under due process of law
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Court in its earlier order dated March 5 1979 has directed the State to file a statement containing particulars of the under trial prisoners who have been confined in Jail for a period of over six months without their trials having commenced
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further details as to the ages of such under trials the dates from which they were confined and the offences with which they were charged were also called for
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the reply statement put in by the respondent we find a large number of cases where detention for considerable periods without the trial having even commenced is being suffered by various persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: Criminal justice breaks down at a point when expeditious trial is not attempted while the affected parties are languishing in jail
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Criminal Procedure Code in sections 167 209 and 309 has emphasised the importance of expeditious disposal of cases including investigations and trials
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is unfortunate indeed pathetic that there should have been such considerable delay in investigations by the police in utter disregard of the fact that a citizen has been deprived of his freedom on the ground that he is accused of an offence
label: ANALYSIS

text: We do not approve of this course and breach of the rule of law and express our strong displeasure at this chaotic state of affairs verging on wholesale breach of human rights guaranteed under the Constitution especially under Article 21 as interpreted by this Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even so we do not wish to pass any orders at the moment until more particulars are brought to our notice
label: ANALYSIS

text: It will suffice for the present and counsel for the State assures us that any direction given by this Court will be promptly complied with that we direct the State to consent to release all persons who have been in custody for over six months and whose trials have not commenced or against whom charge sheets have not been laid
label: RPC

text: But make one exception in cases where sections 302 and 395 IPC are involved
label: RPC

text: We direct that the State shall complete the investigation within two months from today where charge sheets have not been laid and further direct the Sessions Court concerned to dispose of the cases where charge sheets have been laid and commitment has been made within six months from today
label: RPC

text: A report will be made to this Court at the end of six months from today by the State
label: RPC

text: We must emphatically record our view that there has been a self condemnation in the statement put in by the State Government in that in quite a number of cases which are not of a serious character and even in those which involve serious offences investigations have been pending for nearly two years
label: RATIO

text: There are cases where persons have been in custody for five years a situation too ghastly for a civilised country like ours
label: RATIO

text: We therefore draw the attention of the State Government to take a policy decision with a view to ensure that accused persons too indigent to set in motion the judicial process do not suffer incarceration silently
label: RATIO

text: The Government will do well to comply with the spirit of the Code of Criminal Procedure especially in the matter of persons sought to be bound over for good behaviour persons against whom summons cases are pending and persons who have been in custody for more than six months
label: RATIO

text: Maybe this will involve a mass release from Jails but Government has to pay homage in substance and reality to the provisions of the Constitution and the Code
label: RATIO

text: With these observations and directions we dispose of this petition
label: RPC

text: N V K Petition disposed
label: NONE

text: Through

text: Ms Prem Lata Bansal Senior Advocate
label: PREAMBLE

text: with Ms Nidhi Raman and Ms Isha Khanna Advocates along with Mr Ashok Kumar Accounts Officer DBTB versus DIRECTOR OF INCOME TAX E Respondent Through
label: PREAMBLE

text: Mr Rahul Kaushik Senior standing

text: counsel With 34 ITA 811 2015 CM 24170 2015 DELHI BUREAU OF TEXT

text: BOOKS Appellant Through
