label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 P W 6Dipak Gotmare has stated in his evidence that he had received information that Asha Hemant Chauriwal had set herself on fire
label: ANALYSIS

text: The circumstances involving recording of dying declaration and the dying declaration itself will have to be examined in the light of this statement of the Police Officer who had received information of the incident which was first in time
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14 P W 1Pushpalata the Executive Magistrate has stated that she had received the memo from the police for recording dying declaration and she had visited Ward No 26 of Government Hospital
label: ANALYSIS

text: She had recorded statement of the deceased Asha Hemant Chauriwal
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to this witness the Medical Officer had certified that the deceased was in a fit condition to make a statement
label: ANALYSIS

text: The memo received by this witness is produced at Exh 59
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Medical Officer who had examined the deceased has been examined as P W 5
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 5Dr
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sarika Naik has stated that at the request of P W 1Pushpalata she had examined the deceased and had certified that the deceased was mentally competent to give her dying declaration
label: ANALYSIS

text: The memo received by P W 1Pushpalata is at Exh 59 and the certificate given by the Medical Officer is at Exh 96
label: ANALYSIS

text: In her statement which was reduced to writing by P W 1Pushpalata the deceased had stated before P W 1 that she was being tortured at her matrimonial home and they had been constantly demanding money from her
label: ANALYSIS

text: The deceased had also stated that on 20th June 2004 she was set on fire by her husband
label: ANALYSIS

text: She also wanted her husband to be punished for the offence committed by him
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this regard it is necessary to be stated here that the officer of Yavatmal Police who had issued request letter to P W 1Pushpalata for recording statement of the deceased has not been examined
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution has also not examined the Police Constable who had carried request letter to P W 1 Pushpalata
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also not clear from the evidence of P W 1Pushpalata as to who had collected the dying declaration recorded by her at Exh 60
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no evidence at what time the dying declaration was collected from P W 1 Pushpalata and in whose custody it was lying before it reached Ghatanji Police Station where a First Information Report was registered on the basis of the dying declaration carried by P W 2Prakash
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact it was the duty of the learned trial Court to examine whether the statement made by the deceased was voluntary and true
label: ANALYSIS

text: The learned trial Court should have borne in mind that dying declaration has to be judged and appreciated in light of the surrounding circumstances
label: ANALYSIS

text: 15 In a latest judgment reported at 2012 3 SCALE 438 MANU SC 0212 2012 in the matter of Bhajju Karan Singh Vs State of Madhya Pradesh the Hon ble Supreme Court at Para No 12 has stated as under 12
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The law is wellsettled that a dying declaration is admissible in evidence and the admissibility is founded on the principle of necessity
label: PRE_RELIED

text: A dying declaration if found reliable can form the basis of a conviction
label: PRE_RELIED

text: A Court of facts is not excluded from acting upon an uncorroborated dying declaration for finding conviction
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The dying declaration as a piece of evidence stands on the same footing as any other piece of evidence
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It has to be judged and appreciated in light of the surrounding circumstances and its weight determined by reference to the principle governing the weighing of evidence
label: PRE_RELIED

text: If in a given case a particular dying declaration suffers from any infirmity either of its own or as disclosed by the other evidence adduced in the case or the circumstances coming to its notice the Court may as a rule of prudence look for corroboration and if the infirmities are such as would render a dying declaration so infirm that it pricks the conscience of the Court the same may be refused to be accepted as forming basis of the conviction
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It is thus clear that the dying declaration can be basis for conviction without there being any corroboration
label: ANALYSIS

text: However it is necessary that it must enjoy full confidence of the Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: To determine whether it enjoys full confidence of the Court or not it is necessary to judge the dying declaration like any other piece of evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Hon ble Supreme Court has said that it is to be judged and appreciated in light of the surrounding circumstances and its weight determined by reference to the principle governing the weighing of evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: 16 The Hon ble Supreme Court in the matter of Sharda Vs State of Rajasthan reported at AIR 2010 SC 408 has said at Para 34 as under 34
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Though a dying declaration is entitled and is still recognized by law to be given greater weightage but it has also to be kept in mind that accused had no chance of cross examination
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Such a right of crossexamination is essential for eliciting the truth as an obligation of oath
label: PRE_RELIED

text: This is the reason generally the court insists that the dying declaration should be such which inspires full confidence of the court of its correctness
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The court has to be on guard that such statement of deceased was not as a result of either tutoring prompting or product of imagination
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The court must be further satisfied that deceased was in a fit state of mind after a clear opportunity to observe and identify the assailants
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Once the court is satisfied that the aforesaid requirement and also to the fact that declaration was true and voluntary undoubtedly it can base its conviction without any further corroboration
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It is not an absolute rule of law that the dying declaration cannot be form the sole basis of conviction unless it is corroborated
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The rule requiring corroboration is merely a rule of prudence 17
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In the present case the prosecution has not given any explanation as to why did they fail to examine the Police Officer who had issued request letter to the Executive Magistrate for recording dying declaration and at the same time why the Police Constable who had carried the request letter has also not been examined
label: ANALYSIS

text: Non examination of these two witnesses by itself would not have been fatal to the prosecution case had the other circumstances inspired confidence in our mind
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is stated by P W 1Pushpalata in her examinationinchief that relatives of the deceased were present in Burn Ward and she had requested a constable to ask all the relatives to withdraw themselves from the Burn Ward
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has also come in the evidence of P W 3Devidas and P W 4Chandrakala that they had reached hospital before arrival of the Executive Magistrate
label: ANALYSIS

text: The presence of relatives by itself also is no reason to come to the conclusion that the person giving the statement was tutored
label: ANALYSIS

text: At the same time it is to be borne in mind that primarily it is the duty of the prosecution to prove its case beyond all reasonable doubts
label: ANALYSIS

text: The court is not only under obligation to examine the dying declaration but it is also under obligation to examine the circumstances in which the dying declaration was recorded
label: ANALYSIS

text: 18 In the present case Police Officer P W 6Dipak Gotmare has stated that he received information that deceased Asha Hemant Chauriwal had set herself on fire and he had reached the spot for drawing spot panchanama
label: ANALYSIS

text: The contents of dying declaration are contrary to the information received by police which was first in time
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution has not been able to rule out the possibility of creating a false dying declaration at the instance of the relatives
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are fortified our view due to certain facts stated by P W 6 in his crossexamination
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 6Dipak Gotmare Investigating Officer has stated in the crossexamination that he had not seized burnt pieces of clothes from the spot of occurrence as those were not found there
label: ANALYSIS

text: He had also not collected sample of soil from the spot of occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: He did not find burnt pieces of clothes any where in the house
label: ANALYSIS

text: As such we had requested the learned Additional Public Prosecutor to let us know from the evidence as to exactly where the incident had occurred
label: ANALYSIS

text: After having gone through the evidence and the crime report including panchanama the learned Additional Public Prosecutor has not been able to tell us as to what was the location where the deceased had sustained burn injuries
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19 The appellants and accused had given explanation in their statements under Section 313 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which appears to be probable
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is explained by the appellants and the other accused that the deceased had set herself on fire and had committed suicide
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is worth mentioning that P W 2Prakash who was working as Head Constable at Yavatmal Police Headquarters has stated that he was posted at City Police Station Yavatmal
label: ANALYSIS

text: He had carried dying declaration of the deceased to Ghatanji Police Station on 21st June 2004
label: ANALYSIS

text: He had lodged his report which was recorded as First Information Report Exh 78 at Ghatanji Police Station
label: ANALYSIS

text: The statement of the deceased was recorded at about 5 45 p m on 20th June 2004 at Yavatmal
label: ANALYSIS

text: The statement of the deceased was a statement within the meaning of Section 157 of the Evidence Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was not a confidential document
label: ANALYSIS

text: An offence could have been registered at Yavatmal Police Station by giving No 00 2004
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact it is the practice in Maharashtra that whenever the First Information Report of cognizable offence is received by the Police Station with regard to the offence which had not occurred within the jurisdiction of the said police station the First Information Report is recorded under 00 number of the particular year
label: ANALYSIS

text: The said First Information Report is later on transferred to the police Station having jurisdiction over the place of offence
label: ANALYSIS

text: As such there are a lot of mysterious circumstances which have remained unexplained
label: ANALYSIS

text: These unexplained circumstances create a reasonable doubt in our mind as to the correctness of the dying declaration
label: ANALYSIS

text: It need not be stated here that it is the duty of the Court to examine whether the dying declaration was voluntary and true
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the present case we doubt as to whether the statement reduced to writing by P W 1Pushpalata produced at Exh 60 was statement of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: 20 The evidence of parents of the deceased does not help in any manner as far as charge under Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code is concerned
label: ANALYSIS

text: The conviction recorded against appellant No 1 was purely based on the dying declaration of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of our finding that there are many mysterious circumstances which have remained unexplained and that the dying declaration of the deceased reduced to writing by P W 1 Pushpalata does not appear to be genuine dying declaration we are of the view that appellant No 1 should have been acquitted of the offence punishable under Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21 As far as charge under Section 498A read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code is concerned the conviction is mainly based on the letters produced by the parents of the deceased before the Investigating Officer
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 3Devidas has stated in his evidence that he had handed over letters received from the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has identified signature of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 6Dipak Gotmare the Investigating Officer in his evidence has stated that he had seized letters under the panchanama Exh 63
label: ANALYSIS

text: The letters seized under the said panchanama were exhibited at Exhs 82 to 90
label: ANALYSIS

text: However there is no further investigation with regard to the letters
label: ANALYSIS

text: The admitted signatures of the deceased were not collected and opinion of the expert was not sought by the Investigating Officer
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even there does not appear to be attempt on the part of Investigating Officer to verify the genuineness of the letters
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the circumstances in our opinion the conviction recorded by the learned Additional Sessions Judge for the offence punishable under Section 498A read with Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code is also not sustainable
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though the Investigating Officer has stated in his evidence that he made efforts to collect natural handwriting of the deceased but he could not do so he has not explained as to what steps he had taken to get natural handwriting of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: 22 As such the learned trial Court should not have based conviction of the appellants for the offence punishable under Section 498A read with Section 34 of the Indian penal Code only on the basis of the letters produced by father of the deceased which according to him were written to him by his daughter
label: ANALYSIS

text: The learned trial Court should have asked for better evidence or at least proof of the fact that the letters were in handwriting of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: The investigation in our opinion was carried out very shabbily
label: ANALYSIS

text: Either there was sabotage or a false case has been prepared under the pressure of parents of the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are aware that the mistake on the part of the Investigating Officer should not by itself be a ground for acquittal
label: ANALYSIS

text: If the acceptable evidence is sufficient to record conviction the mistakes committed by the Investigating Officer should not come in the way of convicting the accused of the offence proved against him
label: ANALYSIS

text: However in the present case the mistakes committed by the Investigating Officer deliberately or negligently have adversely affected the prosecution case to such an extent that we find it highly risky to sustain the conviction recorded by the learned trial Judge against the appellants
label: RATIO

text: We have come to the conclusion that the judgment is not sustainable and it needs to be set aside
label: RATIO

text: Both the appeals deserve to be allowed
label: RPC

text: Hence we pass the following order
label: RPC

text: i These criminal appeals are allowed and the conviction and sentence of the appellants is hereby quashed and set aside and the appellants are acquitted of the offences with which they were charged and convicted
label: RPC

text: ii Fine if paid by the appellants be refunded to them
label: RPC

text: iii Since the appellant Hemant Kawadu Chauriwal in Criminal Appeal No 53 of 2007 is in Jail he be released forthwith if not required in any other offence
label: RPC

text: iv Bailbonds of the appellant Sau Vachhalla Kawadu Chauriwal stand cancelled
label: RPC

text: JUDGE JUDGE
label: NONE

text: IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT BOMBAY NAGPUR BENCH NAGPUR Writ Petition No 5768 of 2016 Ruchi w o Bhanupratapsingh Gour Petitioner Aged about 32 years Occ Household r o C o Arunkumar Kiledar Sadar Bazar Baitul MP 460 001 Versus Bhanupratapsingh Gour s o Sureshsingh Gour Respondent Aged about 37 years Occ Business R o B 2B Corporation Colony North Ambazari Road Nagpur 440 033 Mrs Jyoti Dharmadhikari Counsel for petitioner Mr Sudhir T Dhurway Counsel for respondent Coram Manish Pitale J Dated 29th January 2019 ORLA JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: Rule
label: NONE

text: Rule returnable forthwith by consent of learned Counsel appearing for the parties
label: NONE

text: By this Writ Petition the petitioner has challenged order dated 27072016 passed by the Family Court Nagpur whereby an application Exhibit44 filed on behalf of the petitioner for permission to file counterclaim and for claiming reliefs under the provisions of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act 2005 for short Act of 2005
label: FAC

text: was rejected
label: FAC

text: 3 The petitioner and respondent were married on 20042007 at Baitul
label: FAC

text: On 13052014 the respondent husband filed a petition for grant of divorce against the petitioner wife before the Family Court
label: FAC

text: During the pendency of the said petition on 27012015 the respondent filed an application for restraining the petitioner from doing any unlawful act and from entering the house of the respondent
label: FAC

text: On 11012016 the respondent filed reply to the said application and she also filed written statement to the petition for divorce filed by the respondent
label: FAC

text: The said application filed on behalf of the respondent was directed to be decided along with the main petition for divorce filed by the respondent
label: FAC

text: 4 According to the petitioner during the pendency of the said petition and the application filed by the respondent on 01042016 she was illegally prevented from entering the matrimonial house and that gave rise to cause of action for her to claim Restitution of Conjugal Rights and to claim certain reliefs under the Act of 2005 5 Accordingly on 14062016 the petitioner filed an application for permission to file counterclaim for restitution of conjugal rights and for reliefs under the provisions of the Act of 2005 claiming that she had been thrown out of the matrimonial house from 01042016 onwards
label: FAC

text: This application was opposed by the respondent
label: FAC

text: 6 By the impugned order dated 27072016 the Family Court has rejected the application filed by the petitioner on the ground that under Order VIII Rule 6A of the Code of Civil Procedure 1908 CPC the petitioner ought to have raised her counterclaim either along with the written statement or within the period of limitation prescribed for raising her defence in response to the petition of divorce filed by the respondent
label: RLC

text: It was found by the Family Court that since the written statement was already filed by the petitioner and the limitation for filing counterclaim under Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC had expired she could not raise any claim towards Restitution of Conjugal Rights as sought by her
label: RLC

text: As regards the relief sought to be claimed by the petitioner in the pending proceeding it was observed by the Family Court that under Section 26 of the Act of 2005 the petitioner could do so
label: RLC

text: But since the Family Court found that the right to raise a counterclaim by the petitioner was barred by limitation the entire application was rejected
label: RLC

text: 7 Mrs Jyoti Dharmadhikari learned Counsel appearing for the petitioner submitted that the impugned order passed by the Family Court was unsustainable because on application of Section 23A of the Hindu Marriage Act 1955 for short Act of 1955 read with Section 21 thereof it was evident that the limitation prescribed under Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC for raising counterclaim would not apply in the present proceedings before the Family Court initiated by the respondent under the provisions of the Act of 1955
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It was submitted that Section 21 of the Act of 1955 clearly states that subject to other provisions of the Act of 1955 all proceedings under the said Act would be regulated as far as may be by the CPC
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It was submitted that since Section 23A of the Act of 1955 specifically provided for right to raise a counterclaim and no limitation was prescribed for the same the Family Court could not have rejected the application filed on behalf of the petitioner
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Reliance was placed on judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in the case of Sameeran Roy vs Smt Leena Roy reported at AIR 2001 MP 192 8
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: On the other hand Mr Sudhir Dhurway learned Counsel appearing for the respondent submitted that the Family Court was justified in rejecting the application of the petitioner because the counterclaim if any ought to have been raised along with written statement or within the limitation as prescribed under Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It was sought to be argued that the reliefs claimed by the petitioner under the provisions of the Act of 2005 could not have been entertained by the Family Court and that such reliefs ought to have been claimed before the Criminal Courts
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: On this basis it was submitted that the Writ Petition deserves to be dismissed
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Heard Counsel for the parties and perused the record
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only question that arises for consideration in this Writ Petition is as to whether the Family Court was justified in relying upon Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC to hold that the petitioner was not entitled to raise a counterclaim after having filed the written statement and upon expiry of period of limitation prescribed under Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC
label: ANALYSIS

text: The findings rendered by the Family Court can be upset only if it is found that the CPC would be applicable to the right of the petitioner to submit a counterclaim in the proceedings for divorce filed by the respondent before the Family Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this regard the following provisions of the Act of 1955 are relevant 21 Application of Act 5 of 1908
label: STA

text: Subject to the other provisions contained in this Act and to such rules as the High Court may make in this behalf all proceedings under this Act shall be regulated as far as may be by the Code of Civil Procedure 1908 23A Relief for respondent in divorce and other proceedings
label: STA

text: In any proceedings for divorce or judicial separation or restitution of conjugal rights the respondent may not only oppose the relief sought on the ground of petitioner s adultery cruelty or desertion but also make a counterclaim for any relief under this Act on the ground and if the petitioner s adultery cruelty or desertion is proved the Court may give to the respondent any relief if he or she had presented a petition seeking such relief on that ground 10 A perusal of the above quoted Section 23A of the Act of 1955 that any proceedings for divorce initiated by a party the respondent would be entitled to raise a counterclaim and it would have to be treated as if the respondent had filed a petition seeking such relief
label: STA

text: There is no period of limitation or any other rider mentioned in the said Section 23A of the Act of 1955 as provided under Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC
label: ANALYSIS

text: Section 21 of the Act of 1955 quoted above shows that the CPC would be applicable to the proceedings initiated under the said Act subject to other provisions contained therein
label: ANALYSIS

text: A conjoint reading of the aforesaid Section 21 and Section 23A of the Act of 1955 shows that the respondent in a proceeding initiated under the Act of 1955 would have a right to raise a counterclaim without being subjected to the specific fetters contained in Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is because to the extent of applicability of Section 23A of the Act of 1955 the provisions of Order VIII Rule 6A of the CPC would not be applicable
label: ANALYSIS

text: This clearly shows that the Family Court erred while passing the impugned order and holding that the application for raising counterclaim filed on behalf of the petitioner could not be entertained
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 In the judgment in the case of Sameeran Roy vs Smt Leena Roy supra relied upon by the learned Counsel appearing for the petitioner in a similar situation Madhya Pradesh High Court has held as follows 8
label: PRE_RELIED

text: At this juncture I may profitably refer to Section 21 of the Act
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It reads as under 21 Application of Act 5 of 1908
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Subject to the other provisions contained in this Act and to such rules as the High Court may make in this behalf all proceedings under this Act shall be regulated as far as may be by the Code of Civil Procedure 1908
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The aforesaid provision makes it luminously clear that the proceeding under the Act shall be regulated as far as may be the Code of Civil Procedure 1908
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus this section clearly indicates that to an application under Section 13 of the Act the Code of Civil Procedure does not automatically apply
label: ANALYSIS

text: The applicability of Code of Civil Procedure has been hedged by two conditions namely subject to other provisions of the Act and subject to the Rules framed by the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: That apart the terms as far as may be have also to be given its due prominence
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus it is apparent that if any provision is in existence under the Act it would oust the application of the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this context Section 23A of the Act assumes significance
label: ANALYSIS

text: The provision reads as under 23A Relief for respondent in divorce and other proceedings
label: STA

text: In any proceedings for divorce or judicial separation or restitution of conjugal rights the respondent may not only oppose the relief sought on the ground of petitioner s adultery cruelty or desertion but also make a counterclaim for any relief under this Act on the ground and if the petitioner s adultery cruelty or desertion is proved the Court may give to the respondent any relief if he or she had presented a petition seeking such relief on that ground
label: STA

text: On a fair reading of the aforesaid provision it is graphically clear that a special provision of this nature provides for counterclaim in respect of a divorce petition
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus provision of Order 8 Rule 6A of the Code shall not be applicable in view of the provisions enshrined under Section 23A of the Act 12 This Court respectfully agrees with the reasonings given by the Madhya Pradesh High Court in the aforesaid judgment
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 Insofar as the question as to whether the petitioner could claim reliefs under the Act of 2005 before the Family Court by raising a counterclaim the learned Counsel appearing for the petitioner is justified in relying on Section 26 of the Act of 2005 wherein it is made clear that in a legal proceeding initiated before the Family Court any relief available under Sections 18 19 20 21 and 22 of the Act of 2005 can be claimed by an aggrieved person
label: RATIO

text: Therefore there is no substance in the contention raised on behalf of the respondent that the petitioner could have claimed reliefs under the provisions of the Act of 2005 only before the Criminal Courts and not before the Family Court where divorce petition is already pending
label: RATIO

text: 14 In view of the above the Writ Petition is allowed
label: RPC

text: The impugned order passed by the Family Court is quashed and set aside and the application filed on behalf of the petitioner is allowed in terms of prayers made therein
label: RPC

text: 15 Rule is made absolute in above terms
label: RPC

text: JUDGE Deshmukh
label: NONE

text: 1 R
label: PREAMBLE

text: IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 19TH DAY OF NOVEMBER 2015
label: PREAMBLE

text: PRESENT THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE VINEET SARAN AND
label: PREAMBLE

text: THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE MOHAN M SHANTANAGOUDAR S T R P NOS 216 2015 242 252 2015
label: PREAMBLE

text: BETWEEN M s Nandi Constructions
label: PREAMBLE

text: TIN 29370707569 125 3rd Main Jayalakshmipuram
label: PREAMBLE

text: Mysuru 570012
label: PREAMBLE

text: by its proprietor T N Hemanth 53 years
label: PREAMBLE

text: Petitioner By Sri T N Keshavamurthy Adv
label: PREAMBLE

text: AND The State of Karnataka
label: PREAMBLE

text: Represented by The Commissioner of Commercial Taxes Gandhinagar Bengaluru 560009
label: PREAMBLE

text: Respondent By Sri K M Shivayogiswamy AGA
label: PREAMBLE

text: These petitions are filed under Section 65 1 of Karnataka Value Added Tax Act 2003 against the judgment and order dated 16 01 2015 passed in STA Nos 660 to 663 2014 and STA Nos 664 to 671 2014 on the file of the Karnataka Appellate Tribunal at Bangalore
label: PREAMBLE

text: These petitions coming on for admission this day VINEET SARAN J made the following O R D E R
label: PREAMBLE

text: These revision petitions are filed by the assessee challenging the order of the Tribunal dated 16 1 2015 whereby the appeals of the assessee have been dismissed
label: FAC

text: 2 The brief facts of this case are that the assessee is a builder and civil works contractor carrying on the business of construction and sale of apartments
label: FAC

text: For the relevant tax periods the assessee had sold some apartments for which it had disclosed the sale consideration out of which the cost of the land was disclosed in the returns at 45 and consequently paid tax on the sale consideration minus the land cost
label: FAC

text: The assessing authority did not accept the land cost at 45 but instead assessed it at 40 and assessed the tax
label: FAC

text: The assessee challenged the assessment order by filing the appeals where it claimed the land cost to be 50 of the sale consideration instead of 45 as had been claimed in the returns
label: FAC

text: 3 The appellate authority considered the matter on merits and though on facts it came to the conclusion that the land cost was over 50 but as the claim made in the returns filed by the assessee was for only 45 of the sale consideration the land cost for the purpose of calculation of tax was taken at 45 only
label: FAC

text: While passing the said order the first appellate authority relied on a decision of the Division Bench of this Court rendered in the case of Infinite Builders and Developers Bangalore vs The Additional Commissioner of Commercial Taxes Zone II Bangalore reported in 2013 76 Kar L J 390
label: FAC

text: Challenging the said order the assessee filed appeals before the Tribunal claiming the land cost be allowed at 50 of the sale consideration
label: FAC

text: The appeals have been dismissed by a common reasoned order which is under challenge in these revision petitions
label: FAC

text: 4 We heard Sri T N Keshava Murthy learned advocate for the petitioner as well as Sri K M Shivayogiswamy learned Government Advocate appearing for the respondent and perused the records
label: NONE

text: 5 Although several questions of law are raised in these petitions learned counsel for the petitioner has today condensed the same and placed before us only two questions of law for determination by this Court which are as follows a Whether the appellate Tribunal is legally justified in holding that land cost at 50 that is not claimed in the returns cannot be considered in view of the decisions of this Court in the case of State of Karnataka vs Centum Industries Pvt Ltd and Infinite Builders Developers vs Additional CCT Zone II Bangalore
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: b Whether appellate Tribunal is legally justified in confirming the land cost allowed by the first appellate authority at 45 of the contract receipts even after noticing the finding of the first appellate authority that land cost as per registered sale deeds and the certificate of the Chartered Accountant worked out to 54 of the contract receipts merely for the reason that the same is not claimed in the returns filed
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 6 The main issue to be decided by this Court is as to whether the petitioner can be granted benefit over and above that what has been claimed in the returns filed by the assessee for the relevant tax periods
label: ISSUE

text: Admittedly the claim of the petitioner in its returns filed for the relevant tax periods was at 45 towards land cost
label: FAC

text: Though Assessing Officer allowed only 40 the first appellate authority granted the benefit of 45 towards land cost
label: FAC

text: The question now to be decided is whether unless a claim is made by the assessee in its return and without the same being revised or modified by filing a revised return any benefit beyond the benefit claimed in the return can be considered and allowed by the authorities
label: ISSUE

text: 7 In our view the answer would be a clear no
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Division Bench of this Court in the case of Infinite Builders and Developers Bangalore supra was considering a case where the first appellate authority had granted a benefit more than what was claimed by the assessee
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The same was denied by this Court with the following observations 43
label: ANALYSIS

text: The assessee never filed any revised return in respect of the period from April 2005 to March 2006 nor claimed any input credit return but on the other hand only filed nil tax liability return
label: ANALYSIS

text: The assessee persisted and did not file any revised return or anything at all even after inspection notice etc
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this view of the matter there was nothing at all before the Assessing Authority to provide any input tax deduction in favour of the assessee for the entire period from April 2005 to March 2006
label: ANALYSIS

text: So it is urged by the appellant assessee that even long after the expiry of the period in which the revised return could have been filed the fact remains that there is no response by filing any revised returns
label: ANALYSIS

text: In such a position we are of the view that the First Appellate Authority did go out of its duties and responsibilities and acted out of its jurisdiction to entertain a claim for deduction of input tax rebate in favour of the assessee by accepting some material purporting it to be based on the books of accounts and the purchase invoices etc and in granting reliefs to the assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: We find it is a case of the First Appellate Authority acting more loyal than the king even though a claim had not been put forth by the assessee through the returns the First Appellate Authority has ventured to allow the appeals and grant relief to the assessee contrary to statutory provisions 8
label: ANALYSIS

text: Similar view has been taken by another Division Bench of this Court in the case of State of Karnataka vs Centum Industries Private Limited Bangalore reported in 2014 80 Kar L J 65 9
label: PRE_RELIED

text: We have no reason to differ with the opinion of the two Division Benches
label: RATIO

text: Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the question in the aforesaid cases was regarding grant of input tax rebate as a deduction whereas in the present case according to the petitioner the claim is exclusion of land cost and as once the authority has accepted it to be higher than 50 no tax could be levied on such amount which was beyond 50 of the sale consideration
label: RATIO

text: We are unable to accept such submission made by the learned counsel for the petitioner as nothing more than what is claimed by the assessee in its return can be given by the authorities and if it is permitted then the assessing authority or the appellate authorities would be given unfettered powers to grant any such relief which may not even have been claimed by the assessee in its returns
label: RATIO

text: The Act provides for filing a revised return under Section 35 4 of the Karnataka Value Added Tax Act 2003
label: RATIO

text: If the assessee fails to avail the benefit of filing revised return then it is only the return which is filed which has to be considered by the assessing officer or other authorities and nothing more than what is claimed in the return that can be granted by the authorities in favour of the assessee
label: RATIO

text: For the foregoing reasons we answer the questions in favour of the revenue and against the assessee
label: RPC

text: Petitions are dismissed accordingly
label: RPC

text: No order as to costs
label: RPC

text: Sd JUDGE Sd JUDGE ck
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER P BHOOMA REDDY Vs RESPONDENT STATE OF MYSORE ORS
label: PREAMBLE

text: DATE OF JUDGMENT 05 12 1968 BENCH BACHAWAT R S
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH BACHAWAT R S SIKRI S M HEGDE K S CITATION 1969 AIR 655 1969 SCR 3 14 1969 SCC 1 68 CITATOR INFO RF 1972 SC2205 26 D 1984 SC1030 17 ACT Mysore Excise Disposal of Privileges of Retail Vend of Liquors Rules 1967 rr 12 17 2 4 and 19 1 3 and 4 Liquor shops in more than one tehsil Whether r 19 1 3 and 4 applicable At once meaning of Whether Divisional Commissioner can revise his own order R 12 Scope of R 17 4 scope of When next highest bid can be accepted HEADNOTE The appellant was the highest bidder for the exclusive privilege of retail vend of toddy and arrack for the year 1968 69 in a group of 1168 shops situated in 19 tehsils in the districts of Raichur and Gulbarga
label: PREAMBLE

text: He made the deposits of money required under rr 7 f and 10 of the Mysore Excise Disposal of Privileges of Retail Vend of Liquors Rules 1967 made under s 71 of the Mysore Excise Act 1965
label: PREAMBLE

text: The highest bid of the appellant was accepted and confirmed by the Divisional Commissioner of Gulbarga under r 17 1 on June 4 1968
label: PREAMBLE

text: Thereafter the appellant made further deposits required by rr 17 5 and 19 2
label: PREAMBLE

text: In all he deposited about Rs 40 lakhs by June 15
label: PREAMBLE

text: On June 18 he applied to the Divisional Commissioner for the issue licence
label: PREAMBLE

text: He however did not comply with r 19 1 and 3 which required that a statement of immovable Properties should be furnished and that he should furnish security or sureties respectively
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Divisional Commissioner Gulbarga issued a notice to the appellant to show cause why the sale should not be cancelled and the deposits already made forfeited under r 20 2
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appellant prayed for two months time for compliance with the requirements of r 19 but the Divisional Commissioner rejected the application and cancelled the sale
label: PREAMBLE

text: He did not pass any order forfeiting the deposits
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court for quashing the order and under directions of the Court deposited another Rs 50 lakhs
label: PREAMBLE

text: The 4th respondent who was the next highest bidder applied to be made a party to the petition and contended that the appellant was a benamidar for other persons and so acceptance of his tender was forbidden by r 12
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court dismissed the writ petition holding 1 that the appellant did not comply with the mandatory requirements of r 19 in that he did not furnish the statements and apply at once for licences as required by r 19 1 2 the appellant was a benamidar and 3 the authorities should consider the advisability of accepting the bid of the 4th respondent
label: PREAMBLE

text: On the very next day after the judgment of the High Court the respondent State issued licences in respect of 1168 shops to the 4th respondent
label: PREAMBLE

text: In appeal to this Court
label: PREAMBLE

text: HELD
label: PREAMBLE

text: The licences issued to the 4th respondent should be cancelled and a writ of mandamus should issue for the grant of licences to the appellant
label: PREAMBLE

text: 26 A 1 a The opening part of r 19 4 requires the purchaser to furnish to the tehsildar the location of shops and the boundaries of the shop sites that is to the tahsildar within whose tehsil the shops are situated
label: PREAMBLE

text: If the shops are situated in more than one tehsil the details can be fur nished to the several tahsildars but in such a case it is not possible to give effect to the last part of the sub rule and also to the provisions of sub rr 3 and 4
label: PREAMBLE

text: The statement of immovable properties under the last part of sub r 1 can be furnished to only one tahsildar so that he can peruse the same and on such perusal or on independent inquiry ascertain under sub r 3 whether or not purchaser is of doubtful solvency and satisfy himself under sub r 4 whether or not the value of the immovable property tendered as security is adequate
label: PREAMBLE

text: Sub rr 3 and 4 do not contemplate findings by more than one tahsildar nor do they provide any machinery for resolving the conflict of opinion if any between two or more tahsildars
label: PREAMBLE

text: The last part of sub r 1 and sub rr 3 and 4 do not apply where the shops are situated in two or more tahsils
label: PREAMBLE

text: Consequently those provisions were not attracted to the sale in the present case and the appellant was not required to comply with those provisions
label: PREAMBLE

text: 22 E b In the absence of an independent enquiry under sub r 3 the appellant could not be regarded as a person of doubtful solvency
label: PREAMBLE

text: c Under the Mysore Excise Licences General Conditions Rules 1967 a licencee is required to commence his business on July 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: The expression at once in r 19 1 means within a reasonable time before July 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: In the present case the appellant sufficiently complied with subrule
label: PREAMBLE

text: 23 D E
label: PREAMBLE

text: d Under r 17 2 it is only the excise commissioner or the State Government that could revise the order of the divisional commissioner confirming a sale and the divisional commissioner himself was not authorised to revise his own order or cancel it
label: PREAMBLE

text: 23 G Therefore the High Court was in error in holding that the appellant committed breaches of r 19
label: PREAMBLE

text: Rule 19 is clumsily drafted its import is not clear its tight time schedule works hard ship and its procedure is cumbersome
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Government should immediately consider the question of redrafting the rule
label: PREAMBLE

text: 24 C D
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 The appellant was a retired inspector drawing a pension of about Rs 75 per month and is not an income tax or wealth tax assessee
label: PREAMBLE

text: He evidently has the backing of powerful financiers but the purchase is not illegal merely because the appellant obtained necessary funds from some financiers
label: PREAMBLE

text: The onus of proving that appellant was a benamidar was on the 4th respondent and from the materials on record it is not possible to hold that he is a benamidar for some other person
label: PREAMBLE

text: 25 D 3 Under r 17 4 it is only when the highest bid is rejected that the next highest bid may be considered
label: PREAMBLE

text: Where there is an acceptance of the highest offer and if for some reason it is revised r 17 4 cannot be invoked
label: PREAMBLE

text: In such a case there must be a fresh disposal of the right of retail vend of liquor in accordance with the Rules
label: PREAMBLE

text: Therefore the High Court erred in observing that the authorities should consider the advisability of accepting the 4th respondents bid
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil
label: NONE

text: Appeal No 2095 of
label: NONE

text: 1968 Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 17 1968 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No 1889 of 1968
label: NONE

text: D Narsaraju M C Chagla R V Pillai Subodh Markendya and M Narayana Reddy for the appellant
label: NONE

text: M C Setalvad B R L Iyengar and S P Nayar for respondents Nos 1 to 3 M K Nambyar Shivaswamy and R Gopalakrishnan for respondent No 4
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bachawat J
label: NONE

text: This appeal raises the question of the legality of the cancellation of the sale to the appellant of the exclusive privilege of retail vend of toddy and arrack for the year 1968 69 in a group of 1168 shops in Raichur and Gulbarga districts under the Mysore Excise Act 1965 and the Mysore Excise Disposal of Privileges of Retail Vend of Liquors Rules 1967
label: FAC

text: On May 10 1968 the excise commissioner of Mysore published a notice stating that the exclusive privilege would be sold by tender cum auction by the divisional commissioner Gulbarga on May 28 and inviting tenders by May 27
label: FAC

text: On May 27 the appellant made a tender offering Rs 9 99 999 towards the monthly rental of the shops and deposited the requisite earnest money amounting to Rs 1 85 168 as required by r 7 f
label: FAC

text: Respondent No 4 K V Niranjan made a tender offering Rs 9 69 999 towards the monthly rental
label: FAC

text: The appellant was the only bidder present at the auction on May 28
label: FAC

text: His offer being the highest was accepted by the divisional commissioner Gulbarga under r 17 1
label: FAC

text: The appellant deposited another sum of Rs 8 14 831 which together with the earnest money made up one month s rent as required by r 17 5
label: FAC

text: On June 4 the divisional commissioner Gulbarga confirmed the sale under r 17 1
label: FAC

text: On June 6 the deputy commissioner Gulbarga issued a notice asking the appellant to make deposits according to r 19 immediately and to obtain licences from the concerned tahsil officers after completing other formalities
label: FAC

text: Under r 19 2 the appellant was required to deposit another one month s rent within 15 days from the date of the sale
label: FAC

text: By June 15 the appellant deposited in all Rs 39 99 996 amounting to 4 months rent
label: FAC

text: By a letter Ex B 1 the appellant informed the excise commissioner that he had deposited 4 months rent as required by circular No EXE 1 15 7 5 issued by the excise commissioner on December 12 1967 and asked for permission to obtain licences from the deputy commissioners of Raichur and Gulbarga
label: FAC

text: On June 18 19 he applied to the divisional commissioner Gulbarga for the issue of licences
label: FAC

text: On June 19 the divisional commissioner issued anotice to the appellant stating that as he had not submitted a solvency certificate of his property or the property of his sureties he was required to deposit the balance to make up six months rent as required by r 19 3 i and to furnish security for six months rental or sureties as require by r 19 3 ii and iii by June 25 and that in default action would be taken under r 20 2
label: FAC

text: A notice to the same effect was given orally on June 19 when he met the divisional commissioner at Bellary
label: FAC

text: On June 22 he presented a petition under s 62 to the state government asking for the issue of licences as he had complied with the conditions of the circular
label: FAC

text: In view of the subsequent writ petition the government did not pass any orders on this petition
label: FAC

text: The notice dated June 19 was received by the appellant on June 23
label: FAC

text: On June 25 he wrote to the divisional commissioner stating that he had complied with the conditions of the rules read with the circular and was entitled to the licences that he had reason to believe that necessary orders would be passed by the state government on his petition under s 62 and that if necessary the terms for compliance with the requirements of r 19 be extended by two months
label: FAC

text: On the same date the divisional commissioner rejected the application for extension of time and issued a notice to the appellant asking him to show cause before June 26 why in view of the non compliance with the notices dated June 6 and 19 the sale should not be cancelled and the deposits already made should not be forfeited to the government
label: FAC

text: The notice was served on his advocate on June 25 at 7 40 p m
label: FAC

text: On June 26 the appellant submitted a petition to the divisional commissioner stating that he had complied with the terms of r 19 and the circular that abrupt cancellation of the sale would result in irreparable injury and that in any event the time to deposit the balance two months rental be extended for a reasonable time
label: FAC

text: By an order dated June 26 Ex J the divisional commissioner rejected the application for extension of time and cancelled the sale starting that 1 the appellant did not at one apply in writing for licences in accordance with r 19 1 2 though he deposited two months rent as required by r 19 2 he did not file a statement of his immovable properties in accordance with r 19 1 and should therefore be considered as a person of doubtful solvency 3 he was therefore required to deposit another 2 months rent under r 19 3 i and to furnish securities for six months rental or surety under r 1 9 3 ii and iii 4 he failed to comply with r 19 in spite of notices dated June 6 and June 19 5 the circular issued by the excise commissioner was opposed to r 19 and could not be acted upon 6 that even under the circular he was required to give two months collateral security in addition to 4 months cash deposit if he was a person of doubtful solvency and 7 that the sale conducting officer has no power to extend the time for compliance with the formalities
label: FAC

text: On June 28 the appellant filed writ petition No 1889 of 1968 against the State of Mysore and others in the High Court of Mysore for quashing the order dated June 26 Ex Jr and for the grant of licences to him to vend liquors in the combined groups of shops in Raichur and Gulbarga districts and for other reliefs
label: FAC

text: The appellant submitted that 1 he had complied with the rules read with the cir cular 2 he did not file any statement of his immovable properties under r 19 1 as he had immovable properties in Andhra Pradesh 3 as there was no inquiry nor finding by any tahsildar that he was of doubtful solvency r 19 3 was not attracted 4 the divisional commissioner Gulbarga was not competent to ask for deposits and security under r 19 3 nor was he competent to pass an order cancelling the sale and 5 r 19 3 was violative of Arts 14 and 19 of the Constitution
label: FAC

text: On June 28 the High Court admitted the writ petition and directed the state government to stay further proceedings and to issue licences to the appellant
label: RLC

text: Subsequently the High Court confirmed the stay order on condition that the appellant would deposit another two months rent
label: RLC

text: The appellant deposited about Rs 20 00 000 in accordance with the order
label: FAC

text: On June 30 the divisional commissioner granted licences to him
label: FAC

text: On July 1 he commenced his business in all the 1168 shops
label: FAC

text: Thereafter he duly deposited about Rs 30 00 000 on account of rent for the months of July August and September
label: FAC

text: The state government the excise commissioner and the divisional commissioner filed separate affidavits disputing the appellant s contentions
label: FAC

text: The rival tenderer K V Niranjan was added as respondent No 4 in W P No 1889 of 1968 on his own application under an order of the High Court dated July 7
label: FAC

text: K V Niranjan filed an affidavit stating that the appellant was a benamidar for other persons and the acceptance of his tender was forbidden by r 12
label: FAC

text: K V Niranjan also filed W P No 2088 of 1968 for quashing the orders of the divisional commissioner dated May 28 and June 4 whereby the appellant s tender was accepted and for a mandamus directing the acceptance of his next highest tender under r 17 4
label: FAC

text: The two writ petitions were heard together and were dismissed by the High Court by a common judgment delivered on September 17
label: FAC

text: The High Court held that 1 the appellant did not comply with the mandatory requirements of r 19 2 r 19 3 was not ultra vires the rule making power under s 71 nor violative of Arts 14 and 19 and the appellant was estopped from challenging it 3 the circular of the excise commissioner could not modify r 19 the appellant could not rely on the circular as he came to know of it long after the sale nor had he complied with its terms by depositing the entire four months rent beforeJune 12 4 the appellant was a benamidar for other person or persons and in view of r 12 was incompetent to bid and 5 the order dated June 26 Ex J was valid
label: RLC

text: On these findings the High Court dismissed W P No 1889 of 1968
label: RLC

text: With regard to W P No 2085 of 1968 the High Court said that as the sale to the appellant had been cancelled by Ex J it was not necessary to set aside the order accepting and confirming his bid
label: RLC

text: The High Court held that under r 17 4 it was not obligatory on the officer conducting the sale to accept the next highest offer of respondent No 4
label: RLC

text: The High Court however said in the circumstances of the case it is necessary to observe that the authorities concerned will consider the advisability of accepting the bid of the fourth respondent subject to his complying with all the requirements of the Act and the Rules
label: RLC

text: With these observations the High Court dismissed W P No 2085 of 1968
label: RLC

text: By a telegram dated September 18 the excise commissioner instructed the divisional commissioner Gulbarga to direct the tahsildars of Raichur and Gulbarga to issue licences to respondent No 4 on his complying with certain conditions
label: FAC

text: On the same date licences were issued to respondent No 4
label: FAC

text: On September 19 the High Court dismissed an application for stay of operation of its order dated September 17 and on the same day granted to the appellant a certificate under Art 1 3 3 1 b of the Constitution
label: RLC

text: On September 25 the appellant filed a stay application in this Court
label: FAC

text: On September 27 the Court passed an order restraining the respondents from forfeiting the deposits made by the appellant
label: FAC

text: It is convenient at this stage to refer to the relevant provisions of the Mysore Excise Act 1965 and the Mysore Excise Disposal of Privileges of Retail Vend of Liquors Rules 1967
label: ANALYSIS

text: Section 3 1 of the Act provides that the excise commissioner shall be the chief controlling authority in all matters connected with the administration of this Act
label: STA

text: Section 15 1 provides that no intoxicant shall be sold except under the authority and subject to the terms and conditions of a licence granted in that behalf
label: STA

text: Under S 15 2 a licence for sale can be granted a by the deputy commissioner if the sale is within a district or b by the excise commissioner if the sale is in more than one districts Section 17 1 b empowers the state government to lease to any person on such conditions and for such period as it thinks fit the exclusive or other right of selling by the wholesale or by retail any Indian liquors within any specified area
label: STA

text: Contravention of the Act or any Rules made thereunder is punishable under s 32 Section 71 empowers the state government to make rules
label: STA

text: Rule 3 of the Mysore Excise Disposal of Privileges of Retail Vend of Liquors Rules 1967 provides that the right of retail vend of liquors shallbe disposed of by tender or by auction or by tender cum auction
label: STA

text: The auction is conducted by the deputy commissioner or the divisional commissioner under r 5 and the tender has to be made to them under r 7 1
label: STA

text: The tenderer is required by r 7 f to deposit as earnest money an amount equal to 1 4 of the shop rental of the previous year of the shop or groups of shops
label: STA

text: The appellant complied with the requirement of r 7 f
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 10 requires an intending bidder or tenderer to furnish a certificate of his solvency or two sureties having similar certificates or bank guarantee or cash deposit to cover four times the earnest money fixed under rule 7 f
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not disputed that the appellant made sufficient cash deposits in compliance with r 10 Rule 12 read Benami bids not allowed
label: STA

text: No person except a power of attorney holder shall be entitled to bid for another person
label: STA

text: The sale to the appellant was not cancelled on the ground that he bid for another person
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 17 regulates the procedure at sales
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 17 1 empowers the officer conducting the auction to accept the highest offer
label: STA

text: The acceptance is subject to the condition of confirmation by the deputy commissioner or by the divisional commissioner
label: ANALYSIS

text: The confirmation is effective unless revised by the excise commissioner or the government
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 17 2 empowers the excise commissioner or the government to revise the order of confirmation
label: STA

text: Rule 17 4 provides that if the officer conducting the sale rejects the highest bid or offer he may either accept the next highest bid or offer or re sell the shop
label: STA

text: Rule 17 5 requires the person whose bid is accepted to make a further deposit which together with the earnest money would make up one month s rent
label: STA

text: The appellant made the deposit required by r 17 5
label: ANALYSIS

text: His bid was accepted and was later confirmed by the divisional commissioner
label: ANALYSIS

text: Neither the excise commissioner nor the state government passed any order under r 17 2 revising the decision confirming the acceptance of his bid
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 19 provides as follows 19 Successful bidder to apply for licence Every person to whom the right of retail vend of liquors is sold or whose tender in respect thereof has been accepted under these rules and who has made deposits as hereinbefore provided shall 1 at once apply in writing for licence for such shop confirmed in his name and within a week thereafter furnish to the Tahsildar the details of boundaries of the site selected by him for the location of the shop and a statement in the prescribed form annexed to the notification showing details of the immovable property possessed by him or in which he has an interest together with accurate and full details of encumbrances if any thereon 5 The purchaser shall get the bond and the mortgage deed registered under the Indian Registration Act 1908 at his expense 6 The purchaser or his surety shall produce an encumbrance certificate in cases where immovable property is mortgaged to the Governor of Mysore It is not alleged that the appellant did not furnish the details of the shop sites as required by r 19 sub r 1 within 15 days of the date of the confirmation of the sale
label: STA

text: The appellant made a deposit of two months rent as required by r 19 sub r 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant did not furnish a statement of immovable properties under r 19 sub r 1 nor did not he furnish security or sureties under r 19 sub r 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also alleged that he did not apply for licences at once as required by r 19 sub r 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 20 2 provides On failure to comply with the provisions of rr 17 and 19 the deposits already made shall be forfeited and the right of retail vend of liquors in such shop or groups disposed of in such manner under these rules as the Excise Commissioner may direct
label: ANALYSIS

text: No order was passed by the excise commissioner under r 20 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion the provision of r 19sub r 1 requiring the successful bidder to furnish a statement of his properties to the Tahsildar and the provisions of r 19 sub rr 3 and 4 do not apply where the shops in respect of which the right of retail vend is sold is situated in more than one tahsil
label: ANALYSIS

text: The opening part of r 19 sub r 1 requires the purchaser to furnish to the tahsildar the location of the shops and the boundaries of the shop sites
label: ANALYSIS

text: The expression the tahsildar is not defined but it is reasonable to think that the details regarding the shops should be furnished to the tahsildar within whose tahsil the shops are situated
label: ANALYSIS

text: If the shops are situated in more than one tahsil the details can be furnished to several tahsildars
label: ANALYSIS

text: But it is not possible to give effect to the last part of sub rule 1 and the provisions of sub rr 3 and 4 in cases where the shops are situated in more than one tahsil
label: ANALYSIS

text: The statement of immovable properties under the last part of sub r 1 can be furnished to only one tahsildar so that he can peruse the same and on such perusal or on independent inquiry ascertain under sub r 3 whether or not the purchaser is of doubtful solvency and satisfy himself under sub r 4 whether or not the value of the immovable properties tendered as security is adequate
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sub rr 3 and 4 do not contemplate findings by more than one tahsildar nor do they provide any machinery for resolving the conflict of opinion if any between two or more tahsildars
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion the last part of sub r 1 and the provisions of sub rr 3 and 4 do not apply where the shops are situated in two or more tahsils
label: ANALYSIS

text: The right of retail vend sold to the appellant is in respect of shops situated in 19 Tahsils in the districts of Raichur and Gulbarga Consequently those provisions were not attracted to this sale and the appellant was not required to comply with those provisions
label: ANALYSIS

text: The divisional commissioner Gulbarga could not record a finding under r 19 sub r 3 that the purchaser was of doubtful solvency
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even a tahsildar could not record such a finding without making an independent inquiry where no statement regarding immovable properties was furnished under sub rule 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: No independent inquiry under sub r 3 was made by any tahsildar
label: ANALYSIS

text: For this reason also the appellant cannot be regarded as a person of doubtful solvency and he was therefore not required to comply with the provisions of sub r 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant has so far deposited about Rs 90 00 000 and it is impossible to believe that he is a person of doubtful solvency
label: ANALYSIS

text: The remaining charge is that the appellant did not at once apply for licences
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 20 2 provides for the forfeiture of the deposits on failure to comply with the provisions of r 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under the Mysore Excise Licences General Conditions Rules 1967 a licensee is required to commence his business on July 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: The purpose of the Act and the Rules is achieved if the application for licence is made within sufficient time so as to enable the issue of licences before July 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: Having regard to the object of the Act and the Rules the expression at once in r 19 sub r 1 means within a reasonable time before July 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: It could not have been intended that the deposits would be forfeited where the purchaser applies for licence within a reasonable time
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant sufficiently complied with r 19 sub r 1 by applying under Ex B to the excise commissioner for permission to obtain licences and by applying to the divisional commissioner on June 18 for the issue of licences
label: ANALYSIS

text: The divisional commissioner Gulbarga was not competent to pass the impugned order Ex J cancelling the sale
label: ANALYSIS

text: Only the excise commissioner or the state government could under r 17 2 revise his previous order confirming the sale and on such revision cancel the sale
label: ANALYSIS

text: The divisional commissioner Gulbarga was not authorised by r 17 2 to revise his own order or to cancel it
label: ANALYSIS

text: In hi notice dated June 19 the divisional commissioner Gulbarga stated that he would take action under r 20 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: In his notice dated June 25 he asked the appellant to show cause why the sale should not be cancelled and why the deposits already made should not be forfeited to the government
label: ANALYSIS

text: But he did not pass any order forfeiting the deposits
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nor was he competent to pass any order under r 20 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: Only the excise commissioner could pass such an order
label: ANALYSIS

text: It follows that the High Court was in error in holding that the appellant committed breaches of r 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: The finding of the divisional commissioner Gulbarga that the appellant committed such breaches is erroneous nor was he competent to record the finding or to pass an order cancelling the sale
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of this conclusion it is not necessary to consider whether r 19 sub r 3 offends Arts 14 and 19 of the Constitution and we express no opinion on the question
label: ANALYSIS

text: We cannot agree with the proposition that the appellant is estopped from challenging the constitutionality and vires of the sub rule
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is true that r 24 provides that the purchaser shall be bound by all the rules
label: ANALYSIS

text: But if r 19 sub r 3 offends Arts 14 and 19 it is non est and there can be no question of the appellant being bound by a rule which does not exist
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though we express no opinion on the vires of the sub rule we must observe that r 19 is clumsily drafted its import is not clear its tight time schedule works hardship and its procedure is cumbersome
label: ANALYSIS

text: The government should immediately consider the question of re drafting r 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: It may be noted that Mr Narasaraju conceded that r 19 is not beyond the rule making powers of the state government
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant relied on the circular No EXE 1 1575 67 Ex E dated December 12 1967
label: ANALYSIS

text: Exhibit E is a letter from the excise commissioner to the deputy commissioner Bangalore on the subject of securities to be furnished by the excise contractors
label: ANALYSIS

text: The letter stated that the procedure of r 19 was number some and not clear that several deputy commissioners sought clarifications on the subject and that the state government had been moved to clarify and simplify the matter
label: ANALYSIS

text: The excise commissioner directed that pending receipt of the government order the following procedure should be followed In addition to obtaining two months cash deposits 1 two months cash security might be accepted and in the absence of cash security four months collateral security might be insisted 2 if the deputy commissioner tahsildar was doubtful about the solvency of the contractor he could insist on six months collateral security and 3 while accepting the collateral securities care should be taken to see that the contractor executed the necessary mortgage bond
label: ANALYSIS

text: Admittedly similar instructions were issued to other deputy commissioners and were enforced in several districts
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is a dispute on the question whether the circular was sent to the districts of Gulbarga and Raichur
label: ANALYSIS

text: In so far as the circular attempted to modify r 19 it was in effective
label: ANALYSIS

text: The excise commissioner had no power to abrogate or modify a rule framed under s 71
label: ANALYSIS

text: On behalf of the appellant it was argued that as the chief controlling authority the excise commissioner could frame regulations under S 3 read with r 24 and could issue general instructions on the subject of taking security in cases not covered by r 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: We express no opinion on this question as the government has already withdrawn the circular
label: ANALYSIS

text: But we must observe that relying on this circular the appellant deposited two months rent as required by the circular in addition to the two months rent as required by r 19 sub r 2 and that such deposits were duly made within 15 days from the date of the sale
label: ANALYSIS

text: However it is not necessary for the appellant to rely on the terms of the circular
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has complied with the provisions of r 19 and the sale in his favour cannot be cancelled
label: ANALYSIS

text: On behalf of respondent No 4 it is argued that the appellant bought the right of retail vend as benamidar for some other person that his benami bid was opposed to r 12 and could not be accepted and that as the sale of liquor by the real buyer without a licence in his favour was illegal in view of ss 15 and 26 the appellant was not entitled to any relief in view of the decision in Venkata Subbayya v Attar Sheik Mastan 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: The onus is upon the respondent to prove that the appellant made a benami purchase
label: ANALYSIS

text: It appears that the appellant is a retired inspector drawing a pension of about Rs 75 per month
label: ANALYSIS

text: He is not an income tax or a wealth tax assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: He does not own any property in Mysore State
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant says that he owns immovable properties in Andhra Pradesh but he did not file the title deeds in respect of them
label: ANALYSIS

text: However the appellant was in possession of a large amount of ready cash
label: ANALYSIS

text: Before June 25 he deposited about Rs 40 lakhs and thereafter deposited about Rs 50 lakhs
label: ANALYSIS

text: There can be no doubt that the appellant has the backing of powerful financiers
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no specific charge that some named person is the real purchaser
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the materials on the record it is not possible to record a finding that the appellant is a benamidar and that that some other person is the real purchaser
label: ANALYSIS

text: The purchase is not illegal merely because the appellant obtained the necessary funds from some financiers
label: ANALYSIS

text: The government never alleged that the appellant s bid was a benami bid and opposed to r 12
label: ANALYSIS

text: His bid was accepted and such acceptance was subsequently confirmed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under r 17 1 the confirmation is effective until revised by the appropriate authority
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is neither alleged nor proved that sonic person other than the appellant had been managing the shops and selling liquor in contravention of s 15
label: ANALYSIS

text: Respondent No 4 has failed to establish contravention of either r 12 or s 15
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court was in error in holding that the appellants bid was opposed to r 12
label: ANALYSIS

text: Having regard to the fact that the appellant had already deposited about Rs 40 lakhs the divisional commissioner Gulbarga acted rather precipitately and harshly in cancelling the sale
label: ANALYSIS

text: 1 A I R 1949 Mad 252 Sup CI 69
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3For the reasons already given the order of cancellation Ex J is invalid
label: ANALYSIS

text: The order must be set aside and a writ of mandamus must issue for the grant of licences to the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: Some complication arises out of the fact that the licences have been granted to respondent No 4 after the disposal of the writ petitions by the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: Licences cannot be given to both the appellant and respondent No 4 for retail vend of liquors in respect of the same groups of shops
label: ANALYSIS

text: In order to give effect to our order for the issue of licences in favour of the appellant it is necessary to give the further direction that the licences issued to respondent No 4 should be cancelled
label: ANALYSIS

text: We can give this direction as respondent No 4 is a party to this appeal
label: ANALYSIS

text: While holding that r 17 sub r 4 did not compel the officer conducting the sale to accept the next highest offer of respondent No 4 the High Court observed that the authorities concerned should consider the advisibility of accepting his bid
label: ANALYSIS

text: This observation is not in accordance with law and has given rise to unnecessary complications
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rule 17 4 provides that if the officer conducting the sale rejects the highest bid or offer he may either accept the next highest bid or offer or re sell the shop
label: ANALYSIS

text: The sub rule cannot be invoked if the officer conducting the sale has accepted the highest offer
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the present case the officer accepted the appellant s highest offer and later confirmed it
label: ANALYSIS

text: The confirmation is still effective under r 17 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: If for some reason the confirmation is subsequently revised or set aside the officer cannot act under r 17 4
label: ANALYSIS

text: In such a case there must be a fresh disposal of the right of retail vend of liquor in accordance with the Rules
label: ANALYSIS

text: It follows that the bid of respondent No 4 could not be accepted under r 17 4 after the disposal of the writ petitions on September 19
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is rather surprising that the Government acted so hastily and issued licences to respondent No 4 on or about September 18
label: RATIO

text: It is not quite clear how licences in respect of 1168 shops could be issued on a single day
label: RATIO

text: The effect of this precipitate action on the part of the government was that the appellant could not on the next day obtain a stay of the operation of the High Court s order
label: RATIO

text: There is ground for suspecting that the government was favouring respondent No 4
label: RATIO

text: In the result the appeal is allowed with costs in this Court and in the High Court
label: RPC

text: The order passed by the High Court is set aside
label: RPC

text: Writ Petition No 1889 of 1968 is allowed
label: RPC

text: The order dated June 26 1968 Ex J is set aside
label: RPC

text: Respondents 1 and 2 ire directed to grant immediately licences to the appellant to vend liquors in the combined groups of shops in Raichur and Gulbarga districts for the remaining period of the year 1968 1969
label: RPC

text: Respondents 1 and 2 are also directed to cancel forthwith the licences issued to respondent No 4 in respect of the aforesaid groups of shops
label: RPC

text: Y P
label: RPC

text: Appeal allowed
label: RPC

text: IN THE COURT OF THE ADDITIONAL SESSIONS JUDGE SUNDARGARH Present Sri D K Mishra LL B Additional Sessions Judge Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: Dated the 13th day of February 2015
label: PREAMBLE

text: S T Case No 164 47 30 of 2012 13
label: PREAMBLE

text: ______ Arising out of G R Case No 10 2012 corresponding to Town P S Sundargarh Case No 01 of 2012 committed by the learned SDJM Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: State of Odisha Complainant
label: PREAMBLE

text: versus
label: PREAMBLE

text: 1 Sanjeeb Kumar Panigrahi aged aboput 27 years son of Pramod Chandra Panigrahi resident of R R I T Colony P S Town District Sundargarh 2 Sumitra Mishra aged about 54 years wife of Pramod Chandra Panigrahi resident of R R I T Colony P S Town District Sundargarh 3
label: PREAMBLE

text: Pramod Chandra Panigrahi aged about 53 years son of late Somnath Panigrahi resident of
label: PREAMBLE

text: R R I T colony P S Town District Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: Accused persons
label: PREAMBLE

text: Counsel for the prosecution Sri Prasanta Kumar Patel Addl
label: PREAMBLE

text: Public Prosecutor
label: PREAMBLE

text: Counsel for the defence Sri D K Naik Smt N Naik and others Advocates
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of argument 05 02 2015 Date of judgment 13 02 2015
label: PREAMBLE

text: Offence under sections 498 A 304 B 302 306 34 of I P C read with section 4 of the D P Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: The accused persons stand charged for the offences punishable under section 498 A 304 B 302 306 34 of I P C read with section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act 2
label: FAC

text: The overview of the prosecution case is that Kabita Panigrahi the daughter of the informant was given in marriage with the accused Sanjeeb Panigrahi of R R I T Colony Sundargarh under Town P S Sundargarh in the month of May 2009
label: FAC

text: Some days after the marriage the said Kabita was subjected to cruelty by her in laws with a view to putting additional pressure on her maternal family to cough up more money in spite of the fact that at the time of marriage they were given a sum of Rs 1 00 000 two tolas of gold and other utensils towards dowry as per their demand
label: FAC

text: The relationship as time passed by further worsened and it culminated in the husband of the said Kabita filing a divorce proceeding against the latter in connivance with his parents
label: FAC

text: On 4 1 2012 at about 4 15 P M the informant came to learn that her daughter Kabita was administered poison and killed by her in laws
label: FAC

text: The informant then came to D H H Sundargarh where her dead body was kept
label: FAC

text: He reported the matter at Town P S Sundargarh alleging therein the fact that her daughter had been murdered by her husband and her parents in law
label: FAC

text: The same was registered as Town P S case No 1 2012 and investigation was carried on
label: FAC

text: After completion of investigation charge sheet was submitted against the accused persons u s 498 A 304 B 306 34 of the I P C read with section 4 of the D P Act
label: FAC

text: In due course the case was committed for trial and charge under sections 498 A 304 B 302 306 34 of I P C read with section 4 of D P Act were framed
label: FAC

text: 3 Defence sets up a plea of clean denial of facts alleged against the accused persons who while being examined u s 313 of the Cr P C have taken the plea that the marriage between the deceased and Sanjeeb was a marriage free from dowry
label: FAC

text: The deceased did not at all take a liking to her husband and want to continue her marital relationship with him even if both of them stayed separately from the parents of accused Sanjeeb
label: FAC

text: Therefore accused Sanjeeb filed a divorce case against the deceased and since then she had been living with her parents at her native village
label: FAC

text: 4 Prosecution in order to prove its case has examined as many as thirteen witnesses in all and defence has examined none in its behalf
label: FAC
