text: PRESENT THE HON BLE MRS JUSTICE S SUJATHA AND THE HON BLE MR JUSTICE JOHN MICHAEL CUNHA SALES TAX REVISION PETITION NO 100006 2016 BETWEEN MUKAND LIMITED HOSPET ROAD GINIGERA 583 228 KOPPAL TALUQ KOPPAL DISTIRICT REPRESENTED HEREIN BY ITS DEPUTY GENERAL MANGAER F A MR DEBABRATA DAS AGE 48 YEARS PETITIONER
label: PREAMBLE

text: BY SRIYUTHS T SURYANARAYANA H R KAMBIYAVAR VIKRAM
label: PREAMBLE

text: HUILGOL TANMAYEE RAJKUMAR VEDANTH ANAND AND
label: PREAMBLE

text: SANDEEP HUILGOL ADVS
label: PREAMBLE

text: AND RESPONDENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: THE STATE OF KARNATAKA
label: PREAMBLE

text: REPRESENTED BY THE COMMISSIONER OF COMMERCIAL TAXES VANIJYA THERIGE KARYALAYA KALIDASA ROAD GANDHINAGAR BANGALORE 560 009
label: PREAMBLE

text: BY SRI M KUMAR AGA THIS STRP FILED U SEC 65 1 OF THE KARNATAKA VALUE ADDED TAX ACT 2003 AGAINST THE ORDER DATED 30 07 2015 PASSED IN STA NO 1516 1527 2013 ON THE FILE OF THE KARNATAKA APPELLATE TRIBUNAL AT BENGALURU DISMISSING THE PETITION FILED UNDER SECTION 63 OF THE KARNATAKA VALUE ADDED TAX ACT 2003
label: PREAMBLE

text: THIS PETITION COMING ON FOR ADMISSION THIS DAY S SUJATHA J MADE THE FOLLOWING ORDER
label: PREAMBLE

text: This revision petition is filed by the assessee under Section 65 1 of the Karnataka Value Added Tax Act 2003 for short the Act relating to the assessment year 2005 06 2
label: FAC

text: The facts in brief are that the petitioner assessee is a dealer registered under the provisions of the Act and is engaged in the business of manufacture and sale of steel blooms billets and rounds
label: FAC

text: It transpires that during the tax periods April 2005 to March 2006 the petitioner effected purchases of iron ore scrap ferro alloys refractory bricks gases etc for use in the course of its business
label: FAC

text: In respect of the said purchases the selling dealers raised tax invoices as prescribed under Section 29 of the Act on the petitioner and it was contended by the assessee that the applicable tax amount was collected by the selling dealers under the provisions of the Act on such sales
label: FAC

text: It was the contention of the petitioner that those goods purchased by it were used in the manufacture of goods and both local and interstate sales of goods of the manufactured goods were effected
label: FAC

text: Accordingly input tax credit claim was made by the assessee for the tax periods in question
label: FAC

text: The Assessing Officer invoking the provisions of Section 39 1 of the Act proposed to disallow the input tax credit amounting to Rs 15 05 332 claimed by the petitioner on the ground that the said input tax related to purchases effected from seven dealers whose returns were not traceable
label: FAC

text: It was the grievance of the petitioner that even before filing the objections to the said notice the Assessing Officer proceeded to pass a reassessment order confirming its proposal to disallow the input tax credit claimed by the petitioner
label: FAC

text: On further appeal before the Joint Commissioner of Commercial Taxes Appeals Davangere Division Davangere the first appellate authority partly allowed the appeals confirming the denial of input tax credit on the ground that the selling dealers have not discharged the tax collected by the petitioner
label: FAC

text: However the levy of penalty under Section 72 2 of the Act was set aside
label: FAC

text: Aggrieved by the same appeals were preferred before the Karnataka Appellate Tribunal
label: FAC

text: The Tribunal dismissed the appeals confirming the order of the Assessing Authority and the First Appellate Authority insofar as disallowing the input tax credit claimed by the petitioner on the ground that seven dealers had not paid tax amounting to Rs 15 05 332 said to have been collected by them from the petitioner
label: RLC

text: Being aggrieved the assessee is in revision petition
label: FAC

text: 3 Learned counsel Sri T Suryanarayana appearing for the petitioner would contend that no provision under the Act authorises the authorities to disallow the input tax credit at the hands of purchasing dealer wherein the selling dealer has failed to file the sales tax returns and discharge its sales tax liability
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Denial of input tax credit is not supported by any statutory provision and is contrary to the provisions of the Act
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It is contended that input tax credit was supported by valid tax invoices raised by the selling dealers in accordance with the provisions of Section 29 of the Act the petitioner is entitled to claim input tax credit based on the invoices raised by the selling dealers the same having been used in the manufacture of goods and being effected with sales both locally and interstate
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It is contended that the Assessing Officer while passing the reassessment order has observed that tax invoices are genuine however denied the input tax credit only for the reason that VAT 100 returns for the year 2005 06 of the selling dealers is not forthcoming in Electronics Filing System EFS 4
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: In compliance with the order passed by this Court on 27 02 2017 the respondent State has filed statement of objections on behalf of the respondent
label: FAC

text: Placing reliance on this statement of objections the learned counsel for the assessee would contend that the respondent has admitted the input tax credit claim allowable in respect of the selling dealer Nos 1 to 3 except for the month of August 2005 in respect of M s High tech industrial gases whereas the same is disallowed in respect of the other four dealers
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: As far as dealer No 4 is concerned it is observed that invoices are dated November 2005 hence the input tax credit claimed after four months is not allowable
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: No reasons are assigned as far as selling dealers No 5 and 6 are concerned
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 5 The learned counsel for the assessee has placed a memo on record along with the returns in Form VAT 100 filed by M s Dalini Enterprises selling dealer No 7 for the tax period April 2005 to March 2006 and the relevant bank statements
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Based on the said returns learned counsel would point out that major portion of the input tax credit claimed was for the purchases made from the said selling dealer No 7 who has filed the monthly returns for the tax period 2005 06 and remitted tax to the treasury which is manifest from the statement of accounts of the selling dealers
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: On these grounds the learned counsel seeks to set aside the order impugned herein by allowing the revision petition
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 6 Learned AGA appearing for the respondent would emphasize that the burden lies on the assessee to prove that the tax collected was deposited by the selling dealers to the Government
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Reliance is placed on Section 70 of the Act to contend that for the purposes of any claim to input tax under the Act the burden of proving that any transaction of a dealer is not liable to tax or any claim to deduction of input tax is correct shall lie on such dealer
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It is pointed out that in pursuance of the directions issued by this Court the department has examined the matter in detail and on verification it was found that some of the selling dealers had filed the returns hence it is decided to extend the benefit of input tax credit as claimed in respect of selling dealer Nos 1 to 3 and the same is denied in respect of selling dealer Nos 4 to 7 as mentioned in the table appended to Para No 3 of the statement of objections
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It is submitted that the dispute has been reduced to Rs 6 14 200 as against Rs 15 05 332
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The learned AGA would submit that the returns filed by the selling dealers No 4 to 7 has not been traced to locate the factual position as regards the payment of tax made by these dealers as the relevant period in question is beyond eight years
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Thus it is submitted that the authorities are justified in rejecting the claim of input tax credit in respect of selling dealer Nos 4 to 7 since no relevant material was placed on record by the assessee to prove the tax being remitted to the Government by the selling dealers
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 7 We have given our anxious consideration to the arguments advanced by the learned counsel for the respective parties and carefully perused the material on record
label: NONE

text: 8 The question involved herein mainly relates to the denial of input tax credit claimed by the assessee for the reason that no VAT 100 returns were filed by the selling dealers for the relevant period in question
label: ISSUE

text: To answer the issue involved in this revision petition it is apt to consider the statement of objections filed by the respondent
label: ANALYSIS

text: Table in para No 3 is extracted hereunder
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sl Party Name TIN Number Month
label: ANALYSIS

text: ITC Output Remarks No as
label: ANALYSIS

text: Per 66612 Returns ITC Claim allowable B VRAJLAL Feb 06 4740 66724 ITC Claim allowable 71352 4740 AND CO 29170120926 2375 71464 ITC Claim allowable 1 Mar 06 18790 80760 ITC Claim allowable 3733 138231 ITC Claim allowable Total 24898 264005 3003 482996 ITC Claim allowable B K AUTO 29320098291 May 05 1035 4220 ITC Claim allowable CENTER 29320098291 Jul 05 1035 3347 ITC Claim allowable 2 5175 4299 ITC Claim Not 5128 allowable 29320098291 Jan 06 2070 ITC Claim allowable 3002 3103 ITC Claim allowable Total 3595 3166 ITC Claim allowable 3106 4065 ITC Claim allowable HI TECH May 05
label: ANALYSIS

text: 1035 4155 ITC Claim allowable 2070 2097 ITC Claim allowable INDUSTRIA 29780052351 2070 4378 ITC Claim allowable 3 L GASES Jun 05 27196 6586
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14969 Invoices are dated Jul 05 53834 Nov 2005
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence 261670
label: ANALYSIS

text: the ITC is claimed Aug 05 53834 after 4 months 855 261670 Sep 05 NIL ITC Claim Not Oct 05 9443
label: ANALYSIS

text: Allowable Nov 05
label: ANALYSIS

text: NIL ITC Claim Not Dec 05 37794 Allowable Jan 06 NIL ITC Claim Not Feb 06 5125 Allowable Mar 06 4577 ITC Claim Not Total 45572 Allowable ACE NIL ITC Claim Not REFRACTO 29700454266 Feb 06 1650 Allowable 4 RIES 1056 ITC Claim Not 2475 Allowable Total 264 ITC Claim Not 102914 Allowable NAVODAYA Jun 05 5897 5 TRADING 29150487694 CO Jul 05 Aug 05 Oct 05 Nov 05 Dec 05 Jan 06 Total ES 58839 35667 ITC Claim Not 6 ELECTRONI 29560307388 JAN 05 Allowable CS INDIA P Total 58839 35667 DALINI Apr 05
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case has been 142747 de registered in 7 ENTERPRIS 29780239173 May 05 108175 2007
label: ANALYSIS

text: Returns are not traced ITC ES
label: ANALYSIS

text: Claim Not Allowable Jun 05 Jul 05 137027 Aug 05 91735 Sep 05
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus it is categorically admitted that in respect of selling dealer Nos 1 to 3 assessee is entitled to the input tax credit as regards the selling dealer No 7 is concerned now the assessee has filed the income tax returns filed by the said dealer along with bank statements which prima facie shows that the selling dealer has remitted the collected tax from the assessee
label: ANALYSIS

text: The assessee has utilized the goods purchased from the selling dealers for the manufacture of goods and effected local and interstate sales
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 The Tribunal mainly relied upon the judgment of this Court in the case of State of Karnataka Vs Centum Industries Private Limited Bangalore 2014 80 Kar L J 65 to confirm the orders of the authorities
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: The said judgment of Centum supra was held in a different context wherein the issue was failure to claim input tax credit in the tax periods in which purchases were effected and the claim made in the subsequent periods
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: In that context it was held by the co ordinate bench of this Court that the claim cannot be made subsequently but in the instant case the issue involved is altogether different
label: ANALYSIS

text: The main ground for denying the input tax credit is that the VAT 100 returns filed by the selling dealers are not traceable under EFS
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not in dispute that the returns invoices filed by the assessee are genuine and the same are accounted in his books of accounts
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if we assume the burden of proof lies on the asseessee to establish the proof of the tax deposited by his selling dealer the same is not contemplated under Section 70 of the Act as contended by the learned AGA
label: ANALYSIS

text: What is contemplated under Section 70 of the Act is for the purposes of payment or assessment of tax or any claim to input tax under the Act the burden of proving that any transaction of a dealer is not liable to tax or any claim to deduction of input tax is correct shall lie on such dealer
label: ANALYSIS

text: Be that as it may it is not relevant to consider the issue on this aspect at present
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 The limited ground on which we have to examine the issue on hand is whether the respondent was justified in denying input tax credit benefits to the assessee on the ground that the VAT 100 returns filed by the selling dealers are not traceable under EFS
label: ISSUE

text: It is trite that the revenue can be at a loss in allowing the input tax credit to a dealer who deals with a bogus transaction for example a selling dealer who is not in existence or a de registered dealer in such circumstances it is not in doubt that unless the purchasing dealer establishes the genuineness of the invoices issued by the selling dealer no input tax credit can be allowed but that is not the case in the present set of facts
label: RATIO

text: The Assessing Officer while passing reassessment order has categorically observed that the invoices are genuine and in view of the material placed before this Court with respect to the selling dealer No 7 the matter requires reconsideration by the Assessing Officer
label: RATIO

text: Even as regards the selling dealer Nos 4 to 6 no reasons are assigned by the respondent for denying the input tax credit
label: RATIO

text: It is also trite that no input tax credit can be disallowed on the premise that the selling dealer is de registered subsequent to the relevant tax periods
label: RATIO

text: The cause shown for disallowance with respect to selling dealer No 7 is that the said concern has been de registered in 2007 returns are not traced and input tax credit claim is not allowable
label: RATIO

text: The same is contrary to the returns now made available before this Court
label: RATIO

text: The tax period involved in the present case is relating to 2005 06 if any de registration is made subsequently the same would not disentitle the purchasing dealer to claim input tax credit for the tax period of 2005 06
label: RATIO

text: 11 In the circumstances based on the objections filed by the respondent as aforesaid the factual aspects requires reconsideration
label: RPC

text: Hence we allow this revision petition and set aside the order impugned herein
label: RPC

text: The matter is remanded to the Assessing Officer to reconsider the issue afresh in the light of the observations made aforesaid and pass appropriate orders in accordance with law in an expedite manner
label: RPC

text: Sd JUDGE Sd JUDGE Sh JTR
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER 1962 SCR Supl 2 726 KANBI KARSAN JADAV Vs RESPONDENT STATE OF GUJARAT DATE OF JUDGMENT 24 01 1962 BENCH KAPUR J L BENCH KAPUR J L DAYAL RAGHUBAR CITATION 1966 AIR 821 ACT Criminal Trial Evidence of approver Corroboration on material particulars Othere circumstances to be considered Chemical Examiner s evidence if can be taken into Consideration to decide identity of hairs Indian Penal Code 1860 45 of 1860 302 201 India Evidence Act 1872 1 of 1872 s 45 HEADNOTE
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appellant and two others were convicted for murder under ss 302 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court accepted the testimony of the approver as being a reliable piece of evidence
label: PREAMBLE

text: It relied upon the discovery of the dead body of the deceased at the instance of the appellant and of blood stained buttons also at his instance and attached importance to the scarf recovered from the pit where the dead body was alleged to have been first buried and which had hairs both of the appellant as well as the deceased
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appellant contended that the evidence of the approver even though it had been accepted as true was not corroborated in material particulars connecting the appellant with the offence
label: PREAMBLE

text: None of the recoveries are corroborative of the statement of the approver to the extent of connecting the appellant with the offence committed on the other hand they are somewhat contradictory of the statement
label: PREAMBLE

text: The evidence of the Chemical Examiner was not sufficient to prove that hairs on the scraf were of the appellant or of the deceased because the Chemical Examiner was no expert on this matter and his evidence was not admissible under s 45 of the Evidence Act and at the most according to the Chemical Examiner the hairs resembled those of the appellant
label: PREAMBLE

text: Held that where the evidence of the approver is held not to be very helpful to the prosecution other circumstances besides the evidence of the approver has to be considered
label: PREAMBLE

text: The mere fact that the dead body was pointed out by the appellant or was discovered as a result of a statement made by him would not necessarily lead to the conclusion of the offence of murder
label: PREAMBLE

text: In the present case beside the evidence of the approver the appellant s pointing out of the dead body his pointing out the silver buttons of the deceased which were stained with human blood and the presence of his hairs on a pania scraf on which there were the hairs of the deceased also are important facts which are sufficient evidence to connect the appellant with the commission of the offence
label: PREAMBLE

text: Held further that writers of medical jurisprudence have stated that from microscopic examination of the hairs it is possible to say whether they are of the same or of different colours or sizes and from the examination it may help in deciding where the hairs come from
label: PREAMBLE

text: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v State of Hyderabad 1956 S C R 247 and Wasim Khan v State of Uttar Pradesh 1956 S C R 191 relied
label: PREAMBLE

text: on JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION
label: NONE

text: Criminal Appeal No 223 of 1959
label: NONE

text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and ordered dated April 14 1959 of the former Bombay High Court Rajkot Branch at Rajkot in Criminal Appeal No 84 of 1958
label: NONE

text: Nur ud din Ahmed and K L Hathi for appellant
label: NONE

text: H R Khanna and R H Dhebar for respondent
label: NONE

text: January 24
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR
label: NONE

text: J The
label: RLC

text: appellant and two others were convicted by the Additional Sessions Judge Gohilwad under ss 302 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Kanji and they were sentenced to imprisonment for life under the former section and to seven years rigorous imprisonment under the latter
label: RLC

text: The sentence were concurrent
label: RLC

text: On appeal the High Court set aside the convictionof Nanji Ravji but upheld the convictions and sentences of the appellant and Karamshi Bhawan
label: RLC

text: The appellant has Come in appeal to this Court by Special leave
label: FAC

text: The deceased Kanji was rather an unsavoury character in village Chiroda and it is alleged that he had a illicit connection with Shrimati Shantu the sister of Karamshi and also used to follow about Smt Baghu the sister of the appellant for a similar object
label: FAC

text: It is stated that five days before the occurrence the appellant Karsan Karamshi Nanji and Gumansinh approver met and decided to murder the appellant
label: FAC

text: With that object in view Gumansinh approver was to decoy the deceased to the Vadi of the appellant and there the murder was to be committed
label: FAC

text: At about sunset on March 19 1958 the deceased was decoyed to the place as previously arranged and there he was murdered by the appellant who gave him a few blows
label: FAC

text: with a sharp cutting instrument called Dharia
label: FAC

text: According to the statement of the approver the dead body was wrapped in the scarf of the deceased and was carried by the appellant from the place of the murder to the dry bed of the river and there it was burried in a pit
label: FAC

text: Nothing was heard of the murder or of the deceased till on March 26 1958 a brother of the deceased made a report to the police about his disappearance and that he suspected the three uncles of the appellant subsequently the appellant and the other accused persons were taken into custody by the police
label: FAC

text: One of them while in the custody of the police was allowed to go to the village and he asked the help of Shamji and Manilal P Ws
label: FAC

text: He also made a confession to them and they reported the matter to the police
label: FAC

text: On March 31 1958 Gumansinh and Karamshi made confessionswhich were recorded by a Magistrate
label: FAC

text: Between March 26 and March 31 recoveries of various articles were made
label: FAC

text: At the instance of the appellant it is stated the dead body and then the head of the deceased was recovered from a distant well
label: FAC

text: At the instance of Nanji on March 28 1958 a scarf was discovered in the pit in which the dead body was according to the approver buried
label: FAC

text: On the scarf there were some hairs which on analysis by the Chemical Examiner were found to be similar to the hairs of the appellant and of the deceased
label: FAC

text: A day previous i e March 27 1958 at the instance of the appellant silver buttons which were stained with human blood were discovered from the field of the appellant at small stick like a button belonging to the deceased was also found at his instance
label: FAC

text: The High Court rejected the confession of Karamshi on the ground that it was not voluntary
label: FAC

text: It acquitted Nanji on the ground that there were no corroboration in regard to him of the approver s statement the place where the dead body was buried was not discovered at his instance his production of stick and shirt and trousers from his house was of no consequence and the oral evidence was contrary to the medical evidence and Karamshi s confessional statement could not be used against Nanji
label: RLC

text: In regard to the appellant the High Court accepted the testimony of the approver as being a reliable piece of evidence
label: FAC

text: It attached no importance to the recovery of the cutting instrument Dharia nor to the discovery of the stick Dhoka at his instance
label: FAC

text: But the High Court did rely upon the discovery of the dead body of the deceased i e the trunk and the head at the instance of the appellant and of the blood stained buttons also at his instance and attached importance to scarf recovered from the pit where the dead body was alleged to have been first buried and which had hairs both of the appellant as well as of the deceased
label: FAC

text: It was argued for the appellant that the evidence of the approver even though it had been accepted as true was not corroborated in material particulars connecting the appellant with the offence
label: FAC

text: On the other hand it was contradicted
label: FAC

text: The approver had stated that the dead body was buried in a pit in the dry bed of the river but when that pit was dug up the dead body was not found there and only a piece of ulna bone and a heel of a human foot were found and all there recoveries had been made earlier and so could not be called corroborative in material particulars
label: FAC

text: It was further submitted that there was no evidence to show as to when and how the body of the deceased was removed from the pit dismembered and thrown into the well
label: FAC

text: The recovery of the scarf it was pointed out was an innocuous circumstance because on the evidence produced it had not been shown to belong to the appellant but to his father and the evidence of the Chemical Examiner was not sufficient to prove that the hairs on the scarf were of the appellant or of the deceased because the Chemical Examiner was certainly no expert on this matter and his evidence was not admissible under s 45 of the Evidence Act and at the most according to the Chemical Examiner s report the hairs resembled those of the appellant
label: FAC

text: And secondly according to the approver the dead body of the deceased was wrapped in his own pania scarf
label: FAC

text: It was further submitted that the statement in regard to the recovery of the trunk and the head will only show that the appellant knew where the trunk and the head were which at the most would lead to an inference of an offence under 8 201 and not of 8
label: FAC

text: What the law requires in the case of an accomplice s evidence is that there should be such corroboration of the material Parts of the story connecting the accused with the crime as will satisfy reasonable minds that the approver can be regardedas a truthful witness
label: ANALYSIS

text: The corroboration need not be direct evidence of the commission of the offence by the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: If it is merely circumstantial evidence of his connection with the crime it will be sufficient and the nature of the corroboration will depend on and vary with the circumstances of each case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v The State of Hyderabad
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The confessional statement made by the approver on March 31 1958 gave the following facts connecting the appellant with the murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: 1 The appellant gave dharia blow to the deceased
label: ANALYSIS

text: The dharia had already been discovered and it has been disregarded from the evidence by the High Court as being of no importance
label: ANALYSIS

text: The next thing stated by the approver was that the deceased s body was tied in a pania scarf
label: ANALYSIS

text: He did not state that the scarf in which it was bound belonged to the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: The next fact stated by him was that the appellant carried the body of the deceased and then it was buried in a pit and lastly he stated that the appellant had told him that the head of the deceased had been thrown into a well
label: ANALYSIS

text: None of these recoveries in the circumstances of this case are corroborative of the statement of the approver to the extent of connecting the appellant with the offence committed
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the other hand they are somewhat contradictory of the statement because the pania scarf which was found in the pit has now been stated to belong to the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: The dead body was not found in the pit the head had already been discovered and the trunk had also been taken out of the well
label: ANALYSIS

text: In these circumstances it was submitted that the approver s statement cannot be said to have been corroborated in material particulars
label: ANALYSIS

text: But there are other circumstances which have to be considered even if the evidence of the approver is held not to be very helpful to the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: Firstly there is the pointing out ofthe dead body by the appellant from the well secondly the discovery of the blood stained stained with human blood buttons at the instance of the appellant i thirdly the scarf which has been held to belong to the appellant and which was found from the pit pointed out by the co accused Nanji and fourthly by the presence of the hairs of the appellant and of the deceased on that scarf
label: ANALYSIS

text: The mere fact that the dead body was pointed out by the appellant or was discovered as a result of a statement made by him would not necessarily lead to the conclusion of the offence of murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: But there are other circumstances which have to be considered
label: ANALYSIS

text: The discovery of the buttons with bloodstains at the instance of the appellant is a circumstance which may raise the presumption of the participation of the appellant in the murder In Wasin Khan v The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 it was held that the recent and unexplained possession of stolen property would be presumptive evidence against a prisoner on a charge of robbery as also of a charge of murder
label: PRE_RELIED

text: But it must depend upon the circumstance of each case
label: ANALYSIS

text: The third piece of evidence to be considered is the recovery of the pania i e scarf
label: ANALYSIS

text: No doubt there is no statement by the approver that the scarf in which the dead body was taken was that of the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: But a scarf has been found which the High Court has held as belonging to the appellant and hairs were found on that scarf
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was argued that the finding of the hairs was of no consequence and at least the Chemical Examiner was not he proper expert who could depose as to the similarity or other wise of the hairs
label: ANALYSIS

text: The writers on medical jurisprudence however have stated that from the microscopic examination of the hairs it is possible to say whether they are of the same or of different colours or sizes and from the examination it may help in deciding where the hairs come from
label: ANALYSIS

text: InTaylor s Medical Jurisprudence 1956 Edn Vol 1 at page 122 sine cases are given showing that hairs were identified as belonging to particular persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus we have besides the evidence of the approver three important facts which connect the appellant with the commission of the offence
label: ANALYSIS

text: His pointing out the dead body his pointing out the silver buttons of the deceased which were stained with human blood and the presence of his hairs on a pania scarf on which there were the hairs of the deceases also
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion this would be sufficient evidence in the circumstances of the present case to connect the appellant with the commission of the offence
label: RATIO

text: We therefore dismiss the appeal
label: RPC

text: Appeal dismissed
label: RPC

text: PETITIONER COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX ASSAM TRIPURA MANIPUR NAGALAN Vs
label: PREAMBLE

text: RESPONDENT M S RAMESHWARI LAL SANWARMAL
label: PREAMBLE

text: DATE OF JUDGMENT22 09 1971
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH
label: PREAMBLE

text: ACT Income tax Act 1922 ss 27 and 34 3 Assessment on S as individual set aside under s 27 and fresh assessment made on S as karta of H U F Fresh assessment is on a different assessee and not one under s 27 Cannot claim protection of s 34 3 2nd proviso Income tax Act 1922 s 2 6A Shares of company in which public are not substantially interested Held in name of karta in H U F Loan to karta by company whether liable to be treated as dividend under s 2 6A HEADNOTE In connection with the assessment year 1955 56 the Income tax Officer issued notice under s 22 2 of the Income tax Act 1922 to S in the status of an individual
label: PREAMBLE

text: He submitted a return in the status of karta of his H U F
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Income tax Officer passed an ex parte assessment order on him as individual under s 23 4
label: PREAMBLE

text: The assessment was however set aside on S s application under s 27 of the Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: A fresh assessment was made on the H U F on February 6 1961 on the basis of the return submitted by S in that status
label: PREAMBLE

text: This assessment was made after the period of four years mentioned in s 34 3 of the Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: The question in appellate and reference proceedings was whether the latter assessment was one under s 27 and therefore protected as regards limitation under s 34 3 2nd proviso
label: PREAMBLE

text: In the previous years relevant to the assessment years 1955 56 and 1956 57 certain loans were advanced to the aforesaid H U F by a company
label: PREAMBLE

text: The tribunal found that S held certain shares in that company
label: PREAMBLE

text: Its further finding was that he held these shares as the karta of his H U F
label: PREAMBLE

text: The company being one in which the public were not substantially in terested the question was whether these loans could be considered as belonging to S and therefore any loan given by the company to S could not come within the scope of cl 3 to s 2 6A HELD i The return submitted by S in respect of the year 1955 56 was in his capacity as karta of his family
label: PREAMBLE

text: The status shown in the return was H U F
label: PREAMBLE

text: He filed no return in the status of an individual
label: PREAMBLE

text: The two capacities are totally different
label: PREAMBLE

text: The ex parte order was made against S in the
label: PREAMBLE

text: status
label: PREAMBLE

text: of an individual
label: PREAMBLE

text: What was set aside under s 27 was the assessment made on him in the status of an individual
label: PREAMBLE

text: There was no assessment against H U F and there was no
label: PREAMBLE

text: question
label: PREAMBLE

text: of setting aside any assessment made against H U F
label: PREAMBLE

text: On February 6 1961 the H U F was assessed for the first time though the Income tax Officer wrongly called it as a fresh assessment
label: PREAMBLE

text: On the facts established it was not possible to come to the conclusion that the assessment made against the H U F was an assessment under s 27
label: PREAMBLE

text: That being so the assessment made against the H U F on February 6 1961 was clearly barred by time
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court was accordingly justified in answering the first question against the Department
label: PREAMBLE

text: G ii Since
label: PREAMBLE

text: the High Court had not gone into the question whether the shares were held by S in his individual capacity or as karta of H U F
label: PREAMBLE

text: this Court had to proceed on the basis of the finding of the Tribunal that he held those shares as the karta of his family
label: PREAMBLE

text: This Court held in Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj s case that when the shares acquired with the funds of H U F were held in the name of the karta the H U F could be assessed to tax under the Act on the dividend from those shares
label: PREAMBLE

text: In view of that decision the loan in question must be held to be dividend within the meaning of cl e of s 2 6A
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Court however made it clear that the loan granted in the account year previous to the assessment year 1955 56 could not be brought to tax because assessment in respect of that year was not made within the time prescribed
label: PREAMBLE

text: 859 B H
label: PREAMBLE

text: Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj v C I T Bangalore 60 I T R 500 applied
label: PREAMBLE

label: PREAMBLE

text: To get over that difficulty the Commissione of Income tax applied for and obtained special leave to appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland
label: FAC

text: The appeals filed on the basis of the special leave granted are Civil Appeals Nos 1426 and 1427 of 1971
label: FAC

text: At present we are only concerned with those appeals
label: NONE

text: The judgment under appeal is one rendered in a reference under s 66 1 of the Indian Income tax Act 1922 to be hereinafter called the Act
label: FAC

text: The Income tax Appellate Tribunal after stating the case referred the following six questions for the opinion of the High Court 1
label: ISSUE

text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case and upon a true interpretation of the provisions of the Second proviso to s 3 4 3 the assessment for the year 1955 56 on the applicant Hindu undivided family made on 6 2 1961 pursuant to an order under section 27 cancelling the assessment of Shri S M Saharia as an individual was barred by limitation
label: ISSUE

text: 2 Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case and on a true interpretation of the terms of section 2 6A e of the Income tax Act 1922
label: ISSUE

text: the Tribunal was right in holding that the amounts of Rs 2 21 702 gross and Rs 3 43 5 05 net were taxable as dividends in the hands of the applicant H U F for the assessment years 1955 56 and 1956 57 respectively when the shares were registered in the name of Sri S M Saharia the Karta of the family 3 Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case
label: ISSUE

text: there was any material before the Tribunal to justify the conclusion that Sri S M Saharia was holding shares in Messrs Shyam Sunder Tea Co Private Ltd in his capacity as Karta of the applicant family consistingof himself and his minor son
label: ISSUE

text: 4 Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case there was any material before the Tribunal for the finding that the applicant family was the beneficiary up till 1678 1955 in respect of 50 shares registered in the name of Sri S M Saharia on 16 5 1953 before the disruption in the joint status of the family of Hanutram Ramprotap
label: ISSUE

text: 5 Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the Case the Tribunal was justified in holding that the Hindu undivided family of Hanutram Ramprotap was no a shareholder in M s Shyam Sundar Tea Company P Ltd up till 16 8 1955 6 Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case in computing the accumulated profits of Messrs Shyam Sunder Tea Co P Ltd within the meaning of Section 2 6A e the Tribunal acted rightly in refusing to allow a deduction in respect of loans advanced by the said Company to the erstwhile family of Messrs Hanutram Ramprotap which amounted to Rs 3 60 989 as at 31 12 1954 and increased to Rs 3 80 567 a at 16 8 1955 and written off at the end of the year 1 955
label: ISSUE

text: b deduction in respect of Rs 51 049 and Rs 66 206 for the assessment years 1955 56 and 1956 57 respectively being the difference between the written down value of depreciable assets of the said Company as per income tax records and their book value
label: ISSUE

text: The High Court has answered the first two questions in favour of the assessee and it did not go into the other questions as it opined that in view of the answers given to the second questions there was no need to answer the remaining questions
label: RLC

text: For the reasons to be presently stated we have come to the conclusion that the answer given by the High Court to the first question is correct and that given by it to the second question is wrong
label: ANALYSIS

text: As a result of our finding the appeal relating to the assessment year 1955 56 viz Civil Appeal No 1426 of 1971 has to be dismissed
label: ANALYSIS

text: But the appeal relating to the assessment year 1956 57 should be allowed and the case remitted to the High Court for answering the questions that remain to be answered
label: ANALYSIS

text: Let us first refer to the facts relating to the first question
label: ANALYSIS

text: As mentioned earlier this question exclusively relates to the assessment year 1955 56 the relevant previous year being Ramnaami year 2011 ending on March 31 1955
label: ANALYSIS

text: In respect of that assessment the Income tax Officer issued a notice under S 22 2 to Shri Sanwamal Saharia in the status of an individual on December 27 1955
label: ANALYSIS

text: He submitted a return on October 29 1959 on behalf of his H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: On February 29 1960 the Income tax Officer passed an ex parte assessment order on him as individual under s 23 4 without issuing any notice under s 23 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: On March 22 1960 Saharia filed an application under s 27 to cancell the ex parte assessment
label: ANALYSIS

text: On December 16 1960 the Income tax Officer set aside the order of assessment made on February 29 1960
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therein he stated that fresh assessment will be made in due course
label: ANALYSIS

text: An assessment was made on the H U F on February 6 1961 on the basis of the return submitted on October 29 1959
label: ANALYSIS

text: Prima facie this assessment is barred by s 34 3 which says No order of assessment or reassessment other than an order of assessment under section 23 to which clause c of sub section 1 of section 28 applies or an order of assessment or reassessment in cases falling within clause a of sub section 1 or sub section 1A of this section shall be made after the expiry of four years from the end of the year in which the income profits or gains were first assessable
label: STA

text: It is not the case of the Department that the assessment in question either falls under clause c of sub section 1 of section 28 or clause a of subsection 1 or sub section 1A of s 34
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the Department cannot take any assistance from the main s 34 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: But in support of its contention that the assess ment was made within time reliance was placed by the Department on the second proviso to s 34 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: That proviso reads Provided further that nothing contained in this section limiting the time within which any action may be taken or any order assessment or reassessment may be made shall apply to reassessment made under section 27 or to an assessment or reassessment made on the assessee or any person in consequence of or to give effect to any finding or direction contained in an order under section 31 section 33 section 33A section 33B section 66 or section 66A What was contended on behalf of the Department is that the reassessment in this case was made under s 27
label: ANALYSIS

text: That contention has been upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner as well as by the Tribunal
label: ANALYSIS

text: But the High Court has come to the conclusion that the reassessment was not made under that section
label: ANALYSIS

text: To recapitulate the facts which we have earlier mentioned the return submitted by Saharia was in his capacity as the karta of his family
label: ANALYSIS

text: The status shown in the return is H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: He filed no return in the status of an individual
label: ANALYSIS

text: The same person can be taxed both as an individual as well as the karta of his family
label: ANALYSIS

text: The two capacities are totally different
label: ANALYSIS

text: The liability to be taxed as an individual is different from the liability to be taxed on behalf of his H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: The individual and the H U F are totally different units of taxation
label: ANALYSIS

text: They are two different assessees
label: ANALYSIS

text: The ex parte order was made on February 29 1960 against Saharia in the status of an individual
label: ANALYSIS

text: What was set aside under s 27 was the assessment made on him in the status of an individual
label: ANALYSIS

text: There was no assessment against H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence there was no question offsetting aside any assessment made against H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: On February 6 1961 the H U F was assessed for the first time though the Income tax officer wrong called it as a fresh assessment
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the facts established it is not possible to come to the conclusion that the assessment made a against the H U F was an assessment under s 27
label: ANALYSIS

text: That being so the assessment made against the H U F on February 6 1961 is clearly barred by time Hence the High Court was justified in answering the first question against the Department
label: ANALYSIS

text: Now coming to the second question the relevant facts are these In the relevant previous years to the assessment years 1955 56 and 1956 57
label: ANALYSIS

text: certain loans had been advanced to the H U F by a company known as M s Shyam Sunder Tea Co P Ltd
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Tribunal has found that Saharia had held certain shares in that company
label: ANALYSIS

text: Its further finding is that he held those shares as thekarta of his H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the question that arose for decision was whether those loans can be considered as dividends as provided in clause e of s 2 6A
label: ANALYSIS

text: There was controversy between the parties whether those shares were held by Saharia in his individual capacity or as the karta of the family
label: ANALYSIS

text: That controversy has not been gone into by the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: At present we are proceeding on the basis that he held those shares as the karta of his family
label: ANALYSIS

text: Clause e of s 2 6A says dividend includes e any payment by a company not being a company in which the public are substantially interested within the meaning of s 23A of any sum whether as representing a part of the assets of company or otherwise by way of advance or loan to a shareholder or any payment by any such company on behalf or for the individual benefit of a shareholder to the extent to which the company in either case possesses accumulated profits
label: STA

text: It is not disputed that M s Shyam Sunder Tea Co P Ltd is not a company in which public are substantially interested
label: ANALYSIS

text: it is a private company
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only question that was in issue wag that as the shares in question stood in the name of Saharia
label: ANALYSIS

text: can they in law be considered as the shares of the H U F
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court held for the purpose of the Act they must be considered as the shares of Saharia and therefore any loan granted by M s Shyam Sunder Tea Co Ltd to the H U F cannot come within the scope of clause e to s 2 6A
label: RLC

text: In arriving at that conclusion the High Court differed from the view taken by the Mysore High Court in Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj v Commissioner of Income tax Mysore 1 wherein that Court held that provisions of s 18 5 23A and 16 2 and other provisions of the Act relating to shares and dividends do not lead to the conclusion that for the purposes of assessment to income tax dividend income derived by a benami holder of shares should be treated as his own income and not that die real owner of the shares which have yielded the dividend income
label: ANALYSIS

text: That decision was affirmed by this Court in Kishanchand Lunidasing Bajaj v Commissioner of Income tax Bangalore 2
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Therein this Court held that where the shares acquired with the funds of H U F were held in the name of the karta the H U F could be assessed to tax under the Act on the dividend from those shares
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In view of that decision we must hold that the High Court erred in its answer to the second question
label: RATIO

text: Hence that answer is discharged and in its place we answer that question in favour of the Department
label: RATIO

text: But we hasten to make it clear that in respect of the loan granted in the account year previous to the 1 53ITR 605 2 60 I T R 500 assessment year 1955 56 the same cannot be brought to tax as assessmet in respect of that year was not made within the time prescribed
label: RPC

text: In the result Civil Appeals Nos 1956 57 of 1959 are dis missed as being not maintainable
label: RPC

text: There will be no order as to costs in those appeals
label: RPC

text: So far as Civil Appeal No 1426 of 1971 appeal relating to assessment year 1955 56 is concerned it is also dismissed but Civil Appeal No 1427 of 1971 appeal relating to assessment year 1956 57 is allowed to the extent mentioned above and the case remitted to the High Court for answering the questions that were not answered by it
label: RPC

text: As both sides have partly succeeded and partly failed before this Court there will be no order as to costs
label: RPC

text: G C Ordered accordingly
label: NONE

text: IN THE COURT OF THE PRINCIPAL DISTRICT AND SESSIONS JUDGE AT MYSORE Friday 6th day of December 2013
label: PREAMBLE

text: PRESENT Sri N RUDRAMUNI B Com LL M Principal District Sessions Judge Mysore CRIMINAL MIS NOS 1761 1789 OF 2013 PETITIONERS CR MIS NO 1761 OF 2013 1 Yeshwanth S o Boregowda Aged about 29 years Residing at No 119 Kempegowda Layout Near Citizen School
label: PREAMBLE

text: Nanjangud Town
label: PREAMBLE

text: Mysore District
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 H P Manju S o Puttaswamy Aged
label: PREAMBLE

text: about 29 years
label: PREAMBLE

text: Residing at
label: PREAMBLE

text: No 120 Kempegowda Layout
label: PREAMBLE

text: Near Citizen School Nanjangud Town Mysore District
label: PREAMBLE

text: By Sri R M Siddaraju Advocate PETITIONERS
label: PREAMBLE

text: CR MIS NO 1789
label: PREAMBLE

text: 1 Prakash
label: PREAMBLE

text: S o Devaiah Aged about 20 years 2 Kumara S o Hanumanthaiah Aged about 22 years
label: PREAMBLE

text: Both are residing at Madrahalli Village Gundlupet Taluk Chamarajanagar District By Sri B P Devaraj Advocate V
label: PREAMBLE

text: s RESPONDENT IN BOTH PETITIONS State by Nanjangud Rural Police
label: PREAMBLE

text: Represented by the Learned Public Prosecutor
label: PREAMBLE

text: COMMON ORDERS ON BAIL APPLICATION UNDER SECTION 438 439 OF CR P C
label: PREAMBLE

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 who are arrayed as Accused Nos 3 and 4 while Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 who are arrayed as Accused Nos 1 and 2 in the F I R have filed anticipatory and regular bail petitions respectively seeking their enlargement on bail in Cr No 271 of 2013 of Nanjangud Rural Police Station registered for the offences made punishable under Sections 3 4 and 5 of Immoral Traffic Prevention Act 1956
label: FAC

text: 2 In brief case according to Prosecution as set out in the Case Diary is as follows
label: FAC

text: The assistant Superintendent of Police Nanjangud Sub Division has suo moto lodged complaint with P S H O of Nanjangud Rural Police Station alleging that on 21 11 2013 at 1 30 p m when he was in the office he received a credible information that in Malabar Plaza Hotel situated at Elachagere Bore Village certain immoral activities were going on
label: FAC

text: Complainant immediately thereafter secured his staff and panchas to conduct raid and proceeded in their Jeep to Elachagere Bore Village
label: FAC

text: When they conducted raid on the hotel they found the Petitioners in compromising position with the Prostitutes
label: FAC

text: On inquiry with them they revealed their names as Prakash and Kumar
label: FAC

text: The complainant arrested the Petitioners seized cell phones from them and produced them before the learned Magistrate who remanded them to Judicial Custody
label: FAC

text: The Petitioners moved bail application before the learned Magistrate which came to be rejected on the premise that Petitioners were caught red handed along with the victims
label: FAC

text: Investigation is yet to be completed
label: FAC

text: 3 On the strength of said complaint a case in Cr No 271 of 2013 for the offences punishable under Sections 3 4 and 5 of Immoral Traffic Prevention Act 1956 came to be registered
label: FAC

text: 4 Petitioner in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 have voluntarily surrendered before the learned Magistrate who in turn remanded them to Judicial Custody
label: RLC

text: Hence Petitioners filed the bail petition and the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 being apprehensive of their arrest filed the bail petition on the following amongst other common grounds Petitioners are innocent of the offences alleged against them and they have been falsely implicated in the case
label: FAC

text: Petitionerd in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 have voluntarily surrendered before the Trial Court on 21 11 2013 and till this day they are in Judicial Custody
label: FAC

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 being Cook in the said hotel were not involved in any of the activities as alleged in the complaint
label: FAC

text: They are neither the owners nor customers of the hotel
label: FAC

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 are not running any hotel and they are agriculturists by profession
label: FAC

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 are residents of Madrahalli Village Gundlupet Taluk Chamarajanagar District and the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 are residents of Nanjangud Taluk Mysore District and having movable and immovable properties
label: FAC

text: They are ready to abide by the conditions that may be imposed by the Court and ready to offer surety to the satisfaction of the Court
label: FAC

text: On all these amongst other grounds Petitioners in both petitions prayed for their enlargement on bail
label: FAC

text: 5 The learned Public Prosecutor has filed similar objections reiterating the averments made in the complaint
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has contended that there are reasonable grounds to believe that Petitioners have committed the above said offences
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 are absconding since the date of offence
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: All the Petitioners are influential persons
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Investigation is at preliminary stage
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: If Petitioners are released on bail they may abscond may tamper prosecution witnesses and may hamper investigation
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Hence Petitioners prayed for rejection of both the bail petitions
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 6 Heard the arguments of learned Counsels appearing on behalf of the Petitioners and learned Public Prosecutor 7
label: NONE

text: The following points would arise for consideration 1
label: ISSUE

text: Whether Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 are entitled to anticipatory bail as prayed in their petition
label: ISSUE

text: 2 Whether Petitioners in Cr Mis No 179 of 2013 are entitled to bail as prayed in their petition
label: ISSUE

text: 3 What order
label: ISSUE

text: 8 My answer to the above points is as follows Point No 1 In the AFFIRMATIVE Point No 2 In the AFFIRMATIVE Point No 3 As per final order for the following REASONS Point Nos 1 and 2 9 Learned Public Prosecutor has filed only the statement of objections
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has not made available to this Court the case diary relating to the investigation thus far done by the Investigating Officer
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 However learned Counsel for the Petitioners has produced order sheet of the Trial Court F I R remand application etc Perused these documents and also perused the grounds urged by the Petitioners in their petitions and their statement of objections
label: ANALYSIS

text: The contents of the F I R is quite clear that the Petitioners were caught red handed while they were in compromising position with the victim ladies
label: ANALYSIS

text: The learned Counsel for the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 would contend that Petitioners are Cook in the Hotel
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The learned Counsel for the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 would contend that Petitioners are not the owners of the hotel nor they are running the hotel and they are agriculturists by profession and they had nothing to do with the alleged brothel being carried on in the hotel
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: But I am not in agreement with the submission of the learned Counsel for the obvious reason that the allegations in the complaint and statement of witnesses would reveal that the Petitioners were found in compromising position with two ladies
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11 At this stage this Court refrains itself from making entire comment upon the rival contention and the merits of the case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Suffice it to say that the alleged offences are not punishable with death or imprisonment for life and are all triable by the Court of Magistrate
label: ANALYSIS

text: Maximum punishment for the said offences is only 7 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: Fact that the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 are permanent residents of Nanjangud Town Mysore District and the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 are permanent residents of Madrahalli Village Gundlupet Taluk Chamarajanagar District owning substantial movable and immovable properties and are deep rooted in society is not disputed
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 Having regard to the nature and magnitude of the offence I am of the view that Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 could be given benefit of anticipatory bail and Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 could be given benefit of regular bail by imposing certain conditions
label: RATIO

text: I have accordingly answered the above Point Nos 1 and 2 in the AFFIRMATIVE
label: RATIO

text: Point No 3 13 In the result and for the reasons stated above I proceed to pass the following ORDER Petition in Cr Mis Nos 1761 of 2013 and Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 filed by the Petitioners under Section 438 and 439 of Cr P C respectively stands ACCEPTED
label: RPC

text: The Respondent Police are directed to enlarge the Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 on bail in the event of their arrest in Cr No 271 of 2013 on their executing personal bond in a sum of Rs 1 00 000 Rupees one lakh only each with two sureties for like sum
label: RPC

text: The Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 is enlarged on bail on their executing personal bond in a sum of Rs 1 00 000 Rupees one lakh only each with two sureties for the like sum subject to following CONDITIONS
label: RPC

text: Petitioners in both petitions shall not tamper with prosecution witnesses or hamper with the investigation
label: RPC

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 shall appear before the Investigating Officer within 10 days from the date of this Order and Investigating Officer shall after interrogation release them on bail by obtaining necessary bonds
label: RPC

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 shall appear before the Investigating Officer on 1st and 16th of every month and mark their attendance till further orders of the Court
label: RPC

text: Petitioners in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 shall not leave the jurisdiction of the concerned Court without prior sanction
label: RPC

text: If the petitioners violate any of the conditions of bail order this order automatically stands cancelled
label: RPC

text: Original of this Common Order shall be kept in Cr Mis No 1761 of 2013 and a copy thereof in Cr Mis No 1789 of 2013 Dictated to the Judgement Writer transcribed by her on Computer revised and corrected and then pronounced by me in the Open Court on this day the 6th day of December 2013 N RUDRAMUNI
label: NONE
