text: Ext 11 Signature of P W 2 on Ext 1 Ext 12 Signature of P W 3 on Ext 1 Ext 13 Tested blue litmus paper Strip Ext 2 Hydrometer Chart Ext 21 Signature of P W 3 on Ext 2 List of Exhibits marked for the Defence Nil C J cum J M F C Rajgangpur
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER BHABA NANDA SARMA ORS Vs
label: PREAMBLE

text: RESPONDENT THE STATE OF ASSAM DATE OF JUDGMENT12 10 1977
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH UNTWALIA N L BENCH UNTWALIA N L GOSWAMI P K DESAI D A CITATION 1977 AIR 2252 1978 SCR 1 714 11 1977 SCC 4 396 CITATOR INFO R 1988 SC 863 ACT Indian Penal Code S 34 vis a vis s 38 Assault by common intention to cause injury likely to result in death Development of further common intention among some assailants to commit murder Liability for murder whether shared by all participants under s 34 HEADNOTE The three appellants assaulted deceased Shashi Mohan with the common intention to cause injury likely to result in his death but during the assault two of them developed a further common intention of murdering him The sessions Court tried the appellants for charges u ss 302 34 and ss 323 34 I P C but giving them the benefit of doubt acquitted them
label: PREAMBLE

text: In a State appeal the High Court set aside the acquittal order and convicted all the assailants sentencing them for life
label: PREAMBLE

text: This Court considered the question whether the conviction of all the three appellants u s 302 with aid of s 34 I P C was justified in law and partly allowing only the appeal of Bhaba Nanda Sarma
label: PREAMBLE

text: HELD Applying the principle of law under s 38 of the Penal Code the case of Bhaba Nanda can be separated from that of his two brothers
label: PREAMBLE

text: He shared their common intention to assault with the knowledge that it was likely to result in death but while committing the act in furtherance of that common intention the other two developed and shared the common intention of causing the murder
label: PREAMBLE

text: Bhaba Nanda can therefore be held guilty only u s 304 Part 11 while the other two appellants are liable for the murder with the aid of s 34 of the Penal Code
label: PREAMBLE

text: 717 G H 718 A B Afrahim Sheikh and Ors v State of West Bengal 1964 6 S C R 172 referred to JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No 155 of 1972 Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 24 11 1971 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court at Gauhati in Criminal Appeal No 20 of 1968
label: NONE

text: S K Nandy for the Appellants
label: NONE

text: S N Choudhary for the Respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by UNTWALIA J
label: NONE

text: This is an appeal under section 2 a of the Supreme Court Enlargement of Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction Act 1970 by three persons who are brothers
label: FAC

text: On the 10th of November 1967 at about 7 00 A M an occurrence took place in a village near Barpeta in Assam
label: FAC

text: The prosecution case was that Shashi Mohan Sarma a person who lost his life as a result of the assault on him in the company of his elder brother Gopi Nath Sarma P W 2 was proceeding to his field with some mustard seeds in a basket
label: FAC

text: Gopi Nath was going with some cattle to tether them in the field
label: FAC

text: When they proceeded to some distance Shashi Mohan was chased by the three appellants appellant Bhaba Nanda Sarma who was aged about 20 years at the time of the occur rence was armed with a lathi appellant Phanidhar Sarma had a dolibari a wooden hammer with along handle and appellant Harendra Nath Sarma carried an iron rod in his hand
label: FAC

text: They all chased Shashi Mohan
label: FAC

text: Shashi Mohan ran towards his brother Gopi Nath raising alarm
label: FAC

text: Bhaba Nanda caught hold of both the hands of Shashi Mohan from behind
label: FAC

text: Thereupon Phanidhar gave him a blow on his head with the dolibari
label: FAC

text: Shashi Mohan fell down
label: FAC

text: There after Harendra struck Shashi Mohan on Ms head and other parts of as body with the iron rod
label: FAC

text: Gopi Nath tried to intervene
label: FAC

text: Bhaba Nanda caught hold of Gopi Nath also Harendra assaulted him with the iron rod causing injuries
label: FAC

text: Shashi Mohan was taken to the hospital where he died at about 3 00 A M on the 11th of November 1967 as a result of severe injuries caused to him by Phanidhar and Harendra
label: FAC

text: The injuries inflicted on Gopi Nath were all simple in nature
label: FAC

text: After charge sheet by the police and committal by the Magistrate the appellants were tried in the Sessions Court for charges under section 302 read with section 34 and section 323 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code
label: FAC

text: The Trial Judge gave them the benefit of doubt and acquitted them
label: RLC

text: The State of Assam filed an appeal in the High Court of Gauhati
label: FAC

text: The High Court set aside the order of acquittal convicted all the three appellants for the offence of murder of Shashi Mohan with the aid of section 34 and sentenced each of them to impri sonment for life
label: RLC

text: Their conviction under section 323 read with section 34 was also recorded by the High Court but no separate sentence was imposed
label: FAC

text: Hence this appeal
label: FAC

text: The eye witnesses of the occurrence were P W 2 Gopi Nath Sarma P W 3 Danesh Ali P W 4 Nur Mohammad and P W 6 Kurpan Ali
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court in its judgment has catalogued the main five reasons which led the Sessions Judge to make an order of acquittal in favour of the appellants
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion the High Court was right in reversing the judgment of the Trial Judge and interfering with the order of acquittal
label: ANALYSIS

text: It did so well within the limits of its power and the law as enunciated by this Court in several decisions
label: ANALYSIS

text: The four reasons given by the learned Sessions Judge were of a flimsy nature
label: ANALYSIS

text: It did not justify the entertaining of any doubt in regard to the prosecution story on the basis of these reasons
label: ANALYSIS

text: One of the five reasons was that the P Ws did not state about the injuries of Bhaba Nanda and they were not explained by the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion the High Court has rightly not attached much significanceto the alleged failure of the prosecution to explain the injuries on Bhaba Nanda
label: ANALYSIS

text: The injuries on his person were of a very minor nature three ofthem being ecchymosis and one swelling of the root of right index finger
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of the Doctor D W 1 was not sufficient to prove that theinjury on the right index finger was grievious in nature
label: ANALYSIS

text: The ecchymosis inquiries however were all very simple
label: ANALYSIS

text: Bhaba Nanda did not claim in his statement under section 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure 1898 as to with what weapon the injuries were caused on his person
label: ANALYSIS

text: He merely said that Gopinath and Shashi gave blows on his back
label: ANALYSIS

text: He did not attribute the right index finger injury as having been caused by either of the two
label: ANALYSIS

text: No defence witness was examined to give any counter version of the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: Bhaba Nanda did not show his injuries to the Investigating Officer as is apparent from his evidence when he arrested him soon after the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: No counter information 9 951 SCI 77 was lodged with the police nor any counter case filed
label: ANALYSIS

text: In a case of this nature before an adverse inference is drawn against the prosecution for its alleged suppression or failure to explain the injuries on the person of an accused it must be reasonably shown that in all probability the injuries were caused to him in the same occurrence or as a part of the same transaction in which the victims on the side of the prosecution were injured
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution is not obliged to explain the injuries oil the personof an accused in all cases and in all circumstances
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is not thelaw
label: ANALYSIS

text: It all depends upon the facts and circumstances of each casewhether the prosecution case becomes reasonably doubtful for its failure to explain the injuries on the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the instant case the Sessions Judge was not justified in doubting the truth of the version given by the eye witnesses three of whom were wholly independent witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: Gopi Nath was surely present on the scene of the occurrence as he himself had received the injuries in the same transaction
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court has rightly believed the testimony of the eye witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: The question for consideration however is whether the conviction of all the three appellants under section 302 with the aid of section 34 of the Penal Code is justified in law
label: ISSUE

text: To attract the application of section 34 it must be established beyond any shadow of doubt that the criminal act was done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all
label: ANALYSIS

text: In other words the prosecution must prove facts to justify an inference that all the partici pants of the act bad shared a common intention to commit the criminal act which was finally committed by one or more of the participants
label: ANALYSIS

text: Section 38 of the Penal Code says Where several persons are engaged or concerned in the commission of a criminal act they may be guilty of different offences by means of that Act
label: STA

text: In Afrahim Sheikh and others v State of West Bengal 1 Hidayatullah J as he then was has pointed out that it was possible to apply the ingredients of section 34 in relation to the commission of an offence tinder section 304 Part II even though death is caused with the knowledge of the persons participating in the occurrence that by their act death was likely to be caused
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The sharing of the common intention as pointed out in that case is the commission of the act or acts by which death was occasioned
label: PRE_RELIED

text: With reference to section 38 the learned Judge observed at page 178 That is to say even though several persons may do a single criminal act
label: PRE_RELIED

text: the responsibility may vary according to the degree of their participation
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The illustration which is given clearly brings out that point
label: PRE_RELIED

text: lastly section 38 provide that the responsibility for the corn pleted criminal act may be of different grades according to the share taken by the different accused in the completion of the criminal act and this section does not mention anything about intention common or otherwise or knowledge
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 1 1964 6 S C R 172 The injuries found on the person of the deceased by P W 5 Dr S Kalita who held the autopsy over the dead body were of a very severe nature
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The fatal injuries in particular were the three head injuries
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to the consistent version of the prosecution one was caused by Phanidhar with the dolibari and the other two were inflicted by Harendra with the iron rod
label: ANALYSIS

text: Harendra is also said to have caused the other injuries found on the person of Shashi Mohan
label: ANALYSIS

text: The result of the three head injuries was fracture of the occipital bone into six pieces and fracture of the right parietal bone 2 in length
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the opinion of the Doctor the death was due to coma as a result of intracranial hemorrhage caused by the injuries sustained by the victim
label: ANALYSIS

text: The two authors of the injuries namely Phanidhar and Harendra therefore undoubtedly had shared the common intention of causing such bodily injuries to Shashi Mohan which were sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause his death
label: ANALYSIS

text: In other words his death was as a result of the criminal acts committed by the said two appellants in furtherance of their common intention
label: ANALYSIS

text: There cannot be any doubt about it
label: ANALYSIS

text: Their liability for the murder of Shashi Mohan with the aid of section 34 of the Penal Code is fully established
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case of Bhaba Nanda however stands on a different footing and can justifiably be separated from that of the other two appellants
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the evidence of Gopi Nath himself the result aforesaid follows
label: ANALYSIS

text: Shashi Mohan had reached near him and when he tried to obstruct the accused and prevent them from committing the assault on Shashi Mohan
label: ANALYSIS

text: Harendra said we have met enemy today need not be freed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereupon Bhaba Nanda caught hold of the hands of Shashi Mohan from behind
label: ANALYSIS

text: Phanidhar then gave him the blow on the head as already stated with the dolibari
label: ANALYSIS

text: Harendra gave further blows on his head and other parts of his body after Shashi fell down
label: ANALYSIS

text: On these facts it is difficult to conclude that Bhaba Nanda caught hold of the hands of Shashi sharing the common intention of Phanidhar and Harendra of causing the death of Shashi
label: ANALYSIS

text: He did not utter a word which would justify such a conclusion
label: ANALYSIS

text: He must be aware that his two elder brothers Phanidhar and Harendra were going to assault Shashi with their respective weapons in their hands
label: ANALYSIS

text: Bhaba Nanda did not use his lathi for causing any injuries on Shashi
label: ANALYSIS

text: The first blow was given by Phanidhar
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereupon Shashi fell down
label: ANALYSIS

text: Bhaba Nanda s intention therefore was to join in the commission of the acts by the other two with the intention of getting Shashi assaulted severely with the knowledge that such an assault in all probability and likelihood might result in the death of Shashi
label: ANALYSIS

text: His participation in the crime therefore did not take him to the extent of the sharing of the common intention to cause his murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: As we have said above Phanidhar and Harendra undoubtedly shared such an intention as is apparent from the manner of assault by them on Shashi and the severity and force with which the blows were given on his bead by both of them with the respective weapons in their hands
label: ANALYSIS

text: Applying the principle of law under section 38 of the Penal Code therefore the case of Bhaba Nanda can be separated from that of the other two
label: ANALYSIS

text: He can be held guilty only under section 304 Part II as he bad intentionally joined in the commission of an act with the knowledge that the assault on Shashi was likely to result in his death
label: ANALYSIS

text: The facts of this case indicate that Bhaba Nanda shared the common intention of his other two brothers for the commission of a lesser offence than murder
label: RATIO

text: But while committing the act in furtherance of that common intention Phanidhar and Harendra developed and shared the common intention of causing his murder
label: RATIO

text: For the reasons stated above the appeal of appellants Phanidhar and Harendra is dismissed
label: RPC

text: The appeal of Bhaba Nanda is partly allowed
label: RPC

text: His conviction is altered from sections 302 34 to section 304 Part 11 read with section 34
label: RPC

text: The sentence of life imprisonment imposed on him is altered to rigorous imprisonment for 7 years only
label: RPC

text: The conviction of all the appellants under sections 323 34 is also main tained
label: RPC

text: M R Appeal allowed in part
label: RPC

text: THE COURT OF JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE FIRST CLASS SUNDARGARH
label: PREAMBLE

text: Present Sri P K Sethi LL M J M F C Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: Dated this the 16th day of October 2015 2 a CC No 174 of 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: Trial No 339 of 2015
label: PREAMBLE

text: STATE
label: PREAMBLE

text: Prosecution
label: PREAMBLE

text: VERSUS
label: PREAMBLE

text: Bhukhal Khadia aged about 65 years
label: PREAMBLE

text: S O Late Litu Khadia At Bandhabahal P S Hemgir District Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: Accused Offence U s 47 a of the B O Excise Act Counsel for the prosecution
label: PREAMBLE

text: Debasish Mishra A P P Sundargarh
label: PREAMBLE

text: Counsel for the defence Shri N Immam Advocate
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of conclusion of argument 15 10 2015
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of pronouncement of judgment 16 10 2015 J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: The accused person namely Bhukhal Khadia stands charged for the commission of offence U s 47 a of the Bihar Orissa Excise Act
label: FAC

text: The accused is on bail and is present in the Court today
label: FAC

text: Briefly stated the case of the prosecution is that on 13 07 2014 at about 7 30 am near Bandhabahal area while Indrajit Sahu S I Of Excise Sadar Mobile was performing patrolling duty along with other official staffs they found the accused Bhukhal Khadia going on the road by holding a plastic jerry cane in his hand
label: FAC

text: On suspicion S I of Excise detained him and search was effected
label: FAC

text: On search he recovered some contraband liquid substance suspected to be liquor
label: FAC

text: After that S I of Excise conducted smell blue litmus paper and hydrometer tests
label: FAC

text: On hydrometer test the temprature was found to be 720 F indication to be 86 0 and strength to be 62 10 UP and out of his distillery training and experience ascertained that the liquid was nothing but I D liquor
label: FAC

text: On being asked the accused could not produce any licence or authority with respect to same
label: FAC

text: After measurement through litre measure the whole quantity was found to be 5 litres
label: FAC

text: Seizure was effected and then seizure list was prepared
label: FAC

text: After that he read over the contents to the accused and the witnesses and obtained their signatures on the seizure list
label: FAC

text: The S I of Excise arrested the accused and forwarded him to the court
label: FAC

text: After completion of inquiry he submitted P R against the accused u s 47 a of the B O Excise Act to face his trial
label: FAC

text: Hence this case
label: FAC

text: 3 The Plea of the defence is of outright denial and false implication
label: FAC

text: 4 The following points arose for determination in the present case I
label: ISSUE

text: Whether on 13 07 2014 at about 7 30 AM at Bandhabahal village the accused namely Bhukhal Khadia was detected by the Excise officials to be in exclusive and conscious possession of one plastic jerrycane containing 5 litres of I D liquor without any license or authority
label: ISSUE

text: II Whether the seized article was nothing but I D liquor
label: ISSUE

text: 5 In order to substantiate its case prosecution has examined 2 witnesses in all out of whom P W 1 is the S I of Excise and P W 2 is the Excise constable
label: ANALYSIS

text: Rest one witness has been declined by the learned A P P Ext s 1 to 2 1 are marked on behalf of the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the other hand defence has neither examined any witnesses nor marked any documents as exhibits on its behalf
label: ANALYSIS

text: 6 The learned counsel for the state has contended that in this case both the official witnesses have supported the prosecution case in full and hence the prosecution case is well established
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the other hand the learned defence counsel has challenged the credibility and quality of the case on the following grounds I The seized articles have not been produced II
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: None could say regarding the special identification mark on the seized articles
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Submitting the above the learned counsel for the defence has prayed for an acquittal
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 7 On appreciation of evidence on record P W 1 the S I of Excise has deposed that on 13 07 2014 at about 7 30 am he was performing patrolling duty at Bandhabahal village along with his official staffs
label: ANALYSIS

text: During patrolling duty they found the accused going on the road by holding a white plastic jerry cane in his hand
label: ANALYSIS

text: On suspicion he detained the accused and on search he recovered I D liquor from the plastic jerry cane
label: ANALYSIS

text: The total amount of I D liquor was found to be 5 litres through litre measurement
label: ANALYSIS

text: He tested the liquid with blue litmus paper as a result of which it turned into red
label: ANALYSIS

text: The temperature indication and strength of the liquid substance were found to be 720 F 86 0 and 62 10 UP respectively on hydrometer test
label: ANALYSIS

text: He proved the tested blue litmus paper as Ext 1 2
label: ANALYSIS

text: He proved the hydrometer chart as Ext 2 and his signature thereon as Ext 2 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: On smell test departmental experience and distillery training it was ascertained that the liquid substance is nothing but I D liquor
label: ANALYSIS

text: On demand the accused failed to produce any authority in respect of the same
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter seizure was effected and seizure list was prepared
label: ANALYSIS

text: He proved the seizure list as Ext 1 and his signature thereon as Ext 1 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 2 Excise constable who accompanied the SI of Excise during patrolling duty has deposed that during patrolling duty they detected the accused person who was going on the road by holding a plastic jerry cane in his hand
label: ANALYSIS

text: On suspicion Sahu sir detained him and on search he recovered 5 litres of I D liquor containing in a plastic jerry cane
label: ANALYSIS

text: After conducting blue litmus paper test hydrometer test and on smell test it was ascertained by the S I of Excise that the said liquid substance was nothing but I D liquor
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter the liquor along with plastic jerry cane was seized and seizure list was prepared in the presence of witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: His signature on the seizure list has been admitted into evidence as Ext 1 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the testimonies of P W 1 and P W 2 it is clear that the S I of Excise has conducted hydrometer test and blue litmus paper test for ascertaining the seized liquid to be I D liquor
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nothing substantial could be elicited from the P W s 1 and 2 during cross examination to discredit their testimonies
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of the aforesaid analysis I am of the opinion that the liquid is nothing but I D liquor
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 The next question to be determined is whether the seizure was made from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused
label: ANALYSIS

text: To this the learned counsel for the accused submitted that there is no independent witness available in this case to prove the search and seizure
label: ANALYSIS

text: The seized article was also not produced before the Court during the course of trial
label: ANALYSIS

text: The witnesses examined in this case are interested witnesses for the prosecution as such they cannot be relied upon and accordingly the accused be acquitted
label: ANALYSIS

text: Admittedly the seized liquor has not been produced in the Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: The witnesses examined are the interested witnesses whose evidence required corroboration by independent witness which is absent in this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the absence of independent corroboration the search and seizure of the contraband articles become doubtful
label: ANALYSIS

text: Moreover the documents relating to the ownership of the house of the accused have not been seized
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of the above discussion the fact that the seized article was recovered from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused becomes doubtful
label: RATIO

text: Hence it is concluded that prosecution has failed to prove the factum of seizure from the exclusive and conscious possession of the accused beyond all reasonable doubts
label: RATIO

text: 9 In the result therefore I hold the accused not guilty of committing the offence punishable U s 47 a of the Bihar Orissa Excise Act and acquit him as per Section 248 1 of the Cr PC
label: RPC

text: The accused be set at liberty forthwith and is discharged from his bail bond
label: RPC

text: The seized articles if any be destroyed after four months of expiry of appeal period if no appeal is preferred and if preferred be dealt with as per the direction of the Appellate Court
label: RPC

text: Enter this case as mistake of fact
label: RPC

text: Pronounced the judgment in the Open Court today i e on 16th day of October 2015 under my hand and seal of the Court J M F C Sundargarh Typed to my dictation corrected by me J M F C Sundargarh

text: PETITIONER DHARAM PAL ORS Vs RESPONDENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: THE STATE OF U P DATE OF JUDGMENT01 09 1975
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH BEG M HAMEEDULLAH BENCH BEG M HAMEEDULLAH BHAGWATI P N SARKARIA RANJIT SINGH CITATION 1975 AIR 1917 1976 SCR 1 587 9 18 1975 SCC 2 596 CITATOR INFO R 1976 SC1084 ACT I P C Sec 302 read sec 149 and 34 Conviction of four accused and acquittal of rest Whether unlawful assembly Whether conviction under common intention Vicarious liability U P Children Act 1951 Sec 29 Young accused Recommendation of remission HEADNOTE The 4 appellants were tried along with 14 others for the offence of rioting in the course of which 2 murders were committed at 6 30 a m on 7 1967
label: PREAMBLE

text: The prosecution revealed a long standing enmity between the tyo groups one to which the appellants belonged and the other to which the deceased belonged
label: PREAMBLE

text: The defence case was that people belonging to the group of the deceased killed the deceased and that thereafter they attacked the 3 injured appellants
label: PREAMBLE

text: At the trial however the defence witnesses stated that the 3 witnesses who were injured l a tempted to save the deceased and were therefore injured
label: PREAMBLE

text: The prosecution evidence suffered from some quite obvious infirmitied
label: PREAMBLE

text: Each of the 4 injured eye witnesses while naming each of the IX accused persons as participants in the occurrence and specifying their weapons without any contradiction had failed to assign any particular part of any of them
label: PREAMBLE

text: Each injured eye witness said that all 18 accused persons were assaulting the injured
label: PREAMBLE

text: I his was hardly consistent with the medical evidence
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Trial Court acquitted 11 accused giving them the benefit of doubt and convicted 7 including the 4 appellants under section 302 read with section 149
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court gave the benefit of doubt to all the accused except the 4 appellants
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the 4 appellants had taken part in The attack in view of the admission of the 4 accused about their participating in the occurrence corroborated by the injuries on the bodies of 3 of them
label: PREAMBLE

text: On appeal by Special leave it was contended by the appellants that since 14 out of 18 accused persons were actually acquitted the Court must presume that total number of assailants was less than 5 and that they therefore cannot be convicted under section t 49 HELD 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is true that the acquittal of an accused person does raise in the eye of law a presumption that he is innocent even if he was actually guilty
label: PREAMBLE

text: but it is only the acquitted accused person and not the convicted accused person who can as a rule get the benefit of such a presumption
label: PREAMBLE

text: The effect of findings on questions of fact depends upon the nature of those findings 1 only five known persons are alleged to have participated in an attack and the counts find that 2 of them were falsely implicated
label: PREAMBLE

text: it would be quite natural and logical to infer or presume that the participants were less than 5 in number
label: PREAMBLE

text: On the other
label: PREAMBLE

text: hand if the court holds that the assailant were actually 5 in number but there could be a doubt as to the identity of 2 of the alleged assailants and therefore acquits 2 of them the others will not get the benefit of douht so long as there is a firm finding based on good evidence and sound reasoning that the participants were 5 or more in number Such a ease is one of doubt only as to identity of some participants and not as to total number of participants 594A C 2
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is true that there are some unfirmities in the prosecution evidence
label: PREAMBLE

text: However the impression of rustic witnesses sought to he conveyed through their statements cannot be interpreted as though they were made in carefully drawn up documents calling for a literal interpretation
label: PREAMBLE

text: The number and location of injuries on both sides also indicate an attack by a group of persons which must have surrounded the party of the deceased persons travelling in the Buggi
label: PREAMBLE

text: Even is 2 persons are engaged in stopping the Buggi and there are 2 on each side of the Buggi then the number would be 6
label: PREAMBLE

text: Again even if one person Is assumed to be the assailant of each of the victims in a simultaneous attack upon them the number of such assailants alone would come to at least 6
label: PREAMBLE

text: The deceased had injuries with sharp edged weapons and lathis
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is therefore clear that each one was attacked by more than one person
label: PREAMBLE

text: These facts were enough to come to the conclusion that the total number of assailants could not conceivably have been less than 5
label: PREAMBLE

text: Even if the number of assailants could have been less than 5 which can the facts stated was really not possible we think that the fact that the attacking party was clearly shown to have waited for the Buggi to reach near the field of Daryao in the early hours shows pre planning
label: PREAMBLE

text: Some of the assailants had sharp edged weapons
label: PREAMBLE

text: They were obviously lying in wait for the Buggi to arrive
label: PREAMBLE

text: A more convincing evidence of a pre concert was not necessary
label: PREAMBLE

text: Therefor if necessary
label: PREAMBLE

text: we would not have hesitated to apply section 31 of I P C also to this case
label: PREAMBLE

text: The principle of vicarious liability does not depend upon the necessity to convict the required number of persons but it depends upon proof of facts beyond reasonable doubt which makes such a principle applicable
label: PREAMBLE

text: 594 F H 595 A Yeshwant Anr v State of Maharashtra 1973 1 S C R 291 It 302 303 at and Sukh Ram v State of U P 1974 2 S C R 518 distinguished 5 The age of appellant Om Pal at the time of trial was IS years
label: PREAMBLE

text: Section 29 of the U P Children Act 1951 was applicable to the case
label: PREAMBLE

text: This question was not raised either before the Trial Court or before the High Court
label: PREAMBLE

text: Although Om Pal accused was said to be armed with a lathi no specific part was assigned to him by the prosecution witnesses He must have been misled by the bad example of his elders
label: PREAMBLE

text: No previous participation in such a case and no previous conviction was shown against him
label: PREAMBLE

text: The appropriate ac ion under section 29 of the Children Act could have been taken in his case is the question had been raised in time
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Court recommended the remission of the remaining period of Om Pal to the authorities concerned
label: PREAMBLE

text: 548D H 599A C

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION
label: NONE

text: Criminal Appeal No
label: NONE

text: 108 of 1971 Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and order dated the 20th November 1970 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No 495 of 1968
label: NONE

text: D Mukherjee U K Jha and U P Singh for the Appellant
label: NONE

text: D P Unival and o P Rana for the Respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BEG
label: NONE

text: J The four appellants Daryao Singh aged 46 years
label: FAC

text: Birbal aged 50 years Dharam Pal aged 29 years and Om Pal aged 15 years were tried alongwith 14 others for the offence of rioting in the course of which two murders were committed on 7 6 1967 at about 6 30 a m on a path adjoining the field of the appellant Daryao Singh leading to village Parsoli from village Nirpura in Police Station Doghat in the District of Meerut
label: FAC

text: The Trial Court acquitted eleven accused persons giving them the benefit of doubt and convicted seven including the four appellants
label: RLC

text: Each of the accused persons was charged and convicted under Section 302 read with Sections 149 Indian Penal Code and sentenced to life imprisonment in addition to charges and convictions under Section 149 324 and 149 34 I P C and either under Section 147 or Section 148 I P C depending upon the weapon alleged to have been used by an accused person
label: RLC

text: The prosecution case revealed a long standing enmity between two groups of village Nirpura one to which the appellants belonged and another to which Mukhtara and Raghubir the murdered men and the four other injured persons belonged
label: FAC

text: As is not unusual the origin of the hostility between the two sides seems to have been a dispute over cultivable land between collaterals who had some joint Khatas
label: FAC

text: Asa Ram P W 1 claimed to be in separate possession of some plots with his two brothers including Raghubira murdered and his uncle Mukhtara murdered
label: FAC

text: It was alleged by Asa Ram P W 1 that Daryao Singh appellant wanted to take forcible possession of some land cultivated by him
label: FAC

text: Daryao Singh and others had already filed partition suit which was pending at the time of the occurrence
label: FAC

text: It appears that Hargyan the father of the appellant Daryao a first cousin of Mukhtara the murdered man had also been murdered in 1923 over a similar dispute
label: FAC

text: Asa Ram P W 1 and Raghubira deceased Bija P W 10 and Asghar P W 4 had been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment
label: FAC

text: They had been released on parole after five years imprisonment
label: FAC

text: On the date of occurrence Mukhtara the murdered man was said to be proceeding with Raghubir who was also murdered and Asa Ram P W 1 and Bija P W 10 all sitting in a buggi driven by Asghar P W 4 and Smt Jahani P W 3 the wife of Asa Ram P W 1 was said to be following the buggi at a short distance with some food for the party
label: FAC

text: When this buggi reached the field of Daryao Singh where a number of persons said to be eighteen altogether whose names are mentioned in the First Information Report lodged at Police Station Doghat at a distance of three miles from village Nirpura at 8 30 a m were sitting on the boundary
label: FAC

text: These persons are alleged to have surrounded the buggi and attacked its occupants with balams and lathies shouting that the whole party in the buggi should be killed
label: FAC

text: give occupants of the buggi and after that Smt Jahani who soon joined them were injured
label: FAC

text: Two of them Mukhtara and Raghubir died very soon after the attack
label: FAC

text: It was alleged that Dharam Pal Birbal and Daryao appellants and Nahar Ajab Singh and Ram Kishan acquitted persons were armed with balams one Salek Chand was armed with a spade and the rest with lathis
label: FAC

text: A number of witnesses are said to have arrived in response to the shout of the injured occupants of the buggi
label: FAC

text: The following injuries are shown to have been sustained by the victims of the attack 1
label: FAC

text: MUKHTARA 1 Vertical abrasion 1 1 2 in x 1 2 in
label: FAC

text: On the head 4 in above the middle of the left eye brow 2
label: FAC

text: Transverse abrasion 1 3 4 in x3 4 in
label: FAC

text: On the head 5 in above the right eye brow
label: FAC

text: 3 Round swelling 2 in x2 in
label: FAC

text: On the right side of the head 1 2 in
label: FAC

text: above the ear there was a depressed fracture 2 in x2 in
label: FAC

text: underneath on the bone
label: FAC

text: 4 Transverse incised wound 1 1 2in x1 2 in xboneand brain deep on the head 1 in behind the middle of the right car
label: FAC

text: Brain matter was coming out of the wound
label: FAC

text: 5 Transverse incised wound 1 1 4in x 1 2 in x bone deep on the A head 3 in behind the upper part of the right car
label: FAC

text: The margins of injuries Nos 4 and 5 were clear cut smooth and well defined and angles on both the end were acute
label: FAC

text: It is significant that in answer to the last question put to Daryao Singh appellant in the Committing Magistrate s Court under Section 342 Criminal Procedure Code whether he had nothing else to say the first thing that came to his mind was that Asa Ram P W 1 and Bijai P W 10 and Raghubir deceased had killed his father about 15 years ago
label: ANALYSIS

text: The defense case seemed quite absurd
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was that Asa Ram and Bijai and Asghar after having killed Mukhtara and Raghubir haul come and attacked the three injured appellants at the time and place given by the prosecution
label: ANALYSIS

text: Their defense witness however in an obvious attempt to explain the injuries of the three appellants put forward the entirely new version that when Asa Bijai and Asghar were killing Mukhtara and Raghubir the three injuries appellants had attempted to save the murdered men and were injured as a consequence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused had even filed a First Information Report on these lines
label: ANALYSIS

text: They unsuccessfully tried to prosecute Asa and Bijai and Asghar who could not as the Trial Court and the High Court had rightly observed be expected to run berserk suddenly and attack persons on their own side for no explicable reason
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution had in addition to examining injured witnesses mentioned above produced Rattan Singh P W 2 Kalu P W 9 and Lakhi P W 7 whose testimony was discarded by it on two grounds firstly because each one was shown to have some enmity with some accused person and secondly because they were said to have been standing at a Harat nearly 400 paces away from where according to the High Court they could not have seen the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: If there was no obstruction to the range of vision and none was shown by evidence these witnesses could at least make out the number of assailants from this distance as sunlight was there
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution evidence suffered from some quite obvious infirmities
label: ANALYSIS

text: Each of the four injured eye witnesses while naming each of the eighteen accused persons as participants in the occurrence and specifying their weapons without any contradiction had failed to assign any particular part to any of them
label: ANALYSIS

text: Each injured witness said that all the eighteen accused persons named in the First information Report were assaulting the injured
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was hardly consistent with either the medical evidence or the very short time the whole occurrence was said to have lasted
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was physically impossible for all the eighteen accused persons to attack simultaneously each of the five victims
label: ANALYSIS

text: However we cannot interpret the impressions of rustic witnesses sought to be conveyed through their statements as though they were made in carefully drawn up documents calling for a literal interpretation
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was likely that each of them had seen some acts of some assailants but due to natural discrepancies in their accounts as each could only depose the part he had observed each had been instructed to omit this part of his testimony
label: ANALYSIS

text: That may explain how each consistently stated that all the accused persons were attackinghis or her party although he or she could not specify which accused attacked which victim
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the manner in which each witness could without making any mistake name each of the eighteen accused persons almost in the same order and specify the weapon each carried without any discrepancy some tutoring could be suspected
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nevertheless both the Trial Court and the High Court had reached the definite conclusion that the party of assailants consisted of more than five persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: It also found that this party was sitting on the boundary of the field of Daryao apparently waiting with their weapons for the buggi carrying Raghubir and Mukhtara and others to reach the spot where they surrounded it and attacked
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was clear from the nature and number of injuries of both sides which we have set out above in extenso that the attacking party must have consisted of more persons than the party of the male victims who were five in number
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if these five victims were sitting in the buggi they were not all empty handed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Some of them had lathis which they plied in self defence
label: ANALYSIS

text: The number and location of injuries on both sides also indicated an attack by a group of persons which must have surrounded the party traveling in the buggi
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if two persons are engaged in stopping the buggi and there are two on each of the two sides of the buggi their number would be six
label: ANALYSIS

text: Again even if at least one person is assumed to be the assailant of each of the victims in a simultaneous attack upon them the number of such assailants alone would come to at least six
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is however clear from the injuries on Mukhtara and Raghubir that each was attacked by more than one person because each had injuries with sharp edged weapons and lathis
label: ANALYSIS

text: these facts were enough to come to the conclusion that the total number of assailants could not conceivably have been less than five
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court however after giving the benefit of doubt to four of the accused persons on the ground that their cases did not differ from those of the others acquitted came to the obviously correct conclusion that at least the four appellants before us must have taken part in the attack because they admitted their participation in the occurrence which took place at the time and place of the incident in which Raghubir and Mukhtara had lost their lives
label: ANALYSIS

text: Three of the accused persons as already indicated had received injuries
label: ANALYSIS

text: On their own version these injuries were sustained in the same occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: If therefore the prosecution version about the broad character of the incident is correct the only question which remained was Against which accused person was the case of participation in the attack established beyond reason able doubt
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the admissions of the four accused corroborated by the injuries on the bodies of three OF them left no doubt whatsoever that they were in any case among the assailants
label: ANALYSIS

text: The others had merely been given the benefit of doubt lest some injustice is done by relying implicitly on partisan witnesses appearing in a type of case in which the innocent ale not infrequently sought to be roped in with the guilty who are of course not spared
label: ANALYSIS

text: This did not mean that the total number of assailants was actually less than five as the learned Counsel for the appellants asked us to presume from the fact that fourteen out of the eighteen accused persons were actually acquitted
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is true that the acquittal of an accused person does raise in the eye of law a presumption that he is innocent even if he was actually guilty
label: ANALYSIS

text: But it is only the acquitted accused person and not the convicted accused persons who can as a rule get the benefit of such a presumption
label: ANALYSIS

text: The effect of findings on questions of fact depends upon the nature of those findings
label: ANALYSIS

text: If for example only five known persons are alleged to have participated in an attack but the Courts find that two of them were falsely implicated it would be quite nature and logical to infer or presume that the participants were less than five in number
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the other hand if the Court holds that the assailants were actually five in number but there could be a doubt as to the identity of two of the alleged assailants and therefore acquits two of them the others will not get the benefit of doubt about the identity of the two accused so long as there is a firm finding based on good evidence and sound reasoning that the participants were five or more in number
label: ANALYSIS

text: Such a case is one of doubt only as to identity of some participants and not as to be total number of participants
label: ANALYSIS

text: It may be that a definite conclusion that the number of participants was at least five may be very difficult to reach whale the allegation of participation is confined to five known persons and there is doubt about the identity of even one
label: ANALYSIS

text: But where a large number of known persons such as eighteen as is the case before us are alleged to have participated and the Court acts on the principle that it is better to err on the side of safety so that no injustice is done to a possibly wrongly implicated accused and benefit of doubt is reaped by a large number with the result that their acquittal out of abundant caution reduces the number of those about whose participation there can be no doubt to less than five it may not be really difficult at all as it not in she case before us to recall the conclusion that having laggard to undeniable facts the number of participants could not possibly be less than five
label: ANALYSIS

text: We have for the reasons given above also reached the same conclusion as the learned Judges of the Allahabad High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: We wish that the High Court had itself given such reasons which are not at all difficult to find in this case so that its conclusion on the number of participants may not have appeared ratter abrupt
label: ANALYSIS

text: Justice has not only to be done but as have been often said must manifestly appear to be done
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if the number of assailants could have been less them five in the instant case which we think on the facts stated above was really not possible we think that the fact that the attacking party was clearly shown to have waited for the buggi to reach near the field of Daryao in the early hours of 7 6 1967 shows pre planning
label: ANALYSIS

text: Some Of the assailants had sharp edged weapons
label: ANALYSIS

text: They were obviously lying in wait for the buggi to arrive
label: ANALYSIS

text: They surrounded and attacked the occupants shouting that the occupants will be killed
label: ANALYSIS

text: We do not think that more convincing evidence of a pre concert was necessary
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore if we had thought it necessary we would not have hesitated to apply Section 34 I P C also to this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: The principle of vicarious liability does not depend upon the necessity to convict a required number of persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: It depends upon proof of facts beyond reasonabledoubt which makes such principle applicable
label: ANALYSIS

text: See Yehwant Anr v State of Maharashtra 1 and Sukh Ram v State of U P 2
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The most general and basic rule on a question such as the one we are considering is that there is no uniform inflexible or invariable rule applicable for arriving at what is really an inference form the totality of facts and circumstances which varies from case to case
label: ANALYSIS

text: We have to examine the elect of findings given in each case on this totality
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is rarely exactly identical with that in another case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Other rules are really subsidiary to this basic verity and depend for their correct application OF the peculiar facts and circumstances in the context of which they are enunciated
label: ANALYSIS

text: In Yeshwant s case supra the question was whether the acquit ah of an alleged participant said to be Brahmanand Tiwari for the murder of a man called Sukal could make it impossible to apply the principle of vicarious liability to convict under Section 302 34 I P C Yeshwant the only other participant in under
label: PRE_RELIED

text: This Court observed at p 303 The benefit of this doubt can only go to the appellant Brahmanand Tiwari and not to the other accused persons 13 who were known well to each eye witness Distinguishing Krishna Govind Patil v State of Maharashtra 3 this Court said in Yeshwant s case supra at p 302 We do not think that this decision which depends upon its own facts as criminal cases generally do lays down any general principle that where the identity of one of the participants is doubtful the whole case must end in acquittal
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Such a question belongs to the realm of facts and not of law The following cases were also cited before us Dalip Singh v State of Punjab 4 Bharwad Mepa Dana Anr v State of Bombay 5 Kartar Singh v State of Punjab 6 Mohan Singh v State of Punjab 7 Ram Bilas Singh Ors v State of Bihar 8
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In the case of Ram Bilas Singh supra previous decisions of this Court on the question argued before us have been considered at some length and a passage from Krishna Govind Patil s case supra was also quoted
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In none of these cases was it decided that where out of abundance of caution a large number of accuse l persons obtained an acquittal with the result that the number of those whose participation is established beyond reasonable doubt is reduced to less than five but at the same time it is clear that the total number of assailants could not be less than five the convicted accused persons must necessarily get the benefit of doubt arising in the case of the acquitted accused persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: A case like the one before us stands on the Same footing as any other case where there is certainty that the number of participants was not less than five but there is doubt only as to 1 1973 I S C R p 291 302 303 2 1974 2 S C R p 518 3 1964 1 S C R 678 4 1954 S C R 145 5 1960 2 S C R 172 6 1962 2 S C R 395 7 1962 Suppl 3 S C R 848 8 1964 1 S C R 775
label: ANALYSIS

text: The identity of some of the participants
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has to be remembered that doubts may arise with regard to the participation of a particular accused person in circumstances whose benefit can only be reaped by the accused who raises such doubt
label: ANALYSIS

text: Doubts may also arise about the veracity of the whole prosecution version and doubts about the participation of individual accused persons may contribute to the emergence of such doubts which may cover and engulf the whole case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Never the less if as in the instant case the Courts whose duty is to separate the chaff from the grain does hold that the convicted persons were certainly members of an unlawful assembly which must have consisted of more than five persons we do not see any principle of law or justice which could stand in the way of the application of Section 149 J P C for convicting those found indubitably guilty of participation in carrying out of the common object of an unlawful assembly
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only remaining question arises from the age of Om Pal Which at the time of trial was found by the Trial Court to be about 15 years
label: ANALYSIS

text: This means that Section 29 of the Uttar Pradesh Children Act 1951 was applicable to the case
label: STA

text: This Section reads as follows 29 Commitment of child to approved school 1 Where a child is found to have committed an offence punishable with transportation or imprisonment the Court if satisfied on inquiry that it is expedient so to deal with the child
label: STA

text: may order him to be sent to an approved school for such period of stay as will not exceed beyond the time when the child will attain the age of 18 years or for a shorter period the reasons for such period to be recorded in writing
label: STA

text: 2 Where prior to the commencement of this Act a youthful offender has been sentenced to transportation Or imprisonment the State Government may direct that in lieu of undergoing or completing such sentence he shall if under the age of sixteen years be sent to an approved school and thereupon the offender shall be subject to all the provisions of this Act as if he had been originally ordered to be detained in such school This question was not raised earlier so that the Trial Court or the High Court may take the action it was open to the Courts to take after due inquiry
label: STA

text: Such action if considered expedient could only be to send the appellant to an approved school
label: ANALYSIS

text: We may observed that although the appellant om Pal was said to be armed with a lathi no specific part was assigned to him by any prosecution witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: He was bound with the background of hostility between two sides and the events mentioned above to have been misled by the bad example of his elders
label: ANALYSIS

text: No previous participation in such a case and no previous conviction was shewn against him
label: ANALYSIS

text: We therefore think that appropriate action under Section 29 of the Children s Act could have been taken in his case if the question had been raised in time
label: RATIO

text: We hope that the punishment he has already undergone has had a salutary effect in making him conscious of the gravity of the consequences of joining an unlawful assembly
label: RATIO

text: All that we can do now in the circumstances of Om Pal s case is to recommend the remission of the remaining period of om Pal s sentence to the authorities concerned
label: RPC

text: Subject to the observations made above with regard to om Pal we affirm the convictions and sentences and dismiss this appeal P H P Appeal dismissed
label: PRE_RELIED

label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 Guru Hembrum Khuntia Son of Bene Hembrum Khuntia of village Balijodi P S Koira DistSundargarh 3
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of conclusion of argument 28 08 2018 Date of delivery of judgment 03 09 2018 OFFENCE U Ss 341 294 323 506 OF THE INDIAN PENAL CODE J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: The accused persons named above stand prosecuted for alleged commission of offence u s 341 294 323 506 of the Indian Penal Code hereinafter in short as IPC
label: FAC

text: 2 The story of the prosecution is that The complainant Sri Sidhakanhu Murmu was working in Bright Security Agency prior to one year of lodging this FIR
label: FAC

text: On 01 10 2018 he was working in S N Mohanty Nuagaon Crusher Unit
label: FAC

text: On that day at about 2 P M driver of one dumper bearing No OR14L 9267 of Maa Santoshi Transport brought iron ore from the crusher unit and parked the vehicle in front of the gate in such a way that no other vehicle could come inside the gate
label: FAC

text: When the complainant asked the driver of the dumper Nidhi Tiria accused to remove the vehicle and parked it in a proper way providing space to other vehicles he abused the complaint in obscene language and gave a push pressing his neck
label: FAC

text: After that Nidhi Tiria took his dumper outside and while leaving he threatened the complaint to kill him with the assistance of his friends
label: FAC

text: On 4 10 2008 while the complainant was on duty in the crusher plant at about 2 30 P M Nidhi Tiriwa Guru Hembrum Khuntia Suren Munda accused persons came there holding a lathi and abused him saying Sala Maagiha
label: FAC

text: Abusing so they assaulted the complainant and tore away his uniform shirt
label: FAC

text: The complainant sustained injury on his left hand and left elbow
label: FAC

text: On the basis of such FIR Koida P S Case No 93 dtd 5 8 2008 was registered and was investigated into by Sri Kartik Rout ASI of Koira P S After completion of investigation charge sheet has been submitted against the accused persons under the aforesaid offences 3
label: FAC

text: The plea of the defence is one of complete denial of this case
label: FAC

text: 4 The points for determination in this case are that a Whether on 04 10 2008 at about 2 30 P M at S N Mohanty Crusher Unit in village Nuagaon the accused persons in furtherance of their common intention wrongfully restrained the ________ __________________________________________________ informant while he was proceeding in any certain direction in which he had right to proceed b Whether on the same date time and place the accused persons in furtherance of their common intention abused the informant in obscene languages in or near a public place causing annoyance to him and others
label: ISSUE

text: c Whether on the same date time and place the accused persons in furtherance of their common intention has voluntarily caused hurt by means of lathi to the informant
label: ISSUE

text: d Whether the accused persons in furtherance of their common intention committed criminal intimidation by threatening the informant to kill 5 him which caused alarm to him and his mind
label: ISSUE

text: In order to prove its case Prosecution has examined as many as four witnesses out of which P W 3 is the complainant of this case and rest are witnesses to the occurrence
label: FAC

text: On the other hand no evidence was adduced by the defence on behalf of the accused to disprove the case
label: FAC

text: 6 P W 3 is the complainant of this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: He deposed in his evidence that he knew the accused persons involved in this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: In his deposition he said that this matter being an old one he did not remember the occurrence exactly
label: ANALYSIS

text: However about 10 years back due to dispute with the accused persons he lost his cool and lodged this FIR which is marked as Ext1 1 7
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 1 in his evidence stated that on 5 10 2008 he was working ASI of Koida P S On that day on receiving written report of the complainant Sidhakanhu Murmu IIC registered the Koira P S Case No 93 and directed him to take up investigation of this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 1 stated in his evidence that during investigation he visited the spot and examined the witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also seized wearing clothes of the complainant prepared the seizure list which is marked as Ext2
label: ANALYSIS

text: He ________ __________________________________________________ also sated that he issued injury requisition in favour of injured complainant and sent it to medical on 29 10 2008
label: ANALYSIS

text: He stated that he handed over the charge of investigation to the IIC of Koida P S on his transfer
label: ANALYSIS

text: 8 P W 2 in his evidence stated that on 15 12 2009 while he was working as ASI of police at Koida P S he took charge of investigation of this case from IIC Pradeep Kumar Sahu
label: ANALYSIS

text: On 26 12 2009 after completion of investigation he submitted charge sheet against Nidhi Tiria Guru Hembrum and Suren Munda u s 341 323 294 506 34 of IPC
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 P W 4 who is the Operational Manager in Security Office stated in his evidence that though he knew the complainant of this case he did not know the accused persons involved in this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: He stated in his evidence that about 10 years back from the date of his deposition he had scribed the FIR as per narration of Sidhakanhu Murmu
label: ANALYSIS

text: He marked his signature in the FIR as Ext1 3
label: ANALYSIS

text: He further stated that the uniform of the informant was seized in the Koida police station
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 The complainant in this case did not support the prosecution case
label: ANALYSIS

text: In his cross examination complainant stated that the matter was amicably settled in presence of village gentries and he did not want to proceed in the matter
label: ANALYSIS

text: In his cross examination he also stated that he did not know the contents of the FIR neither was he examined by police in connection with this case
label: ANALYSIS

text: P W 4 who is the scribe of the FIR also did not speak anything against the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: His cross examination also reveals that the matter was amicably settled in presence of village gentries and he had no direct knowledge regarding the occurrence
label: ANALYSIS

text: ___ 11 It is the mandate of law that the facts admitted need not be proved as per Section 58 of the Indian Evidence Act
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the instant case the complainant who is the victim of this case is denying any such assault on him by the accused persons
label: ANALYSIS

text: When the complainant himself is silent regarding the commission of any offence by the accused persons no further discussion is needed to establish the prosecution case
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12 On the contrary the I O in his evidence stated that on 5 10 2008 he was directed to investigate this case and on 29 10 2008 he issued injury requisition for medical examination of the complainant
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is also quite unbelievable
label: ANALYSIS

text: No other prosecution witness is supporting the prosecution case
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 In the end I am of the considered view that prosecution has failed miserably to prove the offences alleged against the accused persons with beyond all reasonable doubts
label: RATIO

text: 14 Considering the above analysis and further considering the above facts and circumstances it is held that the prosecution has failed to prove the offences u s 341 294 323 506 34 of Indian Penal Code against the accused persons beyond all reasonable doubts
label: RPC

text: In such premises I hold the accused persons not guilty and acquit them U s 248 1 of Cr P C
label: RPC

text: The accused persons be set at liberty forthwith if not required in any other case and their bail bonds stand cancelled
label: RPC

text: Enter this case as a mistake of facts for the statistical purpose
label: RPC

text: The seized articles if any be destroyed four months after the expiry of the appeal period and in case of appeal the same be disposed as per the order of the Hon ble Appellate Court
