label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No 135 of 1956 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 25 1955 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No 702 of 1955 and Referred No 77 of 1955 arising out of the judgment and order dated May 17 1955 of the Court of Sessions Judge at Moradavad in Sessions Trial No
label: NONE

text: P S Safeer for the appellant
label: NONE

text: G C Mathur and C P Lal for the respondent
label: NONE

text: November 21
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM
label: NONE

text: J The
label: RLC

text: appellant was sentenced to death for the marder of Daya Ram by shooting him with a country made pistol
label: RLC

text: He was also convicted for being in possession of an unlicensed firearm under the Arms Act for which offence he was sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment
label: RLC

text: He appealed to the High Court of Allahabad but his appeal was dismissed and the conviction and sentence was affirmed
label: RLC

text: Against the decision of the Allahabad High Court the appellant obtained special leave to appeal to this Court
label: FAC

text: According to the prosecution the occurrence took place at about midnight of July 4 1954 when Daya Ram was sleeping on a cot on a platform
label: FAC

text: Near him were sleeping Gokul Doongar and Jai Singh while two women Ratto and Bhuri slept in a room to the north of the platform and adjoining it
label: FAC

text: The report of the shot fired woke up these people
label: FAC

text: According to them they saw the appellant running towards the east
label: FAC

text: He was accompanied by three others who were armed with lathis
label: FAC

text: Daya Ram died almost instantaneously as the result of the injuries on his chest and stomach from where pellets were recovered at the time of the post mortem examination
label: FAC

text: Daya Ram had been shot from a close distance because the skin was charred over the entire area of the wound
label: FAC

text: Near the cot on which he slept a cartridge Ex I was found which was handed over to the Police Officer when he arrived for investigation
label: FAC

text: A first information report was lodged at the police station five miles away at 8 10 a m on July 5 1954
label: FAC

text: The motive for the murder as alleged by the prosecution was that on the death of one Bhai Singh the appellant hoped to become guardian of Ratto s property who however appointed Daya Ram to take charge of it
label: FAC

text: The appellant resented this very much
label: FAC

text: Three days before the murder of Daya Ram there had been a quarrel between the appellant and his wife on the one side and Ratto and Bhuri on the other
label: FAC

text: The quarrel arose over an attempt by the appellant to construct a wall over Ratto s land
label: FAC

text: The appellant uttered a threat that he would soon settle with the person on whom Ratto was depending that is to say the deceased Daya Ram
label: FAC

text: According to the High Court the defence did not seriously challenge these allegations and the appellant himself admitted that Ratto wanted him to be turned out of his house
label: FAC

text: The appellant was arrested on the night between July 5 and July 6 1954 at a village fourteen miles away from the village of occurrence Dhakeri
label: FAC

text: On July 7 he informed the Sub Inspector that he was prepared to produce the pistol Ex III
label: FAC

text: The SubInspector and the appellant went to village Dhakeri and Kartar Singh Mahtab Singh and Khamani were invited to witness the events that might follow
label: FAC

text: On reaching the appellant s house which adjoins the resid ential house of Ratto the appellant stated that the pistol Ex III had been concealed by him in a corn bin
label: FAC

text: From a secret place he took out a key and opened the lock of his house with it
label: FAC

text: He then took the SubInspector and the witnesses to a mud corn bin inside his house which appeared to be freshly plastered at one place
label: FAC

text: The appellant removed the plaster at this place and from inside took out the country made 12bore pistol Ex III and three live 12 bore cartridges
label: FAC

text: The cartridge Ex I which was found near the cot of Daya Ram and the pistol Ex III were sent to Shyam Narain a Deputy Superintendent of Police who is a fire arms expert of the C I D of Uttar Pradesh Government
label: FAC

text: He made scientific tests
label: FAC

text: He came to the conclusion as the result of the various tests made by him that the cartridge Ex I was fired from the pistol Ex III and no other fire arm
label: FAC

text: While the Sessions Judge believed the testimony of the eye witnesses the learned Judges of the High Court were of the opinion that they were unable to accept the assertion of the eye witnesses that they actually saw the appellant with a pistol by the bedside of the deceased
label: FAC

text: The High Court however relied upon the circumstantial evidence in the case in upholding the conviction of the appellant
label: FAC

text: There was motive for the crime and a few days before the killing of
label: FAC

text: Daya Ram the appellant had held out a threat against him
label: FAC

text: The appellant was arrested fourteen miles away from his village which is the place of occurrence
label: FAC

text: He produced a pistol Ex III from his house in circumstances which clearly showed that he only could have known of its existence there
label: FAC

text: The opinion of the fire arms expert clearly established that the cartridge Ex 1 found near the cot of Daya Ram was fired with the pistol Ex III produced by the appellant
label: FAC

text: All these circumstances in the opinion of the High Court left no doubt in the minds of the learned Judges of that Court that the appellant murdered Daya Ram by shooting him with his pistol
label: FAC

text: The learned Advocate for the appellant urged that the appellant could not have placed the pistol in his house and it must have been planted there by someone because none of the witnesses stated that they had seen him going to his house after the murder and the appellant was certainly not found in his house in the morning
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: According to the situation of the house of the appellant and where the witnesses were immediately after the occurrence it was impossible for the appellant to have entered his house without being seen
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It was further unlikely that after having committed the murder the appellant after having run away would return to his house
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Both the Courts below however found no reason to disbelieve the Sub Inspector and the witnesses that the appellant had produced the pistol Ex III from the corn bin inside his house
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant had the key of the house which was hidden in a secret place and the com bin was itself freshly plastered at one place
label: ANALYSIS

text: These circumstances clearly showed that no one but the appellant could haveknown of the existence of the pistol in the corn bin in his house
label: ANALYSIS

text: As to whether the appellant could or could not have gone to his house after the occurrence that is a matter of pure speculation
label: ANALYSIS

text: It does not appear that any witness was asked anything about it
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court found that the witnesses might have caught a glimpse of the people who were fast disappearing from the scene but who had no reasonable opportunity of marking their features
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the confusion of the occurrence the witnesses may not have observed where the culprits had disa speared except that they were seen running towards the east
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the record there is nothing to show that to enter the appellant s house after the occurrence the appellant had necessarily to go into his house within the view of the witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is quite unnecessary to examine this matter any further because the evidence concerning the production of the pistol Ex III by the appellant from his house is clear and reliable and therefore it is certain that the appellant did enter his house after the occurrence without being seen by anyone
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was next urged on behalf of the appellant that it was impossible for a cartridge to have been near the cot of Daya Ram because after the shot had been fired the cartridge would still remain in the barrel of the firearm
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: This again is pure speculation
label: ANALYSIS

text: That the cartridge was ejected from the fire arm is certain
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why it was ejected none can say
label: ANALYSIS

text: It may be that the miscreant reloaded his weapon to meet any emergency
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of the Sub Inspector is clear that on his arrival at the place of occurrence the cartridge Ex I was handed over to him by the witness Khamani who cannot be said to be unfavorable to the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Courts below had no reason to disbelieve the evidence in the case that the cartridge Ex I was found near the cot of Daya Ram and we can find no extraordinary circumstance to justify us saying that the Courts below took an erroneous view of the evidence
label: ANALYSIS

text: On the facts found there was a motive for the murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: Apparently for no good reason the appellant was not found at his house on the morning of July 5 but was in a village fourteen miles away at the time of his arrest
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant produced the pistol Ex III in circumstances clearly showing that he had deliberately kept it concealed
label: ANALYSIS

text: We have no reason to doubt the evidence in this respect
label: ANALYSIS

text: The real question is whether it is safe to act upon the opinion of the fire arms expert that the cartridge Ex I was fired from the pistol Ex III produced by the appellant and none other because without that evidence the circumstantial evidence in the case would be insufficient to convict the appellant of the crime of murder
label: ANALYSIS

text: The opinion of the fire arms expert based on the result of his tests does not seem to have been challenged in cross examination or before the High Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: If there is no reason to think that there is any room for error in matters of this kind and it is safe to accept the opinion of the expert then clearly it is established that the cartridge Ex I found near the cot of Daya Ram was fired from the pistol Ex III produced by the appellant
label: ANALYSIS

text: To satisfy ourselves we have looked into the works of some authors dealing with the marks left on cartridges and shell cases by fire arms in order to ascertain that there is no error in the opinion of the fire arms expert in the present case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Kirk in his book Crime Investigation at page 346 states Fired cases are less often encountered in criminal investigation than are bullets but when found they are usually of greater significance because they receive at least as clear markings as do bullets have a greater variety of such markings and are not ordinarily damaged in firing
label: ANALYSIS

text: The questions which may be asked as a result of finding such materials are similar to those that require answers when only bullets are located
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the ordinary case quite definite answers can be given
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is true both of shotgun shells and of cartridge cases from pistols revolvers and rifles
label: ANALYSIS

text: In general it is possible to identify a certain firearm as having fired a particular shell or cartridge
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is often possible to identify the type or make of gun which fired it though in many instances this must be tentative or probable identification only
label: ANALYSIS

text: After dealing with the marks left by breech block firing pin impressions marks from extractors and ejectors marks due to expansion magazine marks and loading mechanism marks he states Summarizing the cartridge or shell case us ally carries markings which are quite distinctive of the gun in which the charge is fired and can be used for positive identification of the latter
label: ANALYSIS

text: Those marks arise from a variety of contacts with various parts of the gun an analysis of which is useful in determining the type of weapon in case no suspected gun is available
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus the recovered shell or cartridge case is one of the most useful types of physical evidence which can be found in shooting cases
label: ANALYSIS

text: Soderman and O Connel in their book Modern Criminal Investigation also deal with the subject and they refer to the marks from the fire pin the extractor the ejector and the breech block
label: ANALYSIS

text: After referring to comparison being made of the cartridge or shell fired from a fire arm for the purpose of test they state at page 200 If they are in the same position in relation to one another and their general appearance is the same one may conclude that they have been fired from a pistol of the same make
label: ANALYSIS

text: An absolute conclusion about the origin of the shells however can be reached only after a photomicrographic examination of the markings from the breech block on the rear of the shell Identification with the aid of the enlargement should not prove difficult
label: ANALYSIS

text: The characteristic scratches can be easily seen
label: ANALYSIS

text: A photograph of the incriminating shell and one of a comparison shell should be pasted side by side on cardboard and the characteristic marks should be recorded with lines and ciphers following the same method as that used in the identification of fingerprints In Taylor s book on Medical Jurisprudence Tenth Edition Vol 1 at page 459
label: ANALYSIS

text: it is stated It is never safe to say that a cartridge case was not fired from a given pistol unless the marks are quite194 different and a case which bears no marks at all may quite well have been fired from the same pistol as one which leaves well defined marks
label: ANALYSIS

text: In general however though it is unlikely that all marks will be equally good it is usually possible to obtain definite information from the marks of the firing pin extractor ejector or breech block on the base or rim or from grooves or scratches on the surface
label: ANALYSIS

text: In weapons of the same manufacture the marks are of the same general nature but in each weapon there are individual differences which usually enable it to be definitely identified
label: ANALYSIS

text: The expert s evidence in this case shows that he had fired four test cartridges from the pistol Ex III
label: ANALYSIS

text: He found the individual characteristics of the chamber to have been impressed upon the test cartridges Exs 9 and 10 and that exactly identical markings were present on the paper tube of the cartridge Ex 1
label: ANALYSIS

text: He made microphotographs of some of these individual marks on Exs 1 and 10
label: ANALYSIS

text: In giving his reasons for his opinion the fire arms expert stated that every fire arm has individual characteristics on its breach face striking pin and chamber
label: ANALYSIS

text: When a cartridge is fired gases are generated by the combustion of the powder creating a pressure of 2 to 20 tons per square inch
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under the effect of this pressure the cap and the paper tube of the cartridge cling firmly with the breach face striking pin and chamber and being of a softer matter
label: ANALYSIS

text: the individualities of these parts are impressed upon them
label: ANALYSIS

text: By firing a number of test cartridges from a given fire arm and comparing them under a microscope with the evidence cartridge it can definitely be stated if the marks are clear whether the evidence cartridges had been fired or not from that fire arm
label: ANALYSIS

text: It seems to us that the fire arms expert made the necessary tests and was careful in what he did
label: RATIO

text: There is no good reason for distrusting his opinion
label: RATIO

text: The learned Judges of the High Court examined the micro photographs in question and were satisfied that there was no ground for distrusting the evidence of the expert
label: RATIO

text: They were accordingly justified in coming to the conclusion that the cartridge Ex 1 found nor the cot of Dava Ram was fired from the pistol Ex III produced by the appellant from his house
label: RATIO

text: There can therefore be no room for thinking in the circumstances established in this case that any one else other than the appellant might have shot Daya Ram
label: RATIO

text: He was therefore rightly convicted for the offence of murder
label: RPC

text: The appeal is accordingly dismissed
label: RPC

text: IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT BOMBAY CIVIL
label: PREAMBLE

text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION
label: PREAMBLE

text: CIVIL WRIT PETITION No 4171 of 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: Vijay Dinkarrao Patil and Anr
label: PREAMBLE

text: Petitioners
label: PREAMBLE

text: Vs
label: PREAMBLE

text: The State of Maharashtra ors Respondents ALONG WITH CIVIL
label: PREAMBLE

text: WRIT PETITION No 4243 of 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: Sheetal Ajit Patil
label: PREAMBLE

text: Petitioner
label: PREAMBLE

text: Vs The State of Maharashtra ors
label: PREAMBLE

text: Respondents Shri V P Sawant Advocate i
label: PREAMBLE

text: by Shri Vinod Y Jadhav Advocate for
label: PREAMBLE

text: the petitioners in W P No 4171 of 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: Shri Nikhil Chavan for the petitioner in W P No 4243 of 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: Shri A B Vagyani Government Pleader for Respondent Nos 1 to 7 in both the petitions
label: PREAMBLE

text: CORAM A S OKA A S CHANDURKAR JJ RESERVED ON 22nd July 2014 PRONOUNCED ON 13th August 2014
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT PER A S CHANDURKAR J
label: PREAMBLE

text: 1 Rule Rule made returnable forthwith and heard finally with the consent of parties
label: FAC

text: 2 The challenge in both these writ petitions is to orders dated 3rd April 2014 issued by the Additional District Magistrate Satara directing the petitioners to deposit their licenced weapons with the concerned police station in view of then ensuing elections to the Loksabha in May 2014
label: FAC

text: Since similar issue arises in both these writ petitions they are being decided by this common judgment
label: FAC

text: 3 In Writ Petition No 4171 of 2014 both the petitioners were issued licence under the Arms Act 1959
label: FAC

text: The licences of both the petitioners were subsisting
label: FAC

text: According to the petitioners in the first week of April 2014 they were informed by the police authorities that there was a directive from the office of the Collector for depositing their weapons with the concerned police station
label: FAC

text: On 3rd April 2014 a communication was issued by the Additional District Magistrate Satara respondent No 2 calling upon them to deposit their weapons with the concerned police station
label: FAC

text: According to the petitioners they made a representation to the Sub Divisional Officer and Assistant Election Officer as well as to the Senior Inspector of Police that there was no general direction requiring all licenced holders to deposit their weapons
label: FAC

text: However there was no response from the authorities
label: FAC

text: The aforesaid communication dated 3rd April 2014 is the subject matter of challenge in the said writ petition
label: FAC

text: Similarly the decision of the Screening Committee arrived at pursuant to the meetings held on 20th March 2014 and 3rd April 2014 is also under challenge
label: FAC

text: 4 In Writ Petition No 4243 of 2014 it is the case of the petitioner that she is holding a licence under the Arms Act 1959 which licence is subsisting
label: FAC

text: The petitioner was issued communication dated 3rd April 2014 by respondent No 2 calling upon the petitioner to deposit her weapon with the concerned police station
label: FAC

text: The petitioner made a representation on 12th April 2014 to the Sub Divisional Officer and Assistant Election Officer as well as to the Senior Inspector of Police
label: FAC

text: As according to the petitioner such general directions could not have been given to all licenced holders to deposit their weapons she has challenged communication dated 3rd April 2014 issued by the Additional District Magistrate dated 3rd April 2014
label: FAC

text: Similarly the decision of the Screening Committee taken pursuant to the meeting held on 20th March 2014 and 3rd April 2014 is also under challenge
label: FAC

text: 5 Shri V P Sawant the learned Advocate appearing for the petitioners in Writ Petition No 4171 of 2014 has submitted that the direction issued by the Additional District Magistrate is contrary to law and in breach of the directions issued by the Division Bench of this Court in the case of Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve Vs Vikram Kumar and others reported in 2009 3 Mh LJ Cri 471
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It is submitted that the Screening Committee without examining the necessity of issuing a direction to the petitioners to deposit their weapons has proceeded to issue general directions to all licenced weapon holders to deposit their weapons without there being any justification for the same
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It was further urged that the aforesaid action was in contravention of the directives issued by the Election Commissioner in its letter dated 13th March 1996
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It was therefore submitted that the impugned decision dated 3rd April 2014 taken in the meetings of the Screening Committee is illegal and is required to be set aside
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 6 Shri Nikhil Chavan the learned Advocate for the petitioner in Writ petition No 4243 of 2014 has reiterated the submissions made on behalf of the petitioner in Writ Petition No 4171 of 2014
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: He has also submitted that without screening the case of the petitioner a general direction has been issued to deposit the licenced weapon
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: It is further urged that no such blanket directions had been issued in other adjoining districts of Satara District and the impugned action was therefore arbitrary and discriminatory
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 7 Shri A B Vagyani the learned Government Pleader appearing for the respondents in both the writ petitions has urged that the impugned communication calling upon the petitioners to deposit their licenced weapons has been taken pursuant to the decision taken by the Screening Committee
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It is submitted that the judgment in the case of Govind Bhai Ganesh supra was taken into account by the Screening Committee and thereafter the aforesaid directions came to be issued
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The learned Government Pleader also relied upon Guidelines dated 17th August 2009 issued by the Home Department as well as communication dated 20th June 2014 issued to all Police Commissioners and District Magistrates directing them to follow guidelines dated 17th August 2009 scrupulously
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The decision to direct deposit of arms by licence holders has been taken pursuant to the directions issued under Article 324 of the Constitution of India by the Election Commission of India
label: ANALYSIS

text: On 13th March 1996 said directions were issued by the Election Commission for the purposes of holding free and fair elections
label: ANALYSIS

text: The said directions read as under In exercise of the powers conferred on the Commissioner under Article 324 of the Constitution of India and all other powers enabling it in this behalf and in supersession of all other instructions the Commission hereby orders that the following instructions shall be observed during all future elections 1 Issue of licence for arms will be totally prohibited during the period commencing with the date of announcement of elections This ban will continue to be operative till the completion of the election as notified
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2 The police should be directed to be vigilant and asked to start mopping up operations of the areas infested with known goonda and other bad elements right from the date of announcement of elections
label: ANALYSIS

text: During such mopping up operations special attentions should be paid to unearth and seize unlicensed arms and ammunition
label: ANALYSIS

text: A very thorough search and seizure by the State Police of unlicensed arms and places of indigenous manufacture of arms and ammunition shall be carried out and persons involved shall be arrested
label: ANALYSIS

text: While unearthing and seizure of unlicensed weapons is a normal ongoing responsibility of the police it shall be vigorously intensified during the election period
label: ANALYSIS

text: Interstate and intraState movements of trucks and commercial vehicles shall be strictly checked with a view to preventing smuggling of arms and ammunition and antisocial elements
label: ANALYSIS

text: Raids should be carried out regularly and intensively on underground arms factories 3 Immediately after the announcement of elections District Magistrates shall make a detailed and individual review and assessment in accordance with the prevalent state laws of all licence holders so that licensed arms in those cases where they consider it essential are impounded in order to ensure maintenance of law and order so essential for ensuring free and fair elections
label: ANALYSIS

text: These arms should be deposited with the district authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: Among cases which may need to be reviewed are the following
label: ANALYSIS

text: 1 persons released on bail 2 persons having a history of criminal offences and 3 persons previously involved in rioting at any time any but especially during the election period
label: ANALYSIS

text: The above categories are only illustrative and not exhaustive
label: ANALYSIS

text: After such review all such licence holders who are identified shall be directed to deposit their arms with the District Administration during the period of one week from the last date for withdrawal of candidatures
label: ANALYSIS

text: 5 The District Administration shall make fool proof arrangements for keeping the deposited fire arms in safe custody
label: ANALYSIS

text: Proper receipt must be given to the licence holders depositing the fire arms
label: ANALYSIS

text: It shall be the bounden duty of the District Administration to ensure that all fire arms deposited with the Administration are returned to the licence holders immediately after one week after the declaration of results
label: ANALYSIS

text: 6 Prohibitory orders under Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code 1973 shall be issued banning the carrying of licensed arms as soon as an election is announced and should be effective till the declaration of results 9 A perusal of aforesaid directions reveals that the District Magistrate is required to make a detailed and individual review and assessment of all license holders so as to consider the impounding arms of such licence holders as found necessary to ensure maintenance of law and order during elections
label: ANALYSIS

text: Certain categories of cases has been enumerated and it has been stated that said cases would be required to be reviewed
label: ANALYSIS

text: As aforesaid directions have been issued in exercise of powers conferred by Article 324 of the Constitution of India the same have binding effect
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 In the case of Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve supra the Division Bench of this Court considered the aforesaid directions issued by the Election Commission in its letter dated 13th March 1996
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was noted that under said directions a detailed individual review and assessment of all licence holders was necessary so as to enable the District Magistrate to consider cases where it was essential to direct the licence holders to deposit the arms
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was emphasized that there could not be a blanket directions to all arms licence holders to deposit their weapons
label: ANALYSIS

text: After noticing that there was no screening committee to review cases for issuing directions to deposit arms in terms of directions issued by the Election Commission and that there was no prior review and assessment of individual cases various guidelines were laid down by this Court
label: ANALYSIS

text: A Screening Committee consisting of a District Magistrate and the Superintendent of Police was directed to be constituted
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was further directed that cases of all licence holders should be placed before the Screening Committee and after conducting the exercise of screening the concerned licence holder could be directed to deposit his arms forthwith
label: ANALYSIS

text: The guidelines issued in Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve supra read as under a There shall be a Screening Committee in every District and in every Commissionerate area
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In the District the Screening Committee shall consist of the District Magistrate and the Superintendent of Police
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In the Commissionerate area it shall consist of the Commissioner of Police and Joint Additional Commissioner of Police Admn
label: PRE_RELIED

text: b The Screening Committee shall commence the work of screening from the day of declaration of dates of election by the Election Commission
label: PRE_RELIED

text: c Cases of all the license holders as laid down by the Election Commission in its directive shall be placed before the Screening Committee
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The categories are i Persons released on bail ii Persons having a history of criminal offences and iii Persons involved in rioting at any time but especially during the election period
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The Screening Committee shall bear in mind that the above categories are only illustrative and not exhaustive
label: PRE_RELIED

text: d The Screening committee shall complete the exercise of screening in respect of licences placed before it as far as possible before the 1st date of filing of nominations
label: PRE_RELIED

text: e On receipt of report from the Screening Committee the licensing authority shall issue notice before the last date fixed for withdrawal of candidature to the individual licence holder for depositing his arms and inform the licence holder that failure to deposit the arms as directed would result in prosecution under Section 188 of the I P C as stated in clause h f
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The licence holder thereafter shall deposit his arms forthwith and in any case within a period of seven days from the date of receipt of the notice
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The licensing Authority shall give proper receipt to the license holder
label: PRE_RELIED

text: g The decision taken by the Screening Committee shall be final
label: PRE_RELIED

text: h Any licence holder who fails to deposit arms within the period specified above shall be liable for prosecution under section 188 of Indian Penal Code
label: PRE_RELIED

text: i All the arms so deposited with the administration be returned to the licence holder within a period of one week after declaration of election results
label: PRE_RELIED

text: j The above timeframe should be adhered to as far as possible
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 11 Pursuant to the aforesaid judgment the Home Department of the State of Maharashtra has issued certain guidelines on 17th August 2009
label: ANALYSIS

text: The said guidelines read as under a There shall be a Screening Committee in every District and in every Commissionerate area
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the District the Screening Committee shall consist of the District Magistrate and the Superintendent of Police
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the Commissionerate area it shall consist of the Commissioner of Police and Joint Additional Commissioner of Police Admn
label: ANALYSIS

text: b The Screening Committee shall commence the work of screening from the day of declaration of dates of election by the Election Commission
label: ANALYSIS

text: c Cases of all the license holders as laid down by the Election Commission in its directive shall be placed before the Screening Committee
label: ANALYSIS

text: The categories are i Persons released on bail ii Persons having a history of criminal offences and iii Persons involved in rioting at any time but especially during the election period
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Screening Committee shall bear in mind that the above categories are only illustrative and not exhaustive
label: ANALYSIS

text: d The Screening committee shall complete the exercise of screening in respect of licences placed before it as far as possible before the 1st date of filing of nominations
label: ANALYSIS

text: e On receipt of report from the Screening Committee the licensing authority shall issue notice before the last date fixed for withdrawal of candidature to the individual licence holder for depositing his arms and inform the licence holder that failure to deposit the arms as directed would result in prosecution under Section 188 of the I P C as stated in clause h f
label: ANALYSIS

text: The licence holder thereafter shall deposit his arms forthwith and in any case within a period of seven days from the date of receipt of the notice
label: ANALYSIS

text: The licensing Authority shall give proper receipt to the license holder
label: ANALYSIS

text: g The decision taken by the Screening Committee shall be final
label: ANALYSIS

text: h Any licence holder who fails to deposit arms within the period specified above shall be liable for prosecution under section 188 of Indian Penal Code
label: ANALYSIS

text: i All the arms so deposited with the administration be returned to the licence holder within a period of one week after declaration of election results
label: ANALYSIS

text: j The above timeframe should be adhered to as far as possible 12 In the meetings of the Screening Committee held on 20th March 2014 and 3rd April 2014 a blanket decision was taken calling upon about 732 arms licence holders to deposit their arms with the concerned authority
label: ANALYSIS

text: The said minutes indicate that each case was not independently reviewed as per the directions issued by the Election Commission on 13th March 1996 and the guidelines issued in terms of the judgment of this Court in Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve s case
label: ANALYSIS

text: Pursuant to the aforesaid meetings the impugned orders have been issued in both these writ petitions directing the petitioners to deposit their arms with the police authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is therefore obvious that the screening committee without examining the individual cases of the petitioners has directed them to deposit their arms
label: ANALYSIS

text: The object behind directing deposit of arms is to ensure holding of free and fair elections and maintenance of law and order
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is with that object that a direction has been issued to review each case individually
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is therefore clear that the impugned orders issued in both these writ petitions are in contravention of the directions dated 13th March 1996 issued by the Election Commission as well as guidelines dated 17th August 2009 issued by the Home Department pursuant to the judgment in Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve s case supra
label: ANALYSIS

text: On this short ground the impugned orders are required to be set aside
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13 It is to be noted that the directions issued by the Election Commission on 13th March 1996 are clear that it is necessary to make a detailed individual review and assessment of all licence holders
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the said directions some categories have been illustrated and cases falling in the said categories are required to be reviewed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Said directions were reiterated in the guidelines laid down by this Court in Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve s case supra
label: ANALYSIS

text: Despite guidelines dated 17th August 2009 having been issued it is noticed that the same are not at all being followed in their true letter and spirit
label: ANALYSIS

text: Blanket orders are being passed directing all licence holders to deposit their arms with the police authorities
label: ANALYSIS

text: As observed by this Court in Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve s case supra a law abiding citizen who has been issued a licence to possess arms can consider the order directing him to surrender his arms as an affront to his dignity and status
label: ANALYSIS

text: Despite clear directions being issued by the Election Commission it is to be noted that the Screening Committee has failed to implement the same
label: ANALYSIS

text: Similarly guidelines dated 17th August 2009 are also not being scrupulously followed
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14 At this stage it would be necessary to note the anomaly in the guidelines dated 17th August 2009 issued by the Home Department
label: ANALYSIS

text: In direction No 3 dated 13th March 1996 issued by the Election Commission while emphasizing the need to make an individual review and assessment of all licence holders it has been directed that there are category of cases in which review would be necessary
label: ANALYSIS

text: emphasis supplied
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is further stated that said categories were only illustrative and not exhaustive
label: ANALYSIS

text: Guideline c issued on 17th August 2009 reads as under c Cases of all the license holders as laid down by the Election Commission in its directive shall be placed before the Screening Committee
label: ANALYSIS

text: The categories are i Persons released on bail ii Persons having a history of criminal offences and iii Persons involved in rioting at any time but especially during the election period
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Screening Committee shall bear in mind that the above categories are only illustrative and not exhaustive 15 The guidelines merely categorize persons released on bail persons having history of criminal offences and persons involved in rioting especially during election period
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has not been mentioned in the said guidelines that cases of persons falling in such categories are required to be reviewed
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus the emphasis placed by the Election Commission on the need to review cases of such license holders falling in the aforesaid categories has been lost sight of by the Home Department while issuing guidelines dated 17th August 2009
label: ANALYSIS

text: The aforesaid categories comprise of such persons who though are issued arms licences could be involved in acts resulting in law and order situation
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence directions in that regard have been issued by the Election Commission that cases of such persons are required to be reviewed
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Home Department would therefore be required to modify the said guidelines to bring them in tune with direction No 3 issued by the Election Commission on 13th March 1996
label: ANALYSIS

text: This will ensure compliance with the aforesaid directions in their true letter and spirit
label: ANALYSIS

text: 16 It is further noticed that the State Government has not framed any guidelines whatsoever with regard to functioning of the screening committee
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though the Screening Committee has been constituted in terms of guidelines issued in Govind Bhai Ganesh Tilve s case supra there are no guidelines with regard to manner in which the said Screening Committee shall function
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Screening Committee will have to peruse the record of all licence holders
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Committee should have access to the police record of all the licence holders
label: ANALYSIS

text: The guidelines should provide that a detailed review and assessment of individual cases be made
label: ANALYSIS

text: Considering its nature of work and the duty assigned to it it is necessary that the State Government frames appropriate guidelines with regard to functioning of the Screening Committee
label: ANALYSIS

text: As the Screening Committee has been assigned the duty of individual review and assessment of cases of all licence holders it would be appropriate if the State Government issues guidelines to enable the Screening Committee to function in a responsible and transparent manner
label: ANALYSIS

text: This would also ensure compliance with the directions issued by the Election Commission under Article 324 of the Constitution of India
label: ANALYSIS

text: 17 In view of the aforesaid we pass the following order ORDER A Both the writ petitions are allowed B The impugned orders dated 3rd April 2014 issued by the Additional District Magistrate Satara in both the writ petitions is quashed and set aside C The Home Department of the State of Maharashtra shall take all necessary steps to reframe guideline c issued on 17th August 2009 in terms of observations made in paragraphs 14 and 15 of this judgment D The Home Department of the State of Maharashtra is directed to issue guidelines in the matter of functioning of the Screening Committee constituted for review of the cases of licenced arms holders within a period of six weeks from today E Both the writ petitions
label: RPC

text: shall stand disposed of in the aforesaid terms with no order as to costs F For reporting compliance in the matter of framing of guidelines with regard to functioning of the Screening Committee
label: RPC

text: the matter shall be placed on board on 22nd September 2014 under the caption of directions
label: RPC

text: A S CHANDURKAR J A S OKA J
label: NONE

text: IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
label: PREAMBLE

text: Date of decision September 3 2007 R 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: ITR 553 of 1983
label: PREAMBLE

text: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX
label: PREAMBLE

text: Petitioner
label: PREAMBLE

text: Through Mr J R Goel Advocate versus M
label: PREAMBLE

text: S KWALITY ICE CREAM
label: PREAMBLE

text: Respondent
label: PREAMBLE

text: Through Mr Ajay Vohra with Ms Kavita Jha and Mr
label: PREAMBLE

text: Rahul Yadavi Advocates
label: PREAMBLE

text: CORAM HON BLE MR JUSTICE MADAN B LOKUR HON BLE DR JUSTICE S MURALIDHAR 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: Whether Reporters of local papers may be allowed to see the judgment
label: PREAMBLE

text: YES 2
label: PREAMBLE

text: To be referred to the Reporter or not
label: PREAMBLE

text: YES 3
label: PREAMBLE

text: Whether the judgment should be reported in Digest
label: PREAMBLE

text: YES ORDER
label: PREAMBLE

text: In this reference relevant to the Assessment Year 1976 77 the following question of law has been referred for our opinion under Section 256 1 of the Income Tax Act 1961 Act
label: ISSUE

text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the liability to pay the sales tax of Rs 4 24 029 made up of Rs 3 22 482 being refund of sales tax received by the assessee during the relevant year and Rs 1 01 507 being provision for sales tax made in the accounting period relevant to the assessment year 1976 77 was chargeable to tax to the total income of the assessee
label: ISSUE

text: In so far as the first part of the question is concerned whether the liability to pay sales tax of Rs 3 22 482 being refund of sales tax received by the assessee during the relevant year was chargeable to tax learned counsel for the parties are agreed that in view of the decision in Polyflex India Pvt Limited v Commissioner of Income Tax 2002 257 ITR 343 SC this part of the question is required to be answered in the affirmative that is in favour of the Revenue and against the assessee
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The second part of the question is whether the liability to pay sales tax on the amount of Rs 1 01 507 being provision for sales tax made in the accounting period relevant to the assessment year 1976 77 is chargeable to tax
label: ANALYSIS

text: The admitted position is that the assessee is following the mercantile system of accounting
label: ANALYSIS

text: Initially there was some dispute whether the ice cream sold by the assessee was exigible to tax or not
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Court in its judgment dated 27th March 1974 held that the ice cream manufactured and sold by the assessee was not exigible to sales tax
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Revenue was not satisfied with the decision rendered by this Court and preferred an appeal which remained pending before the Supreme Court
label: FAC

text: Ultimately it was decided by the Supreme Court on 6 th September 1995
label: FAC

text: It is common ground that the decision of the Supreme Court affirmed the decision of this Court that the assessee was not liable to pay sales tax on the ice cream sold by it
label: FAC

text: During the pendency of the the appeal preferred by the Revenue in the Supreme Court the assessee made a provision of Rs 1 01 507 for sales tax in the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1976 77
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to learned counsel for the Revenue this provision was not required to be made since this Court had declared that no sales tax was payable on the sale of ice cream and further the Supreme Court also did not grant a stay of the operation of the judgment of this Court
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Learned counsel for the Revenue submitted that since the assessee did not in fact pay any sales tax on the sale of ice cream in the relevant previous year there was no question of any provision for sales tax being made
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Learned counsel for the Assessee has drawn our attention to the decision of the Supreme Court in Kedarnath Jute Manufacturing Co Limited v Commissioner of Income Tax 1971 82 ITR 363 wherein it has been held that the moment a dealer makes either a purchase or sale of any commodity subject to sales tax the obligation to pay the tax arises
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Although that liability could not be enforced till quantification was effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax was independent of the assessment
label: ANALYSIS

text: Since the assessee was following the mercantile system of accounting it was entitled to make a provision for and therefore deduct from the profits and gains of its business the liability to pay sales tax
label: ANALYSIS

text: The liability did not cease to be a liability merely because the assessee had disputed it
label: ANALYSIS

text: So long as the appeal filed by the Revenue was pending before the Supreme Court the liability had accrued in so far as the assessee was concerned
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Allahabad High Court in J K Synthetics Limited v O S Bajpai ITO Central Circle V Kanpur 1976 105 ITR 864 has held that an assessee is entitled to claim deduction in respect of the liability of excise duty for which it had made a provision in its account books
label: PRE_RELIED

text: This view was upheld by the Hon ble Supreme Court in Union of India v J K Synthetics Limited 1993 199 ITR 14
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The Supreme Court held that since under Section 41 of the Act the liability to tax would depend on the outcome of the appeal there would be no prejudice to the department if the provision is made and the assessment is made on that basis
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Section 41 1 Act envisages that where the assessee has obtained some benefit in respect of a trading liability by way of remission or cessation thereof the amount obtained by the assessee or the value of benefit accruing to him shall be deemed to be profits and gains of business for that year in which such remission or cessation occurs and would accordingly be chargeable to income tax as the income of that relevant previous year
label: STA

text: There would be no loss of tax in so far as the Revenue is concerned
label: ANALYSIS

text: It can now tax in the Assessment Year 1996 97 the entire amount provided for by the assessee towards sales tax liability
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under the circumstances we answer the second part of the question in the negative that is in favour of the assessee and against the revenue
label: RPC

text: The reference is disposed of accordingly
label: RPC

text: MADAN B LOKUR J S MURALIDHAR J SEPTEMBER 03 2007 rk
label: NONE

text: Non Reportable IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CRIMINAL APPEAL Nos 407 408 of 2009 Mohd Akhtar Kari Ors Appellants Versus Respondents State of Bihar Anr J U D G M E N T
label: PREAMBLE

text: L NAGESWARA RAO J
label: NONE

text: 1 In these Appeals we are concerned with the correctness of the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Patna by which the judgment of the trial court was set aside and the acquittal of the Appellants was reversed
label: FAC

text: The High Court convicted the Appellants under Section 302 read with Sections 34 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code 1860 the IPC and sentenced them to undergo life imprisonment
label: RLC

text: 2 We are informed that the Appellant Nos 1 2 and 4 died during the pendency of these Appeals and so the Appeals filed by them abate
label: FAC

text: On the statement of the informant Md Abu Daud PW 6 the fardbeyan was recorded by the Officer Incharge of Matihani Police Station at 9 00 p m on 05 01 1984
label: FAC

text: He stated that along with his brother Md Nadir Sah Jumma deceased he had gone to the house of Md Mobin PW 4 for collecting irrigation dues
label: FAC

text: They were basking by the ghura fire place at Md Mobin s darwaza
label: FAC

text: A mob of 10 11 persons armed with pistols rifles and gun came there at that time
label: FAC

text: The informant identified seven out of eleven persons
label: FAC

text: Md Chamru Sahadat was armed with gun Noor Alam with rifle Md Jam Alam Appellant No 4 with gun and Md Kari Akhtar Appellant No 1 Md Samad and
label: FAC

text: Md Sanjat Appellant No 3 also had fire arms
label: FAC

text: Immediately after the mob reached the accused Md Chamru Sahadat warned that nobody should try to escape and then Md Sanjat Appellant No 3 fired one shot which did not hit anybody
label: FAC

text: The informant Md Nadir Sah Jumma deceased and Md Mobin PW 4 started running and all the accused chased them
label: FAC

text: The informant hid himself by the side of a Simal tree from where he saw his brother Md Nadir Sah Jumma deceased being surrounded by the accused near the southern wall of the house of one Samshul
label: FAC

text: After being surrounded the deceased Md Nadir Sah Jumma was shot dead by Md Chamru Sahadat Md Jan Alam and Noor Alam
label: FAC

text: The accused fled towards the village and soon after the informant and Md Mobin rushed to where the deceased was lying and found that he was hit by the bullets
label: FAC

text: They started shouting for help
label: FAC

text: Md Adil Md Ataul Rehman and several others came
label: FAC

text: They were informed about the incident by the informant
label: FAC

text: 3 On completion of the investigation a charge sheet was filed under Sections 148 and 302 read with Section 149 IPC against seven persons out of whom one of the accused Md Samad died and Md Chamru Sahadat and Noor Alam absconded
label: FAC

text: The remaining accused i e the Appellants herein faced trial for the charges framed under Sections 148 and 302 read with Section 149 IPC
label: FAC

text: According to PW 9 Bishram Das who was the investigating officer the information was received at 7 45 p m on 05 01 1984 that 2 3 shots were hurled and one person killed in Saidpur village
label: FAC

text: After recording S D Entry No 65 he proceeded to the Saidpur village along with other policemen
label: FAC

text: After reaching the place of the incident he recorded the statement of Md Abu Daud and prepared an inquest report
label: FAC

text: He also seized the blood soaked soil ash of ghura and a lantern
label: FAC

text: 4 Post mortem examination of deceased Jumma was conducted by PW 5 at 8 00 a m on 06 01 1984 who found the following injuries on the person of the deceased Md Nadir Sah Jumma i Deep wound with irregular burnt margin size x 2 x 2 over the right cheek with surrounding areas with black stained with comminuted fracture on the right side mandible and maxilla and there was laceration of the surrounding tissues of the tongue
label: FAC

text: Multiple pillets and cork were recovered which were preserved and sealed
label: FAC

text: ii Penetrating wound diameter with burnt and inverted margin over the right coastal cartilage middle of the right nipple caused fracture of the cartilage
label: FAC

text: On further deep dissection the right lunge was found penetrated
label: FAC

text: There was also blood in the left side of chest cavity
label: FAC

text: There was also penetration of lower lobe of the left lung
label: FAC

text: There was hole in the heart
label: FAC

text: There was fracture of the ninth rib
label: FAC

text: There was wound on the back size 1 in diameter with inverted margine
label: FAC

text: 5 Hemorrhage due to the above injuries was the cause of death according to PW 5 and the death had occurred 24 hours prior to the post mortem examination
label: FAC

text: Out of the 11 witnesses who were examined by the Prosecution PWs 3 4 and 6 were the eye witnesses
label: FAC

text: PW 3 deposed that he heard the sound of firing near the house of Samshul when he was returning from Ghasarpur Tola and saw seven accused who were chasing the deceased Md Nadir Sah Jumma Md Abu Daud PW 6 and Md Mobin PW 4
label: FAC

text: Accused Md Jam Alam Md Sahadat and Noor Alam
label: FAC

text: had fired at the deceased near the house of Samshul
label: FAC

text: He stated that he identified the accused by flashing his torch light
label: FAC

text: According to him the police arrived at the place of the incident at 9 00 p m
label: FAC

text: He testified that he did not tell anybody about the incident till the police reached there
label: FAC

text: PW 4 stated in his evidence that he arranged a ghura fireplace with leaves at 6 00 p m on 05 01 1984
label: FAC

text: Md Abu Daud PW 6 and Md Nadir Sah Jumma deceased who came to demand the remaining irrigation dues from him also sat near the ghura
label: FAC

text: At that time a mob of 11 persons suddenly came there
label: FAC

text: He could identify seven out of eleven persons in mob in the light of ghura and of lantern which was hanging in the oriyani veranda
label: FAC

text: He further deposed that he the deceased and PW 6 started running away from the mob
label: FAC

text: The deceased was surrounded by the accused near the southern wall of Samshul s house
label: FAC

text: He was shot dead by the accused Sahadat Md Jam Alam and Noor Alam
label: FAC

text: He stated that Md Jam Alam and Sahadat had guns Noor Alam had a rifle and rest of the accused had lathis
label: FAC

text: PW 6 who is the informant deposed that there was sufficient light cast because of the ghura fire place the lantern and the torch which he was carrying
label: FAC

text: He witnessed the incident from behind the Simal tree which was 15 yards from the place of occurrence
label: FAC

text: 6 The oral testimonies of PWs 3 4 and 6 were examined thoroughly and the trial court was of the opinion that it is not safe to rely on their statements
label: RLC

text: The trial court held that the evidence relating to identification of the accused in the available light was not convincing
label: RLC

text: There is reference to the evidence regarding the lantern in the varanda which was behind the place where the mob was standing and the improbability of their being identified in the light emitted by the lantern
label: RLC

text: The evidence of PW 6 that he flashed a torch light for identifying the accused persons was disbelieved as no torch was seized by the police
label: RLC

text: For the aforesaid reasons the trial court was of the opinion that the eye witnesses could not have identified the accused
label: RLC

text: Previous enmity between the accused on one hand and the informant s family on the other was proved
label: RLC

text: The trial court further found that there was a delay in lodging the FIR which provided an opportunity to the informant and other PWs to implicate their enemies
label: RLC

text: Thus false implication could not be ruled out
label: RLC

text: Further the fardbeyan was recorded in the village at 9 00 p m on 05 01 1984
label: RLC

text: A dead body challan which was prepared by J N Singh Sub Inspector of Police S I which shows that the body was sent for post mortem at 11 00 p m
label: RLC

text: There was also an entry in the station diary that J N Singh S I returned to the police station at 9 00 p m
label: RLC

text: If the fardbeyan was prepared at 9 00 p m at the place of incident which is six kilometers away from the police station J N Singh S I could not have arrived at the police station at 9 00 p m
label: RLC

text: The record shows that he prepared the inquest report at 10 00 p m and the dead body challan at 11 00 p m at the place of occurrence
label: RLC

text: J N Singh S I who is an important witness was not examined by the prosecution
label: RLC

text: Referring to the above circumstances the trial court held that it was clear that the inquest report and the dead body challan were prepared later at the police station
label: RLC

text: An adverse inference was drawn against the Prosecution
label: RLC

text: The trial court also took note of the presence of the Mangal Tanti the Chowkidar of the village who reached the place of the incident in 30 minutes after the incident took place
label: RLC

text: He was not examined as a witness
label: RLC

text: None of the witnesses deposed that they informed the Chowkidar about the incident
label: RLC

text: No independent witness was examined though the village was hardly 200 metres from the place of the incident
label: RLC

text: No pellet or traces of bullets were recovered from the place of the incident
label: RLC

text: On the basis of the above findings along with other contradictions in the evidence of the witnesses the trial court acquitted the Appellants of all the charges against them
label: RLC

text: 7 The Appeals filed by the State and the revision filed by the complainant were taken altogether
label: FAC

text: The High Court appreciated the evidence and found fault with the judgment of the trial court
label: RLC

text: The High Court felt that apart from minor inconsistencies the evidence of the eye witnesses was reliable and there was sufficient light to identify the accused
label: RLC

text: The accused shared a common intention of killing the deceased according to the High Court
label: RLC

text: The delay in registering the FIR was found to be not fatal to the case of the Prosecution
label: RLC

text: The evidence of interested witnesses was also held reliable by the High Court
label: RLC

text: The minor errors in recording the time in the police station and the non examination of J N Singh S I did not prejudice the prosecution s case
label: RLC

text: By differing with the view taken by the trial court on the above points the High Court found that the judgment of the trial court is perverse and that there is only one view possible which leads to the guilt of the accused
label: RLC

text: On the aforesaid findings the High Court convicted the Appellants under Section 302 read with Sections 34 and 148 IPC and sentenced them to life imprisonment
label: RLC

text: 8 The question that falls for determination in this case is whether the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the Appellants and convicting them for an offence of murder
label: ISSUE

text: While holding that there is no limitation placed on the power to review the evidence in an appeal against acquittal Lord Russell in Sheo Swarup v King Emperor1 held 9 the High Court should and will always give proper weight and consideration to such matters as 1 the views of the trial Judge as to the credibility of the witnesses 2 the presumption of innocence in favour of the accused a presumption certainly not weakened by the fact that he has been acquitted at his trial 3 the right of the accused to the benefit of any doubt and 4 the slowness of an appellate Court in disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a 1 1934 36 BOM LR 1185 9 Judge who had the advantage of seeing the witnesses
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9 The approach of the High Court in an appeal against acquittals was explained by this Court in Surajpal Singh Ors v The State2 as follows
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is well established that in an appeal under section 417 of the Criminal Procedure Code the High Court has full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded but it is equally well settled that the presumption of innocence of the accused is further reinforced by his acquittal by the trial court and the findings of the trial court which had the advantage of seeing the witnesses and hearing their evidence can be reversed only for very substantial and compelling reasons
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10 This Court in Muralidhar Gidda Anr v State of Karnataka3 referred to several earlier judgments dealing with appeals against acquittals and observed that the appellate court must bear in mind the following 12 i There is presumption of innocence in favour of an accused person and such 2 1952 3 SCR 193 3 2014 5 SCC 730 12 i iv presumption is strengthened by the order of acquittal passed in his favour by the trial court ii The accused person is entitled to the benefit of reasonable doubt when it deals with the merit of the appeal against acquittal iii Though the powers of the appellate court in considering the appeals against acquittal are as extensive as its powers in appeals against convictions but the appellate court is generally loath in disturbing the finding of fact recorded by the trial court
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It is so because the trial court had an advantage of seeing the demeanour of the witnesses
label: PRE_RELIED

text: If the trial court takes a reasonable view of the facts of the case interference by the appellate court with the judgment of acquittal is not justified
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Unless the conclusions reached by the trial court are palpably wrong or based on erroneous view of the law or if such conclusions are allowed to stand they are likely to result in grave injustice the reluctance on the part of the appellate court in interfering with such conclusions is fully justified and iv Merely because the appellate court on reappreciation and re evaluation of the evidence is inclined to take a different view interference with the judgment of acquittal is not justified if the view taken by the trial court is a possible view
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The evenly balanced views of the evidence must not result in the interference by the appellate court in the judgment of the trial court 11
label: PRE_RELIED

text: It is relevant to refer to another judgment of this Court in Ghurey Lal v State of Uttar Pradesh4 in which the principles to be followed by the appellate courts to overrule or otherwise disturb the trial court s acquittal were crystallised as under 70 1
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The appellate court may only overrule or otherwise disturb the trial court s acquittal if it has very substantial and compelling reasons for doing so
label: PRE_RELIED

text: A number of instances arise in which the appellate court would have very substantial and compelling reasons to discard the trial court s decision
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Very substantial and compelling reasons exist when i The trial court s conclusion with regard to the facts is palpably wrong 4 2008 10 SCC 450 ii The trial court s decision was based on an erroneous view of law iii The trial court s judgment is likely to result in grave miscarriage of justice iv The entire approach of the trial court in dealing with the evidence was patently illegal v The trial court s judgment was manifestly unjust and unreasonable vi The trial court has ignored the evidence or misread the material evidence or has ignored material documents like dying declarations report of the ballistic expert etc
label: PRE_RELIED

text: vii This list is intended to be illustrative not exhaustive
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 2 The appellate court must always give proper weight and consideration to the findings of the trial court
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 3 If two reasonable views can be reached one that leads to acquittal the other to conviction the High Courts appellate courts must rule in favour of the accused
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 12 Interference with the judgment of the trial court in this case by the High Court is on a re appreciation of evidence which is undoubtedly permissible
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though the High Court was aware of the well settled principles of law in matters relating to appeals against acquittals it failed to apply the same in their proper perspective
label: ANALYSIS

text: Interference with an order of acquittal is not permissible on the ground that a different view is possible
label: ANALYSIS

text: If the acquittal is justified on a probable view taken by the trial court it should not be interfered with
label: ANALYSIS

text: The reasons given by the trial court for acquittal mainly pertain to the delay in lodging the FIR untrustworthy eye witnesses improbability of identification of the accused non examination of independent witnesses previous enmity between the accused and the witnesses non production of important prosecution witnesses and improper investigation of the case
label: ANALYSIS

text: On a thorough examination of the entire evidence on record and the judgment of the trial court we are of the considered view that the judgment of acquittal by the trial court is justified which ought not to have been interfered with by the High Court
label: RATIO

text: The High Court could not have reversed a judgment of acquittal merely because another view is possible
label: RATIO

text: The High Court brushed aside the findings recorded by the trial court relating to certain omissions as being minor and held the omissions should not have been the basis on which the Appellants have been acquitted
label: RATIO

text: The High Court ignored the fact that the presumption of innocence in favour of the Appellants is further strengthened by an order of acquittal
label: RATIO

text: No perversity in the judgment of the trial court in acquitting the Appellants has been demonstrated by the High Court for interfering with the judgment of the trial court
label: RATIO

text: 13 For the aforementioned reasons the Appeals are allowed
label: RPC

text: The judgment of the High Court is set aside and the judgment of the trial court is restored
label: RPC

text: The Appellant No 3 was released on bail on 30 01 2017
label: RPC

text: His bail bonds are discharged
label: RPC

text: J L NAGESWARA RAO
label: NONE

text: J R SUBHASH REDDY
label: NONE

text: New Delhi December 04 2018
label: NONE

text: PETITIONER SUPERINTENDENT TECH I CENTRAL EXCISE I D D JABALPUR AND Vs RESPONDENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: PRATAP RAI
label: PREAMBLE

text: DATE OF JUDGMENT26 04 1978
label: PREAMBLE

text: BENCH FAZALALI SYED MURTAZA BENCH FAZALALI SYED MURTAZA SINGH JASWANT PATHAK R S CITATION 1978 AIR 1244 1978 SCR 3 729 4 1978 SCC 3 113 CITATOR INFO R 1981 SC 858 ACT Natural Justice Principles of When an order is struck down by the appellate authority being in violation of the principles of natural justice there is no final decision and fresh proceedings can be taken Interpretation of the Appellate Collector s orders Words and Phrases Meaning of without prejudice Customs Act Section 122 and 128 HEADNOTE Twenty three watches on which no custom duty was paid were seized from the respondent by the Customs Authorities and in the adjudication proceedings under section 122 of the Customs Act the Assistant Collector of Customs ordered that the watches which were seized be confiscated and imposed a penalty of Rs 250 on the respondent under Section 112 of the Act
label: PREAMBLE

text: In appeal the Appellate Collector by his order dated 22 2 1972 vacated without prejudice the order of the Assistant Collector mainly on the ground that the Assistant Collector had not complied with the rules of natural justice
label: PREAMBLE

text: The department interpreted the order as an implied order of remand and issued a fresh notice to the respondent on 27 7 1972 and started fresh adjudication proceedings
label: PREAMBLE

text: Thereafter the respondent filed in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh a writ petition which was allowed
label: PREAMBLE

text: The notice and the fresh adjudication proceedings were quashed
label: PREAMBLE

text: Allowing the appeal by special leave the Court HELD 1
label: PREAMBLE

text: Where an order passed in appeal vacates the order of the first tribunal on purely technical grounds and expressly states that it was being passed without prejudice which means an order not on the merits of the case such an order does not debar fresh adjudicatory proceedings which may be justified under the law
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is necessary for the court interpreting an order of this kind to give full and complete effect to the exact words used by the authorities and not to draw a sweeping conclusion merely from the fact that no explicit direction has been made by the appellate authority
label: PREAMBLE

text: 735 C D 2 a Whenever an order is struck down as invalid being in violation of the principles of natural justice there is no final decision of the cause and fresh proceedings are left open
label: PREAMBLE

text: All that is done is that the order assailed by virtue of its inherent defect is vacated but the proceedings are not terminated 732
label: PREAMBLE

text: C b In the instant case A perusal of the order of the Appellate Authority clearly shows two important facts 1 that the Appellant Collector has not set aside or vacated the order of the Assistant Collector on merits but has vacated it only on a technical infirmity namely the violation of the rules of natural justice and that is why the Appellate Collector has
label: PREAMBLE

text: advisedly
label: PREAMBLE

text: used the words without prejudice in his order
label: PREAMBLE

text: 2 that the Assistant Collector in his order dated 30th June 1969 had directed confiscation of the watches and imposed a penalty of Rs 250 and if the Appellate Collector intended to set aside this order completely and irrevocably then he should have passed a consequential order for refund of the amount of the penalty and release of the property confiscated The fact that no such order was passed by the Appellate Collector clearly shows that he never intended to bar fresh adjudicatory proceedings provided they were conducted according to the principles of natural justice
label: PREAMBLE

text: 731 A 732 A C ii The Appellate Collector found that the order of the Assistant Collector suffered from a serious procedural infirmity viz that it was passed without 12 315SCI 78giving the respondent a proper opportunity of being heard and therefore it cannot be said that fresh proceedings by complying with the rules of natural justice could not be started against the respondent
label: PREAMBLE

text: The Appellate Collector has clearly used the words without prejudice which also indicate that the order of the Collector was not final and irrevocable
label: PREAMBLE

text: 732 G H 733 A M s Thimmasamudram Tobacco Co v Assistant Collector of Central Excise Nellore Dt Nellore A I R 1961 A P 324 approved 3
label: PREAMBLE

text: a The implication of the term without prejudice means 1 that the cause or the matter has not been decided on merits 2 that fresh proceedings according to law were not barred
label: PREAMBLE

text: It is true that the Appellate Collector does not say in so many words that the case is remanded to the Assistant Collector but the tenor and the spirit of the order
label: PREAMBLE

text: clearly shows that what he intended was that fresh proceedings should be started against the respondent after complying with the rules of natural justice
label: PREAMBLE

text: 733E F
label: PREAMBLE

text: b A true interpretation of the order of the Appellate Collector would be that the order of the Assistant Collector was a nullity having violated the rules of natural justice and having been vacated the parties would be relegated to the position which they occupied before the order of the Assistant Collector was passed
label: PREAMBLE

text: In this view of the matter the Assistant Collector had ample jurisdiction in issuing the notice against the respondent in order to start fresh adjudicatory proceedings in accordance with law
label: PREAMBLE

text: 733F G
label: PREAMBLE

text: Collector of Central Excise Madras v K Pulappa Nadar A I R 1964 Mad III and The Marsden Spg and Co Ltd v Shri L V Pol Superintendent of Central Excise Tax I L R 1965 Guj III criticised discussed and distin
label: PREAMBLE

text: guished
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No 363 of 1978
label: NONE

text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th November 1976 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in M P No 32 of 1973
label: NONE

text: E C Agarwala and Girish Chandra for the Appellant
label: NONE

text: Naunit Lal and Kailash Vasdev for Respondent
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZAL ALI
label: NONE

text: J This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court dated 19th November 1976 by which the High Court quashed the notice dated 27th July 1972 issued by the Assistant Collector of Customs and also quashed fresh adjudication proceedings started by him under the provisions of the Customs Act hereinafter referred to as the Act
label: FAC

text: The appeal lies within a very narrow compass and turns upon the interpretation of the order passed by the appellate authority under section 128 of the Act
label: FAC

text: On 27th February 1969 the respondent Pratap Rai was detrained at Jabalpur by the Customs authorities while he was travelling by the Bombay Janta Express
label: FAC

text: On being searched as many as 23 wrist watches on which no custom duty was paid were recovered from his person
label: FAC

text: Thereafter adjudication proceedings under section 122 of the Act were commenced by the Assistant Col lector of Customs which culminated in the order of the AssistantCollector dated 30th June 1969 by which the watches were seized and ordered to be confiscated
label: FAC

text: A penalty of Rs 250 was levied on the respondent under section 112 of the Act
label: FAC

text: The respondent then carried an appeal to the Appellate Collector under section 128 of the Act against the order of the Assistant Collector
label: FAC

text: The Appellate Collector by his order dated 22nd February 1972 vacated the order of the Assistant Collector mainly on the ground that the Assistant Collector had not complied with the rules of natural justice
label: FAC

text: The fate of this case depends on the interpretation of the order passed by the Appellate Collector
label: FAC

text: In order to appreciate the point in issue it may be necessary to extract the relevant portion of the order of the Appellate Collector which runs thus The adjudication therefore suffers for lack of principle of natural justice inasmuch as adequate opportunities were not given to the appellant to defend his case
label: FAC

text: 1 therefore without prejudice vacate the order of the adjudication passed by the Assistant Collector Central Excice Jabalpur Emphasis supplied
label: FAC

text: The department appears to have interpreted the aforesaid order as an implied cider of remand and issued a fresh notice to the respondent on the 27th July 1972 and started fresh adjudication proceeding according to the implied direction of the Appellate Collector
label: FAC

text: Thereafter the respondent filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh assailing the notice and praying that the proceedings started by the Assistant Collector even after the vacation of the order by the Appellate Collector be quashed
label: FAC

text: The plea taken by the respondent appears to have found favour with the High Court which allowed the petition quashed the notice as also the fresh adjudication proceedings
label: FAC

text: The appellant obtained special leave of this Court against the order of the High Court and hence this appeal before us
label: FAC

text: The only point that was contended before us by Mr E C Agrawala appearing in support of the appeal was that the High Court has erred in not properly interpreting the order of the Appellate Collector
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: According to the learned counsel a true and plain interpretation of the order of the Appellate Collector would clearly reveal that he had merely vacated the order of the Assistant Collector because it suffered from a technical infirmity and had not barred the commencement of fresh adjudicatory proceedings
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Mr Naunit Lal appearing for the respondent however submitted that there was no clear direction in the order of the Appellate Collector from which it could be inferred that he had remanded the case and therefore there was no jurisdiction in the Assistant Collector to issue a fresh notice or start adjudicatory proceedings against the respondent
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In our opinion the contention of counsel for the appellants appears to be sound and must prevail
label: ANALYSIS

text: A perusal of the order of the Appellate Collector extracted above clearly shows two important facts 1 that the Appellate Collector has not set aside or vacated the orderof the Assistant Collector on merits but has vacated it only on a technical infirmity namely the violation of the rules of_natural justice and that is why the Appellate Collector has advised used the words without prejudice in his order 2 that the Assistant Collector in his order dated 30th June 1969 had directed confiscation of the watches and imposed a penalty of Rs 250 and if the Appellate Collector intended to set aside this order completely and irrevocably then he should have passed a consequential order for refund of the amount of the penalty and release of the property confiscated
label: ANALYSIS

text: The fact that no such order was passed by the Appellate Collector clearly shows that he never intended to bar fresh adjudicatory proceedings provided they were conducted according to the principles of natural justice
label: ANALYSIS

text: It seems to us that whenever an order is struck down as invalid being in violation of the principles of natural justice there is no final decision of the cause and fresh proceedings are left open
label: ANALYSIS

text: AR that is done is that the order assailed by virtue of its inherent defect is vacated but the proceedings are not terminated
label: ANALYSIS
